Despite large iron and coal reserves, global competition reduced extraction after 1974. Key active mines include Panasqueira and Neves-Corvo.

Portugal's industrial sector includes automotive, aerospace, electronics, textiles, food, chemicals, cement, and wood pulp. Key investments like Volkswagen's AutoEuropa plant highlight significant foreign involvement. The country has expanded into modern industries such as aerospace, biotechnology, and information technology, with major hubs in cities like Lisbon, Porto, and Coimbra.

Portugal's tourism sector faces growing competition from cheaper Eastern European destinations like Croatia. To remain competitive, Portugal is focusing on niche markets such as health, nature, and rural tourism.

In 2007, Portugal was labeled Europe's "new sick man" due to its struggling economy. Unemployment rose sharply from 2002 to 2007, reaching a 23-year high of 10.2% by late 2009. Credit agencies downgraded Portugal's ratings, citing structural economic weaknesses and a growing risk of default, which culminated in further downgrades by 2011.

In April 2011, Portugal sought IMF and EU financial aid after parliament rejected the prime minister's austerity plan, marking its third IMF request since the 1970s. Later that year, Moody's downgraded nine Portuguese banks due to financial weakness.

Portugal's public sector in 2005 had more employees per capita than the EU average. Its justice system was notably slow and inefficient, ranking second slowest in Western Europe by 2011, despite having a high number of judges and prosecutors. The broader public service was characterized by mismanagement, redundancies, bureaucratic excess, and low productivity, especially in justice.

In May 2013, Portugal's Prime Minister Passos Coelho announced austerity measures, including cutting 30,000 public sector jobs and extending the workweek from 35 to 40 hours. These steps aim to avoid another international bailout, targeting €4.8 billion in savings over three years.

Prime Minister Passos Coelho raised the retirement age and cut pensions, unemployment benefits, and public spending in health, education, and science, while exempting judges, diplomats, military, and police from similar reductions. He also reduced politicians' salaries. These austerity measures sparked social unrest and institutional conflicts, including with the Constitutional Court, and drew criticism even from within the government's supporting parties.

Portugal's unemployment rate peaked at 17.7% in early 2013, then fell steadily to 11.9% by mid-2015. Despite this decline, it remained higher than the pre-2008 average of around 7.3%, having risen sharply following the global financial crisis.

Portugal's motorway system expanded significantly from the 1970s onward, driven by economic growth and European integration. The first motorway opened in 1944, but major construction began in the 1980s. Today, the network spans about 3,000 km of motorways, managed largely by concessionaire Brisa, with tolls common on many routes. The Vasco da Gama Bridge is Europe's longest.

Portugal has four main international airports in Lisbon, Porto, Faro, and Beja, with Lisbon serving as a key hub. TAP Portugal is the primary airline, though others operate domestically and internationally. Plans to replace Lisbon’s airport with one in Alcochete are on hold due to austerity. Major airports, managed by ANA, include those in Lisbon, Porto, Faro, Funchal, and Ponta Delgada.

Portugal's national railway system, operated by Comboios de Portugal (CP), spans 2,791 km with 1,430 km electrified and 900 km supporting speeds over 120 km/h. Managed by REFER, CP transported 133 million passengers and 9.75 million tons of goods in 2006.

Lisbon and Porto have subway systems, each over 35 km long. Lisbon's tram service has operated for over a century, while Porto's tram network, now mainly a tourist line, began in 1895. All major cities have local transport and taxis.

Portugal's scientific research is primarily carried out by R&D units in public universities and state institutions such as INETI and INRB. This system is funded and overseen by the Ministry of Science, Technology and Higher Education and its Foundation for Science and Technology. Leading university research units, notable in biosciences, include the Institute of Molecular Medicine and the Centre for Neuroscience and Cell Biology.

Portugal has established multiple science parks, such as Taguspark and Coimbra iParque, to foster scientific and technological businesses by offering them financial, legal, marketing, and tech support services.

Portugal's REN uses advanced modeling to forecast wind and optimize renewable energy. Hydropower, long-established, now integrates with wind: turbines pump water uphill at night, releasing it to generate power during peak daytime demand. The grid also supports two-way distribution, incentivizing small-scale solar contributions via premium pricing.

Portugal's 2011 population was estimated at 10.6 million, with a historically homogeneous makeup due to Catholicism and the Portuguese language. While Moors and Jews were expelled, many stayed as converts, some secretly practicing Judaism. The distinction between Old and New Christians ended in 1772.

Portuguese ancestry primarily traces back to Paleolithic peoples who arrived in Europe around 45,000 years ago. While later migrations contributed genetically and culturally, the Paleolithic population remains the main source. Genetically, Portuguese people are similar to other Europeans.

Portugal's colonial past shapes its identity, having been one of the last European powers to relinquish overseas territories like Angola, Mozambique, and Macau. This history has fostered cultural exchange and immigration from former colonies, transforming Portugal from a nation of emigration to one of net immigration. By 2007, it had over 10.6 million inhabitants, including about 332,000 legal immigrants.

Over 80% of Portuguese identify as Roman Catholic, with minority religious groups including Protestants, Muslims, Hindus, and others. A small percentage are non-religious or did not specify their faith.

Portuguese holidays and traditions often have Christian roots. Historically, the Catholic Church held significant wealth and influence, especially during the reconquest and early nationalism, and later through missionary work in the empire. However, liberal and republican movements before the First Republic altered the church's role.

The white inescutcheon features five blue shields with white bezants, symbolizing Christ's five wounds and linked to the Miracle of Ourique. Before the 1139 Battle of Ourique, a hermit prophesied Count Afonso Henriques' victory. That night, after hearing a chapel bell, Afonso saw an apparition of Jesus on the cross, who promised future victories and a divine mission for Portugal to spread His name.

Predatory lending involves unethical lenders enticing borrowers into risky secured loans for improper purposes. A common tactic is the bait-and-switch, where companies like Countrywide Financial advertised low interest rates but ultimately provided more costly adjustable rate mortgages (ARMs) at closing. This practice can lead to negative amortization, often unnoticed by borrowers until much later.

Countrywide was sued by California Attorney General Jerry Brown for unfair business practices and false advertising related to high-cost mortgages offered to homeowners with poor credit. These adjustable-rate mortgages (ARMs) allowed interest-only payments, leading to financial strain when housing prices fell. Consequently, this situation worsened Countrywide's financial stability, resulting in its seizure by the Office of Thrift Supervision.

Critics, including economist Paul Krugman and Treasury Secretary Timothy Geithner, argue that financial regulations lagged behind innovations like shadow banking and derivatives. An OECD study indicates that Basel-based regulations may have encouraged risky practices that worsened the financial crisis, while some laws were altered or enforcement diminished in certain financial sectors.

Before the crisis, financial institutions became highly leveraged and increasingly engaged in risky investments, weakening their ability to absorb losses. This leverage was largely due to complex financial instruments like off-balance sheet securitization and derivatives, complicating risk monitoring and making bankruptcy reorganization difficult, which ultimately led to government bailouts.

From 2004 to 2007, major U.S. investment banks increased financial leverage, raising their risk of financial shocks. Changes in capital requirements allowed lower risk weightings for AAA securities, viewed by regulators as a risk reduction. By 2007, the top five banks reported over $4.1 trillion in debt, about 30% of the U.S. GDP. Lehman Brothers declared bankruptcy, while Bear Stearns and Merrill Lynch were sold, and Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley became regulated commercial banks. Except for Lehman, these institutions required government support, with Lehman unsuccessfully seeking buyers in Bank of America and Barclays.

The paradox of thrift occurs when many individuals save simultaneously, leading to reduced consumption and potentially deepening a recession, as one person's saving reduces another's income. Similarly, Hyman Minsky's "paradox of deleveraging" highlights that financial institutions with high debt cannot all reduce their leverage at once without causing significant asset value declines.

In April 2009, Janet Yellen highlighted a negative feedback loop between a severe credit crunch and a recession, which worsened as demand and employment declined. This led to widespread balance sheet deleveraging, with consumers reducing spending, businesses halting investments and laying off workers, and financial institutions shrinking assets to strengthen capital. Yellen referenced Minsky's concept of the paradox of deleveraging, where individual precautions, while necessary for recovery, intensify overall economic distress.

Financial innovation involves the creation of financial products to meet specific client needs, such as managing risk or securing financing. Key examples related to the financial crisis include adjustable-rate mortgages, the bundling of subprime mortgages into mortgage-backed securities (MBS) and collateralized debt obligations (CDO), and credit default swaps (CDS). The use of these complex financial products surged prior to the crisis, impacting their valuation within financial institutions.

CDO issuance surged from $20 billion in Q1 2004 to over $180 billion by Q1 2007, then plummeted below $20 billion by Q1 2008. The credit quality of CDOs deteriorated during this period, with subprime and non-prime mortgage debt rising from 5% to 36% of assets. The use of synthetic CDOs allowed for excessive speculation on housing loans, leading to significant risks when CDOs became worthless.

This distance from the actual assets fostered opportunities for fraud and misjudgment, contributing to the market collapse. A computational model created in 2005 by computer scientists accurately reflected the biased ratings of rating agencies observed during the 2006–2008 crisis.

The pricing of risk involves the extra compensation investors seek for taking on additional risk, often reflected in interest rates or fees. Scholars argue that insufficient transparency regarding banks' risk exposures hindered accurate risk pricing prior to the crisis, allowed the mortgage market to expand excessively, and exacerbated the financial crisis by obscuring risk levels.

Market participants failed to accurately assess the risks of financial innovations like MBS and CDOs, impacting financial stability. The pricing models for CDOs underestimated the risks involved. Between late 2005 and mid-2007, $450 billion in CDOs were sold, but among the $102 billion liquidated, recovery rates were low, averaging 32 cents on the dollar for high-quality CDOs and five cents for mezzanine CDOs.

AIG insured financial institutions using credit default swaps (CDS) but lacked the financial strength to fulfill its commitments as the crisis deepened, leading to a government takeover in September 2008. U.S. taxpayers provided over $180 billion in support to AIG, which was used to pay various counterparties, including major global financial institutions.

As financial assets grew more complex and difficult to value, investors were misled by mathematical models that underestimated risks. George Soros noted that the situation worsened when authorities relied on banks' risk management and the rating agencies depended on information from synthetic product originators, which he described as a significant abdication of responsibility.

Before the financial crisis, the industry sought to address the limitations of existing models, particularly in representing dependence dynamics and extreme events. A 2007 volume titled "Credit Correlation: Life After Copulas" summarizes a 2006 Merrill Lynch conference where practitioners proposed solutions to these issues. Notable works by Donnelly and Embrechts, along with Brigo, Pallavicini, and Torresetti, also highlighted concerns and research on CDOs from 2006.

In a June 2008 speech, Timothy Geithner attributed the freezing of credit markets to a "run" on the shadow banking system, which, lacking regulatory oversight, became essential to the financial system. These entities faced risks due to maturity mismatches, borrowing short-term to invest in long-term, illiquid assets, making them vulnerable to rapid deleveraging during credit market disruptions.

The traditional banking system lacked the necessary capital to fill this gap, with the Brookings Institution noting it would take years of strong profits to support increased lending. Some forms of securitization may permanently disappear due to excessively loose credit conditions.

In January 2010, economist Mark Zandi testified that the securitization markets were impaired due to anticipated loan losses and uncertainty surrounding legal and regulatory changes. Private bond issuance of mortgage-backed securities and CDOs had drastically declined from nearly $2 trillion in 2006 to under $150 billion in 2009, primarily due to the Federal Reserve's TALF program supporting asset-backed securities.

Following the collapse of the housing bubble, commodity prices surged, with oil prices soaring from $50 to $147 between early 2007 and 2008 before crashing amidst the financial crisis. Experts attribute this to factors like speculative investments, monetary policy, and perceived scarcity of resources, particularly due to increased Chinese investment in Africa. Rising oil prices shift consumer spending toward gasoline, negatively impacting economic growth in importing countries while benefitting oil-producing states. The volatility of oil prices in the preceding decade is considered a contributing factor to the financial crisis.
Despite this, ICE had been regulated by U.S. and European authorities since acquiring the International Petroleum Exchange in 2001, and Greenberger was later corrected on this point.

Raghuram Rajan, current Governor of the Reserve Bank of India, predicted a financial crisis in 2005 during his tenure as chief economist at the IMF. In a critical paper presented at a celebration for Alan Greenspan, he warned that financial sector managers were incentivized to take significant risks with potentially severe consequences, known as tail risks. Rajan highlighted the importance of banks' ability to provide liquidity to mitigate the effects on the real economy if such risks materialized.

The financial crisis caught most mainstream economists off guard, except Raghuram Rajan, who focused on the Great Moderation. In contrast, several heterodox economists, including Dean Baker and Nouriel Roubini, accurately predicted the crisis. Dirk Bezemer identified twelve economists who forecasted it, highlighting varying analyses. The Austrian economic school viewed the crisis as a validation of their theories on credit-fueled bubbles and criticized the lax monetary policies, a sentiment even acknowledged by former Fed Chair Alan Greenspan.

A BusinessWeek cover story highlights that economists largely failed to foresee the recent global financial crisis, deemed the worst since the Great Depression. The Wharton School's online journal explores this failure, noting that public perception has been shaped by media articles suggesting economists neglected their predictive responsibilities. Notably, economist Nouriel Roubini warned of a crisis in September 2006 but faced ridicule for his predictions, earning the nickname "Dr. Doom."

Nassim Nicholas Taleb, a stock trader and financial risk engineer, warned about the banking system's fragility due to flawed risk models and forecasting, as discussed in his book The Black Swan. He capitalized on this insight by betting against banking stocks, profiting from the financial crisis. David Brooks noted that Taleb not only predicted the crisis but also understood its underlying causes.

Market strategist Phil Dow notes differences between the current market downturn and the Great Depression, highlighting that while both saw significant declines in the Dow Jones average, the current situation lacks the same rapid descent observed in 2007. Floyd Norris of The New York Times points out that although the decline amounts were similar, the current downturn has only ranked eighth in worst percentage drops, with the past two years being third.

Despite initial resistance to nationalization, the British government took control of the bank in February 2008 after failing to find a private buyer. This incident signaled broader issues for other banks and financial institutions.

IndyMac frequently issued loans without verifying borrowers' income or creditworthiness, often relying on questionable appraisals. As an Alt-A lender, it utilized risky loan products like option ARMs and subprime loans, leading to many borrowers being unable to repay. The company's profitability depended on selling these loans in the secondary market, and it resisted regulatory efforts to tighten lending criteria.

During the economic crisis from 2007 to 2009, 63% of American households experienced a decline in wealth, with 77% of the wealthiest families affected. In contrast, only 50% of the poorest families saw a decrease, and half of them maintained their wealth.

In November 2008, the European Commission predicted a mere 0.1% growth for the Eurozone in 2009, with the UK, Ireland, and Spain expected to see negative growth. The IMF forecasted a global recession of -0.3% for developed economies. Concurrently, the Bank of England and the European Central Bank cut interest rates, prompting several countries to introduce large economic support packages.

The U.S. Federal Reserve and global central banks have expanded money supplies to prevent deflation caused by falling wages and rising unemployment, while governments have implemented large fiscal stimulus packages to counter reduced private sector demand. The Fed's expanded liquidity facilities aimed to support its role as a lender of last resort, reducing stigma and broadening access to liquidity for various institutions.

The credit freeze nearly collapsed the global financial system, prompting central banks to respond with unprecedented measures. In late 2008, they injected $2.5 trillion into the credit market by purchasing government debt and troubled assets. Following the UK’s bank rescue model, U.S. and European governments guaranteed bank debts and raised capital, acquiring $1.5 trillion in preferred stock from major banks. In October 2010, Joseph Stiglitz noted the Federal Reserve's strategy of creating $600 billion to encourage domestic lending. However, banks redirected these funds towards more profitable international investments, which raised concerns about potential currency wars as China shifted its currency holdings away from the U.S.

In June 2009, President Barack Obama and advisers introduced regulatory proposals focused on consumer protection, executive pay, bank capital requirements, shadow banking, and enhanced Federal Reserve authority to manage systemically important institutions. In January 2010, Obama proposed additional regulations to limit banks' proprietary trading, known as "The Volcker Rule," named after Paul Volcker, who advocated for these changes.

In May 2010, the U.S. Senate passed a reform bill, following the House's December 2009 approval. The two bills need reconciliation. The New York Times compared their features, noting that they address the Obama administration's principles differently. Notably, the Senate bill allows regulators discretion regarding the Volcker Rule on proprietary trading, but does not mandate its prohibition.

The crisis threatened major financial institutions, leading to government bailouts while global stock markets fell. It adversely affected the housing market, causing evictions and unemployment. The crisis contributed to key business failures, a significant decline in consumer wealth, and a global recession from 2008 to 2012, as well as the European sovereign-debt crisis. It began on August 9, 2007, when BNP Paribas halted withdrawals from hedge funds due to a liquidity crisis.

The U.S. housing bubble burst in 2004, leading to a significant drop in real estate-related securities and causing global financial turmoil. This crisis was fueled by policies promoting home ownership, easy loans for subprime borrowers, overvalued mortgages, questionable trading practices, and insufficient capital reserves in banks. The resulting concerns over bank solvency and reduced credit availability affected global stock markets, causing widespread economic slowdown and declining international trade. In response, governments implemented extensive fiscal and monetary measures, including the U.S. American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009.

The financial crisis has various suggested causes, with the U.S. Senate's Levin–Coburn Report attributing it to risky financial products, undisclosed conflicts of interest, and regulatory failures. The Financial Crisis Inquiry Commission identified avoidable factors including inadequate financial regulation, poor corporate governance, excessive borrowing, and lack of transparency in financial institutions. Additionally, government responses contributed to uncertainty, while the repeal of the Glass-Steagall Act removed barriers between investment and depository banks. Critics noted that credit rating agencies mispriced risks, and regulatory practices failed to adapt to modern financial markets. Interest rate spreads have also been examined in relation to the crisis.

The rise of mortgage-backed securities (MBS) and collateralized debt obligations (CDO) during the housing and credit booms allowed global investments in the U.S. housing market. However, as housing prices fell, major financial institutions faced substantial losses from their investments in subprime MBS.

Falling home prices led to mortgages exceeding property values, incentivizing foreclosure. The foreclosure crisis, starting in late 2006, has drained consumer wealth and weakened banks, with defaults spreading beyond housing. Global losses are estimated in the trillions of dollars.

The financial system expanded and became fragile due to financialization, driven by U.S. government policies favoring deregulation since the 1970s. This led to reduced oversight and lack of transparency regarding the activities of banks and emerging financial institutions, particularly investment banks and hedge funds, which gained significant importance in providing credit but remained less regulated than commercial banks.

Financial institutions faced heavy debt from loans, lacking the capacity to handle defaults or losses from mortgage-backed securities (MBS), which hindered lending and slowed the economy. In response, central banks provided funds to support lending and restore confidence in commercial paper markets, while governments bailed out key banks and launched stimulus programs, increasing their financial commitments.

The U.S. Financial Crisis Inquiry Commission's January 2011 report concluded that the financial crisis was avoidable, citing failures in regulation, reckless corporate governance, excessive borrowing, unprepared policymakers, and breaches in accountability and ethics.

During heightened competition among mortgage lenders, underwriting standards were relaxed, leading to riskier loans for less creditworthy borrowers. Before 2003, government-sponsored enterprises (GSEs) maintained stricter standards, but as competition from private securitizers grew, the quality of mortgages declined, peaking in riskiness between 2004 and 2007 when GSE market share was lowest.

The majority report by the Financial Crisis Inquiry Commission's Democratic appointees and the minority report by Republican appointees, along with studies from Federal Reserve economists and independent scholars, argue that government affordable housing policy was not the primary cause of the financial crisis. While acknowledging some governmental influence, they assert that GSE loans outperformed those from private investment banks and some institutional loans. Paul Krugman claims GSEs never purchased subprime loans, though this is debated.

Peter J. Wallison, in his dissent to the Financial Crisis Inquiry Commission, attributed the financial crisis primarily to 1990s affordable housing policies by HUD and risky loan purchases by Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac. He and Edward Pinto later estimated that in 2008, Fannie and Freddie held 13 million substandard loans worth over $2 trillion.

In the early 2000s, the Bush administration urged investigations into the safety of Government-Sponsored Enterprises (GSEs) and their subprime mortgage portfolios. A 2003 House Financial Services Committee hearing examined a report revealing accounting issues at Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac. However, the hearings did not lead to new legislation or investigations, as committee members largely dismissed the report, ignoring potential systemic risks from subprime mortgages.

A 2000 U.S. Treasury study found that from 1993 to 1998, CRA-covered lenders provided $467 billion in mortgage loans to low and moderate-income borrowers, representing 10% of all U.S. mortgage lending, primarily in prime loans. By 1998, CRA-covered institutions held a 3% market share of sub-prime loans, but 25% of all sub-prime lending was connected to CRA during the crisis. However, a 2009 Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas analysis concluded that the CRA did not cause the mortgage crisis, noting that poor lending practices arose a decade after CRA rules were established and that most sub-prime loans were not directed at the CRA's target demographic. There was no evidence that CRA lending increased delinquency rates or influenced independent mortgage lenders to increase sub-prime lending.

Analysts argue that the delay between CRA rule changes in 1995 and the surge in subprime lending does not absolve the CRA. They identify two key factors leading to the crisis: relaxed underwriting standards in 1995 and low interest rates post-9/11. Critics note that CRA loan commitments reached $4.5 trillion from 1994 to 2007 and challenge the Federal Reserve's classification of CRA loans as “prime,” claiming it incorrectly equates high-interest loans with subprime status.

Critics argue that the number of bad loans was insufficient to trigger a crisis. Michael Lewis highlighted that investment banks and hedge funds used financial innovations, such as credit default swaps and synthetic CDOs, to enable large bets that exceeded the actual value of the underlying mortgage loans.

Peter J. Wallison argues against Krugman, stating that not all large bubbles lead to financial crises upon deflation. He points out that other developed countries experienced significant bubbles from 1997 to 2007 but faced lower losses than the U.S. He attributes the U.S. housing bubble's crisis to a high number of substandard loans, often with little or no down payments.

Agricultural production on the island is challenging due to its dry and rocky terrain, yet early settlers cultivated various crops such as vegetables, cotton, and bananas, alongside fishing. The port of Gustavia facilitated commerce, enhancing the island's prosperity through duty-free trade and high-end tourism, leading to a high standard of living for its residents.

The island's arid terrain features poor soil, mainly supporting cacti and succulents, while the rainy season brings lush vegetation, particularly in the eastern region with higher rainfall. A 1994 survey identified hundreds of indigenous plant species, with irrigated areas hosting various flora and dry areas dominated by cacti. Common plants include sea grapes, palm trees, mangroves, and shrubs, with coconut palms introduced from the Pacific.

Notable trees include royal palms, sea grape trees, aloe vera, night blooming cereus, mamillaria nivosa, yellow prickly pear, Mexican cactus, stapelia gigantea, and golden trumpet. Yellow prickly pear was used as a defense against British forces in 1773.

Marine mammals, including dolphins, porpoises, and whales, migrate from December to May. Turtles are also common along the coastline, with some species endangered and taking 15–50 years to reach reproductive age. Notable species include leatherback turtles, the largest at up to 3 m and 450 kg, hawksbill turtles, about 90 cm and 60 kg, and green turtles, also around 90 cm, which are herbivores. Female turtles come ashore to lay eggs and are protected by private organizations.

The marine life includes anemones, urchins, sea cucumbers, eels, turtles, conch, and various fish species such as sergeant majors and blue tangs. Conch, known for its pearly-pink shells, is popular for its meat and as a collector's item. Ghost crabs and hermit crabs inhabit the shore, with hermit crabs laying eggs in water and feeding on waste.

The town features three Swedish forts built for defense. Fort Oscar, now replaced by a military building, overlooks the sea. Fort Karl has minimal ruins remaining, while Fort Gustav, constructed in 1787, has ruins of its ramparts and other structures near the weather station and lighthouse.

Grande Saline Bay offers temporary anchorage for small vessels, while Colombier Bay features a 4 fathoms patch at its entrance. St. Jean Bay contains a narrow cut through the reef, with visible coral reefs along the island's north and east coasts. The coastal areas are rich in beaches, many with offshore reefs that are part of a marine reserve.

The island spans 25 square kilometers, with a climate that is mostly arid and an average annual rainfall of 1000 mm, varying across the terrain. The rainy season lasts from May to November, while December to April is dry. Sunshine is prevalent year-round, and humidity remains low due to winds. Average temperatures are around 25 °C, peaking at 32 °C during the day, with January highs of 28 °C and lows of 22 °C, and July highs of 30 °C and lows of 24 °C. The lowest recorded night temperature is 13 °C, and nearby sea waters average 27 °C.

In 1744, the British invasion led to the destruction of a harbour town's architecture. New structures were built, and in 1785, the Swedes occupied the town, renaming it Gustavia after King Gustav III. It became a prime trading center, operating as a neutral port during the Caribbean war, but its prosperity was short-lived.
The genome is the genetic material of an organism, comprising DNA (or RNA in RNA viruses) and includes both genes and non-coding sequences.

The term "genome" was coined in 1920 by Hans Winkler, a botany professor at the University of Hamburg. It combines "gene" and "chromosome," fitting into a broader vocabulary that includes terms like biome and rhizome.

Some organisms have varying chromosome counts, such as diploid, triploid, and tetraploid. In sexually reproducing eukaryotes, gametes possess half the chromosome number of somatic cells, achieved through meiosis. Haploid organisms, including bacteria and some viruses, have a single set of DNA or RNA. The term "genome" refers to the complete set of nuclear DNA or the DNA within organelles like mitochondria and chloroplasts, and can also include non-chromosomal elements like viruses and plasmids.

Sequencing a sexually reproducing species' genome typically means determining the sequences of one set of autosomes and each type of sex chromosome, representing both sexes. In some cases, a "genome sequence" may be a composite from various individuals. The term "genetic makeup" can refer to an individual's genome. The study of genomes across related organisms is called genomics, while genetics focuses on individual genes or groups.

The number of base pairs and genes varies significantly among species, with a rough correlation known as the C-value paradox. The highest known gene count is about 60,000 in a protozoan causing trichomoniasis, nearly three times that of the human genome.

In 1976, Walter Fiers sequenced the first viral RNA genome (Bacteriophage MS2), followed by Fred Sanger's sequencing of the first DNA genome (Phage Φ-X174) in 1977. In the mid-1990s, the first complete genomes across all life domains were sequenced: Haemophilus influenzae (bacteria) in 1995, Saccharomyces cerevisiae (eukaryote) shortly after, and Methanococcus jannaschii (archaeon) in 1996, all by The Institute for Genomic Research.

Advancements in technology have made genome sequencing easier and more affordable, leading to a rapid increase in complete genome sequences. The US National Institutes of Health oversees a comprehensive genomic database. Notable sequenced genomes include those of rice, mice, Arabidopsis thaliana, puffer fish, and E. coli. In December 2013, scientists sequenced the genome of a Neanderthal from a 130,000-year-old toe bone discovered in Siberia.

New sequencing technologies, particularly massive parallel sequencing, have enabled personal genome sequencing as a diagnostic tool, exemplified by Manteia Predictive Medicine. A significant milestone was the 2007 completion of James D. Watson's full genome.

A genome map identifies key landmarks in a genome, providing less detail than a genome sequence. The Human Genome Project aimed to both map and sequence the human genome, with a significant contribution being a detailed genomic map released by Jean Weissenbach's team at the Genoscope in Paris.

Genome composition refers to the characteristics of a haploid genome, including genome size and the ratios of non-repetitive to repetitive DNA. Comparing these compositions helps scientists understand the evolutionary history of genomes.

Genome composition differs significantly between prokaryotes and eukaryotes. Prokaryotes consist mainly of non-repetitive DNA (85–90%), primarily coding DNA, with minimal non-coding regions. In contrast, eukaryotes feature exon-intron organization in protein-coding genes and exhibit high variability in repetitive DNA content, with mammals and plants largely composed of repetitive DNA.

Complex biological entities often carry additional genetic material beyond their chromosomes, including plasmids. In genomic sequencing of pathogens, "genome" refers to all genes and non-coding DNA present in these auxiliary materials.

In eukaryotes, the term "genome" typically refers to chromosomal DNA, excluding the DNA found in organelles like chloroplasts and mitochondria. While mitochondria possess their own "mitochondrial genome," the chloroplast DNA is called the "plastome."

Genome size, representing the total DNA base pairs in a haploid genome, shows a positive correlation with morphological complexity in prokaryotes and lower eukaryotes. However, this correlation diminishes in higher eukaryotes, particularly mollusks, indicating the significant impact of repetitive DNA on genomes.
Researchers are exploring minimal genomes by reducing the number of genes necessary for the survival of both single-celled and multi-celled organisms, utilizing both in vivo and in silico methods.

The proportion of non-repetitive DNA is determined by dividing its length by genome size. Non-repetitive DNA includes protein-coding and RNA-coding genes. In higher eukaryotes, larger genomes do not correspond to more genes, and the proportion of non-repetitive DNA decreases with increasing genome size.

The proportion of non-repetitive DNA varies significantly among species. Prokaryotes like E. coli contain only non-repetitive DNA, while lower eukaryotes such as C. elegans and fruit flies have more non-repetitive than repetitive DNA. In contrast, higher eukaryotes generally exhibit a higher proportion of repetitive DNA. Some plants and amphibians may have non-repetitive DNA comprising less than 20% of their genetic material.
Repetitive DNA proportion is determined by dividing the length of repetitive DNA by the genome size, categorized into tandem repeats and interspersed repeats.

Tandem repeats occur due to replication slippage, unequal crossing-over, and gene conversion. They include satellite DNA and microsatellites, but interspersed repeats make up the largest portion of mammalian genomes.

Interspersed repeats primarily originate from transposable elements (TEs), along with some protein coding gene families and pseudogenes. TEs can integrate into the genome and are considered a key factor in the evolution of higher eukaryotes. They are divided into two types: Class 1 (retrotransposons) and Class 2 (DNA transposons).

Retrotransposons are genetic elements that can be transcribed into RNA and then duplicated elsewhere in the genome. They are categorized into Long Terminal Repeats (LTRs) and Non-Long Terminal Repeats (Non-LTR).

DNA transposons typically move within the genome through a "cut and paste" mechanism, with some instances of duplication. Class 2 transposable elements, which do not utilize RNA intermediates, are common in bacteria and have also been identified in metazoans.

Genomes encompass more than just genes, allowing for the measurement and study of traits such as chromosome number, genome size, gene order, codon usage bias, and GC-content. Researchers analyze these traits to understand the mechanisms behind the diversity of existing genomes.
Duplications significantly influence genome structure, encompassing various scales from short tandem repeats to entire genomes. They are essential for generating genetic diversity and novelty.

Horizontal gene transfer accounts for the high similarity in genome segments between distantly related organisms, particularly among microbes. Additionally, some genetic material has been transferred from chloroplast and mitochondrial genomes to the nuclear chromosomes of eukaryotic cells.

A comprehensive school is a state school in England and Wales that does not select students based on academic performance. Introduced in the 1940s and widespread by 1965, about 90% of British secondary school pupils now attend these schools, which are similar to public high schools in the U.S. and Canada and the German Gesamtschule.

Schwarzenegger began his political career as chairman of the President's Council on Physical Fitness and Sports from 1990 to 1993, appointed by George H. W. Bush, who nicknamed him "Conan the Republican." He later chaired the California Governor's Council on Physical Fitness and Sports under Governor Pete Wilson.

In 1999, Schwarzenegger expressed interest in a political career during an interview but later clarified that he was focused on his entertainment career and downplayed speculation about running for California governor.

Arnold Schwarzenegger announced his run for governor in the 2003 California recall election on The Tonight Show with Jay Leno, gaining immediate global attention despite having no prior political experience. Known primarily for his acting career, especially roles in films like *The Terminator* and *The Running Man*, he was nicknamed the "Governator" and became a central figure in what media dubbed "Total Recall." He largely avoided debates, participating in only one during the campaign.

On October 7, 2003, Governor Gray Davis was recalled from office with 55.4% voting in favor. Arnold Schwarzenegger won the gubernatorial election with 48.6% of the vote, defeating Cruz Bustamante, who received 31%, and others, securing victory by about 1.3 million votes without a runoff. Schwarzenegger became California’s second foreign-born governor, the first since Irish-born John G. Downey in 1862.

After Schwarzenegger's election as governor, Willie Brown threatened a recall effort, while Schwarzenegger remained focused on his agenda to end political gridlock. Drawing from a Saturday Night Live parody of his bodybuilding persona, he dismissed Democratic lawmakers as "girlie men."

Schwarzenegger initially gained support by repealing a vehicle fee hike and blocking driver's licenses for undocumented immigrants, but faced growing opposition from powerful state unions. His political challenges peaked in November 2005 when voters rejected four of his proposed ballot measures. He took responsibility for the losses and committed to seeking broader consensus, later noting the overwhelming financial opposition—over $160 million—from opponents. The U.S. Supreme Court subsequently ruled that public employee unions' use of compulsory funds in the campaign was illegal.

Schwarzenegger defied Republican advisers by appointing Democrat Susan Kennedy as Chief of Staff and shifted toward a more moderate stance, aiming to secure a strong legacy ahead of the upcoming gubernatorial election.

Arnold Schwarzenegger won re-election as California governor in 2006, defeating Democrat Phil Angelides with 56.0% of the vote to Angelides' 38.9%, despite a challenging political climate for Republicans. His shift toward centrist or center-left policies led some, including San Francisco Mayor Gavin Newsom, to suggest he was moving significantly away from traditional Republican positions.
Schwarzenegger was rumored to run for the U.S. Senate in 2010 after his governorship term ended, but the speculation was unfounded.

Wendy Leigh's biography suggests Arnold Schwarzenegger strategically used bodybuilding and film to gain power, driven by a desire to lead rather than follow. Though he claimed politics was never his goal, marrying into the Kennedy-Shriver family exposed him to public service, inspiring him through figures like Eunice and Sargent Shriver. Due to not being a natural-born U.S. citizen, he cannot become president, though pop culture references in *The Simpsons Movie* and *Demolition Man* humorously depict him as president.

Schwarzenegger, a dual Austrian and U.S. citizen, was awarded the 2007 European Voice Campaigner of the Year for his climate action, including the California Global Warming Solutions Act of 2006 and plans for an emissions trading scheme with U.S. states and potentially the EU.

Schwarzenegger remained neutral in the 2008 Republican presidential primary despite close ties to Rudy Giuliani and John McCain. After Giuliani dropped out and endorsed McCain, Schwarzenegger publicly supported McCain at a debate, humorously blaming Giuliani for his delayed decision. His endorsement was seen as beneficial to McCain’s campaign, particularly on environmental and economic issues.
Citizens for Responsibility and Ethics in Washington named Schwarzenegger one of the 11 "worst governors" in 2010 due to ethics issues during his term.
He started his governorship with 89% approval in December 2003 but left office with a record low of 23%, just one percent higher than Gray Davis's rating at the time of his recall.

During Arnold Schwarzenegger's first gubernatorial campaign, multiple women accused him of sexual misconduct in a scandal dubbed "Gropegate." In the final days before the election, the Los Angeles Times reported allegations from several women, with six ultimately sharing their personal accounts.
Multiple women accused Schwarzenegger of inappropriate physical contact, including groping, attempting to remove a woman’s bathing suit, pulling someone onto his lap, and making explicit remarks.

Schwarzenegger acknowledged past misconduct and apologized, while disputing the accuracy of some allegations, including claims from a 1977 Oui magazine interview about sexual orgies and drug use. He was shown smoking marijuana in the 1975 film *Pumping Iron*, and in a 2007 GQ interview, he downplayed marijuana as "a leaf," not a drug, a comment his spokesperson later clarified as a joke.

Anna Richardson, a British TV personality, settled a 2006 libel lawsuit against Arnold Schwarzenegger, his aide Sean Walsh, and publicist Sheryl Main. The suit stemmed from claims that they damaged her reputation by disputing her allegation that Schwarzenegger touched her breast during a press event for *The 6th Day* in London, and by suggesting she encouraged the behavior in a *Los Angeles Times* article. A joint statement confirmed the resolution of the legal dispute.

Arnold Schwarzenegger became a U.S. citizen in 1983 while retaining his Austrian citizenship, which was permitted in his case despite Austria’s general ban on dual nationality. In 2005, Austrian Green Party politician Peter Pilz called for revoking Schwarzenegger’s Austrian citizenship, arguing that his role in allowing the executions of two death row inmates as Governor of California damaged Austria’s reputation, a country opposed to capital punishment since 1968. The request was based on a clause in the Austrian Citizenship Act allowing loss of citizenship if a public servant severely harms Austria’s interests or reputation. Schwarzenegger defended his actions by stating his duty was to uphold the integrity of California’s judicial system.

On September 27, 2006, Schwarzenegger signed landmark legislation establishing the first U.S. cap on greenhouse gas emissions, imposing strict limits on utilities, refineries, and manufacturers. A second bill banned large California corporations from long-term contracts with suppliers failing to meet state emission standards. Together, these measures aimed to cut the state’s emissions to 1990 levels by 2020, complementing an earlier 2005 executive order targeting an 80 percent reduction below 1990 levels by 2050.

In 2006, Schwarzenegger signed an executive order enabling California to join the Northeast's Regional Greenhouse Gas Initiative, a program that limits carbon dioxide emissions by allocating carbon credits to power plants, requiring those that exceed limits to buy additional credits. The initiative began in 2009. To support climate action personally, he converted his Hummers to run on hydrogen and biofuels and installed solar panels at home.
Schwarzenegger opened the 2009 SAE World Congress in Detroit on April 20, 2009, in recognition of his influence on the U.S. motor industry.

In 2013, Arnold Schwarzenegger considered a presidential run despite being barred by the Constitution’s requirement that presidents be natural-born citizens. He reportedly explored lobbying for a constitutional amendment or launching a legal challenge. Legal experts noted the law is clear but uncertain in court enforcement, leaving room for political or judicial interpretation.

Schwarzenegger built a successful business career in the U.S., becoming a millionaire by age 30 through disciplined goal setting and entrepreneurial ventures, achieving financial independence before his Hollywood fame.

In 1968, Schwarzenegger and Franco Columbu launched a successful bricklaying business, which thrived after the 1971 San Fernando earthquake. They used the profits to start a mail-order business selling fitness equipment and instructional tapes.

Schwarzenegger used profits from his mail-order business and bodybuilding career to buy a $10,000 apartment building, marking his first real estate investment, and later invested in several real estate holding companies.

Arnold Schwarzenegger, along with Bruce Willis, Sylvester Stallone, and Demi Moore, was a founding celebrity investor in the Planet Hollywood restaurant chain. He ended his financial involvement in early 2000, citing the venture's lack of expected success and his desire to focus on new global business opportunities and his film career.

Arnold Schwarzenegger has invested in a Columbus, Ohio shopping mall and owns significant stakes in Dimensional Fund Advisors, Arnold's Sports Festival, the film company Oak Productions, Inc., and Fitness Publications, a publishing venture with Simon & Schuster. He credits business mentors including Milton Friedman, Donald Trump, Les Wexner, and Warren Buffett, and cites lessons learned from ventures like Planet Hollywood.
In 1992, Schwarzenegger and his wife opened a restaurant named Schatzi On Main in Santa Monica, with "Schatzi" meaning "little treasure" or "darling" in German. He sold the restaurant in 1998.

Arnold Schwarzenegger's net worth, estimated between $100 million and $800 million depending on sources and time, has grown through investments in stocks, bonds, private companies, and global real estate. After separating from Maria Shriver in 2011, estimates of his wealth increased, though fluctuations in real estate markets have made precise valuations difficult. He invested heavily in assets like a $38 million Gulfstream jet in 1997 and has often downplayed the importance of money, humorously noting that he was just as happy with $48 million as with $50 million, while also acknowledging his substantial earnings as a businessman.

In 1969, Arnold Schwarzenegger began a relationship with Barbara Outland, an English teacher, which lasted until 1974. She described him as charismatic and driven but increasingly self-centered, while he acknowledged their differing desires—she sought a conventional life, whereas he rejected ordinariness. They met shortly after his arrival in the U.S., shared a modest life in Santa Monica, and bonded over events like watching the Apollo Moon landing. Baker later wrote a memoir, *Arnold and Me: In the Shadow of the Austrian Oak*, detailing their passionate yet turbulent relationship, including his infidelity and her mixed feelings about his personality. Despite discrepancies in their recollections, Schwarzenegger contributed a foreword and met with her for the book. She ultimately viewed him as a self-made man shaped by determination and lack of familial support, believing deeply in his love for her.

Arnold Schwarzenegger began a relationship with Sue Moray, a Beverly Hills hairdresser's assistant, after meeting her on Venice Beach in July 1977, maintaining an open relationship. He also started seeing Maria Shriver after meeting her at the Robert F. Kennedy Tennis Tournament the same month, continuing both relationships until Moray ended hers with him in August 1978 upon learning of his commitment to Shriver.

Arnold Schwarzenegger married journalist Maria Shriver, niece of President John F. Kennedy, on April 26, 1986, in Hyannis, Massachusetts, with the ceremony held at St. Francis Xavier Catholic Church. The couple had four children: Katherine (born 1989), Christina (1991), Patrick (1993), and Christopher (1997), all born in Los Angeles. They lived in a large home in Brentwood and owned vacation properties in Sun Valley, Idaho, and Hyannis Port, Massachusetts, while attending St. Monica's Catholic Church. After their separation, Schwarzenegger began dating physical therapist Heather Milligan.

In May 2011, Maria Shriver separated from Arnold Schwarzenegger after 25 years of marriage. Shortly after, it was revealed that Schwarzenegger had fathered a child with their housekeeper, Mildred Baena, over a decade earlier. He admitted the affair to Shriver only after she confronted him with confirmed information about the child.

Maria Baena, a Guatemalan-born housekeeper, worked for Arnold Schwarzenegger’s family for 20 years before retiring in 2011. She gave birth to Schwarzenegger’s son, Joseph, in 1997, around the same time Schwarzenegger’s wife, Maria Shriver, gave birth to their youngest child. Schwarzenegger stated he did not realize he was Joseph’s father until the boy was several years old and began resembling him. He has provided financial support since the beginning, including purchasing a four-bedroom home with a pool for Baena and their son in Bakersfield in 2010. Baena separated from her husband, Rogelio, months after Joseph’s birth and filed for divorce in 2008. Rogelio claims the child’s birth certificate was falsified and intends to sue Schwarzenegger for allegedly conspiring to commit a felony.

Schwarzenegger, represented by attorney Bob Kaufman, is finalizing a divorce settlement with Shriver, retaining the Brentwood home while she bought a nearby residence to facilitate shared custody of their two minor children. After facing criticism for omitting spousal support and legal fee reimbursement in the initial filing—actions he claims were unintentional due to not reading the documents thoroughly—he has since filed amended papers to correct these oversights.

Brigitte Nielsen revealed she had an affair with Arnold Schwarzenegger while he was in a relationship with Maria Shriver, stating it might not have happened if he had been clear about their serious commitment. In 2014, Schwarzenegger expressed regret, saying the mistakes that hurt his family and led to their separation were what he was least proud of.

Arnold Schwarzenegger was born with a bicuspid aortic valve and in 1997 underwent surgery to replace it with a valve made from his own tissue, avoiding a mechanical valve to preserve his ability to exercise. Experts predicted the replacement would degrade within two to eight years, requiring further surgery.

On January 8, 2006, Arnold Schwarzenegger collided with a car while riding his Harley Davidson in Los Angeles, with his son Patrick in the sidecar. The low-speed crash caused a minor lip injury requiring 15 stitches, but no one else was harmed and no citations were issued. Schwarzenegger obtained his motorcycle license later that year on July 3.

Schwarzenegger fractured his right femur in a skiing accident in Sun Valley, Idaho, on December 23, 2006. He had surgery on December 26 to repair the break with cables and screws and was discharged from the hospital on December 30.
Schwarzenegger's private jet made an emergency landing at Van Nuys Airport on June 19, 2009, due to smoke in the cockpit, but no one was injured.

Arnold Schwarzenegger's claimed height of 6'2" (1.88 m) has been widely questioned. Measured at 6'1.5" (1.87 m) during his 1960s bodybuilding career, reports later suggested he appeared shorter. Media outlets like the Daily Mail and Time Out noted this in 1988, and the Chicago Reader raised questions before his gubernatorial run. As Governor, he humorously clashed with Assemblyman Herb Wesson over their heights, including an incident with a measuring tape and a teasing pillow. Some, including Bob Mulholland and Men's Health magazine in 1999, claimed he was as short as 5'10" (1.78 m), alleging he wore lifts in his boots.

Arnold Schwarzenegger's 2012 autobiography *Total Recall* details his life across three main areas: bodybuilding, acting, and his tenure as Governor of California, with one chapter revealing his extramarital affair.

Schwarzenegger was the first civilian to buy a Humvee and played a key role in convincing manufacturer AM General to create a street-legal civilian version, which debuted in 1992; he purchased one of the first two ever sold.

In 2014, he gained media attention for purchasing a rare Bugatti Veyron Grand Sport Vitesse, which was seen in summer 2015 as a silver car with bright aluminum wheels and a dark brown leather interior.

Arnold Schwarzenegger owned large Hummers exempt from U.S. fuel economy rules. During his 2003 gubernatorial recall campaign, he pledged to convert one to hydrogen, spending about $21,000. After winning, he signed an executive order to develop the California Hydrogen Highway Network and secured a federal grant toward its $91 million cost. California received the first Hydrogen Hummer (H2H) in October 2004.

Arnold Schwarzenegger has long supported the Special Olympics, founded by his former mother-in-law Eunice Kennedy Shriver, and served as spokesperson for the 2007 games in Shanghai. Committed to expanding educational access for underserved youth, he founded the Inner City Games Foundation in 1995, which offers cultural and educational programs to over 250,000 children across 400 schools in 15 cities. He also helped establish the After-School All-Stars in Los Angeles in 2002, an organization that promotes health, fitness, and nutrition through after-school programming.

In 2012, Schwarzenegger co-founded the Schwarzenegger Institute for State and Global Policy at the University of Southern California’s Sol Price School of Public Policy, where he serves as chairman. The Institute promotes post-partisanship, aiming to prioritize people over political parties and develop effective solutions to major challenges through collaborative public policy and discourse.

Plymouth is a city on the south coast of Devon, England, located about 37 miles southwest of Exeter and 190 miles west-southwest of London, situated between the rivers Plym and Tamar at Plymouth Sound, which marks the border with Cornwall.

Plymouth's history dates back to the Bronze Age with a settlement at Mount Batten, later used by the Romans. It was eventually overtaken by Sutton (modern-day Plymouth). In 1620, the Pilgrim Fathers sailed from Plymouth to found the second English colony in North America. During the English Civil War, the town was held by Parliamentarians and endured a siege from 1642 to 1646.

Plymouth expanded during the Industrial Revolution as a commercial port, while nearby Devonport served as a key naval shipbuilding centre. In 1914, Plymouth, Devonport, and East Stonehouse merged into a single county borough named Plymouth, which became a city in 1928. Its strategic naval role made it a target during the Plymouth Blitz in World War II. After extensive wartime destruction, the city centre was rebuilt and expanded in 1967 by incorporating Plympton, Plymstock, and other suburbs.

Plymouth, with a population of 261,546 in 2014, is the UK's 30th most populous urban area. Governed by Plymouth City Council and represented by three MPs, its economy has shifted from shipbuilding and maritime activities—such as ferry services to Brittany and Spain—to a service-based model since the 1990s. The city hosts Western Europe’s largest operational naval base, HMNB Devonport, and is home to Plymouth University.

Upper Palaeolithic human remains and Bronze Age to Middle Iron Age artefacts found at Mount Batten indicate early habitation and its role as a major trading port. The settlement 'TAMARI OSTIA,' mentioned in Ptolemy's Geographia, is believed to have been located in the area of modern-day Plymouth.

Plympton, an early trading port upstream on the River Plym, declined when the river silted up in the 11th century, prompting settlers to move to the Barbican area near the river mouth. This new settlement, originally called Sutton (meaning "south town"), became known as Plym Mouth by 1211, referring to the river's mouth. The name Plymouth officially replaced Sutton in 1440 through a royal charter issued by King Henry VI.

During the Hundred Years' War, French forces attacked in 1340, burning a manor but failing to enter Plymouth; Breton raiders later burned the town in 1403. In the late 15th century, a 'castle quadrate' with four round towers—reflected in the city’s coat of arms—was built near The Barbican to protect Sutton Pool, then the base of Plymouth’s fleet. In 1512, Parliament authorized further fortifications, including walls and a chain across Sutton Pool, artillery blockhouses, and defenses on St Nicholas Island, one at Fishers Nose on the Hoe. This site was fortified in 1596 with Drake's Fort, later replaced by the Citadel in the 1660s.

In the 16th century, Plymouth was a key port for wool exports and maritime trade, home to figures like Sir John Hawkins and Sir Francis Drake, who played pivotal roles in England’s naval and colonial ventures. Drake famously delayed confronting the Spanish Armada to finish a game of bowls in 1588. In 1620, the Pilgrim Fathers departed from Plymouth to found Plymouth Colony, the second English settlement in what became the United States.

Plymouth supported the Parliamentarians during the English Civil War and endured a four-year Royalist siege, repelling a final major assault by Sir Richard Grenville at Freedom Fields Park. After Parliament's victory, the monarchy was restored under Charles II in 1660, who imprisoned Parliamentary supporters on Drake's Island. The Royal Citadel was built starting in 1665 with cannons aimed seaward and toward the town, symbolizing royal authority, while Mount Batten tower also originated from this period.

Plymouth declined as a major trading port in the 17th century due to high transport costs and lack of processing capabilities for key imports like sugar and tobacco, playing only a minor role in the Atlantic slave trade in the early 18th century.

HMNB Devonport, the first dockyard in Stoke Damerel, opened in 1690 on the River Tamar’s eastern bank, with additional docks built in 1727, 1762, and 1793. The growing settlement, initially called "Dock" or "Plymouth Dock," became a distinct town separate from Plymouth, with employment rising to 318 men by 1712 and a population of 3,000 by 1733.

Before the late 18th century, Plymouth's main imports were grain, timber, and coal, but wealth primarily came from Plymouth Dock (later Devonport), driven by the dockyard. The Three Towns—Plymouth, Stonehouse, and Devonport—prospered in the late 18th and early 19th centuries with neo-classical developments by architect John Foulston, who designed notable public buildings like the Athenaeum, Theatre Royal, Royal Hotel, and parts of Union Street, most of which no longer exist.

William Cookworthy founded Plymouth Porcelain in 1768 to utilize newly found China Clay deposits, contributing to the city's economy. He also played an indirect role in the development of the Eddystone Lighthouse through his association with engineer John Smeaton.

Plymouth Sound's 1-mile-long breakwater, designed by John Rennie to protect naval movements at Devonport, began construction in 1812 but faced delays due to technical challenges and storm damage, finishing in 1841. In the 1860s, a series of Palmerston forts was built around Devonport to defend the dockyard from all directions.

In the late 19th century, Plymouth imported key goods like maize, wheat, barley, sugar cane, guano, sodium nitrate, and phosphate from the Americas and Europe. Alongside the Devonport dockyard, local industries such as gasworks, railways, tramways, and small chemical plants developed and persisted into the 20th century.

During World War I, Plymouth served as a key entry point for imperial troops and a center for munitions production. While major Royal Navy units relocated to Scapa Flow, Devonport remained vital for escort vessel operations and repairs, and flying boats operated from Mount Batten.

During World War I, Devonport served as the headquarters of Western Approaches Command and a base for Royal Australian Air Force Sunderland flying boats. In World War II, it was a key embarkation point for US troops during D-Day and suffered 59 Luftwaffe bombing raids known as the Plymouth Blitz. The bombings targeted dockyards but devastated much of the city centre, destroying over 3,700 homes and killing more than 1,000 civilians, largely due to Plymouth's strategic importance as a major port. Charles Church, partially destroyed in 1941, remains as a permanent monument to the wartime destruction.

After World War II, Plymouth was redeveloped under Sir Patrick Abercrombie’s 1943 plan, which transformed the war-damaged, overcrowded city into a low-density suburban layout. Between 1951 and 1964, over 20,000 new homes were built using prefabricated systems, replacing slums. The city centre was zoned and rebuilt from scratch, with most pre-war shops demolished. A landmark of this redevelopment was the 1962 modernist Civic Centre, a high-rise complex later granted grade II listed status to prevent demolition despite years of neglect.

After the war, Devonport Dockyard focused on refitting aircraft carriers and later nuclear submarines, while new industrial zones spurred urban growth. The army largely left by 1971, but the city remained home to the Royal Marines' 42 Commando.

Plymouth was first recorded in 1086 as Sudtone, a Saxon settlement meaning "south farm," located at today's Barbican and part of Roborough hundred. It became a town in 1254 and received a parliamentary charter in 1439, making it the first town in England to do so. Plymouth had a mayor from 1439 until 1934. In 1914, the boroughs of Plymouth and Devonport, along with East Stonehouse, merged into a single county borough known collectively as "The Three Towns."

In 1919, Nancy Astor became the first woman to take her seat as a member of parliament in the UK, representing Plymouth Sutton after succeeding her husband. Plymouth gained city status in 1928, appointed its first Lord Mayor in 1935, and expanded its boundaries in 1967 to include Plympton and Plymstock.

Michael Foot, born in Plymouth, was elected Labour MP for Plymouth Devonport in 1945, later served as Secretary of State for Education, helped pass the 1974 Health and Safety at Work Act, and became a prominent leader of the Labour Party.

In 1971, a proposal to abolish county boroughs threatened Plymouth's autonomy by placing it under Devon County Council, prompting a failed campaign for a new Tamarside county. As a result, Plymouth lost its county borough status on 1 April 1974, with key services transferred to Devon. Full powers were restored when Plymouth became a unitary authority on 1 April 1998 following the Banham Commission's recommendations.

Plymouth is represented in the UK Parliament by three constituencies—Plymouth Moor View, Plymouth Sutton and Devonport, and South West Devon—and in the European Parliament as part of South West England. In the 2015 general election, all three constituencies elected Conservative MPs: Johnny Mercer, Gary Streeter, and Oliver Colvile.

Plymouth was granted the title of Lord Mayor by King George V in 1935. The position is elected annually by six councillors, traditionally alternating between the Conservative and Labour parties, with the Lord Mayor selecting the Deputy Lord Mayor; Dr John Mahony, a Conservative, held the role for 2015–16.

3 Elliot Terrace on the Hoe, formerly home to Waldorf and Nancy Astor, serves as the Lord Mayor’s official residence and is used for civic events, guest accommodations, and private hires. The Civic Centre in Armada Way, a listed building since 2007, faces demolition due to high refurbishment costs of £40m, sparking controversy and concerns over potential job losses.

Plymouth is located between the River Plym and River Tamar, both feeding into Plymouth Sound. Since 1967, it has incorporated the former towns of Plympton and Plymstock east of the Plym. The Tamar marks the Devon-Cornwall border and forms the Hamoaze estuary, home to Devonport Dockyard.

The River Plym forms the Cattewater estuary east of Plymouth, while Plymouth Sound is sheltered by the 1814-built breakwater and features Drake's Island, visible from the limestone cliffs of Plymouth Hoe. The city's unitary authority covers 79.84 km², with terrain rising from sea level to 509 feet (155 m) at Roborough.

Plymouth's geology consists of limestone, Devonian slate, granite, and Middle Devonian limestone, with the city mainly built on Upper Devonian slates and shales. The headlands at Plymouth Sound are composed of Lower Devonian slates resistant to sea erosion, contributing to the area's designation as a Site of Special Scientific Interest due to its geological significance.

A band of Middle Devonian limestone extends from Cremyll to Plymstock, visible in many of Plymouth’s buildings and structures. Dartmoor’s granite to the north was mined and shipped through Plymouth, while minerals like tin, copper, and lead were transported down the Tamar. The limestone belt in southern Plymouth was quarried at sites including West Hoe, Cattedown, and Radford.

After World War II, Sir Patrick Abercrombie's 1944 plan reshaped Plymouth with modern east-west boulevards and Armada Way connecting the railway station to Plymouth Hoe, defining the city centre's layout. This structure persisted despite later pedestrianisation and influenced the 2003 'Vision for Plymouth' promoting mixed-use and residential renewal. Suburban expansion from 1946 included prefabs and over 20,000 new homes by 1964, mostly council houses built under a Modernist garden city model. The city now has 28 parks, including Central Park, Victoria Park, and Plymouth Hoe, averaging 45,638 square metres each.

The average annual temperature is about 11°C, with February minimums around 3–4°C and summer highs just over 19°C in July and August. Snow is rare, averaging less than 7 cm annually, though notable exceptions occurred in 2009–10 and December 2010 with up to 8 cm falling. The maritime influence suppresses extreme temperatures, making winters milder and summers cooler than expected for its latitude, allowing exotic plants to thrive.

Rainfall in the region mainly comes from Atlantic depressions, especially active in autumn and winter, and convection. The south-west receives most of its rain during these seasons, with an average annual rainfall of about 980 mm. Wind speeds are highest from November to March and lowest from June to August, with south-westerly winds prevailing.
South West England benefits from the Azores High extending northeast, especially in summer, leading to high sunshine levels, with coastal areas receiving over 1,600 hours annually.

The warmest day averages 26.6°C, peaking at 31.6°C in June 1976. On average, 4.25 days exceed 25.1°C annually. The coldest night typically reaches −4.1°C, dropping to −8.8°C in January 1979, with 18.6 nights recording air frost yearly.

The University of Plymouth, established in 1992 from Polytechnic South West, has 25,895 students and 3,000 staff, with an annual income of £160 million. It offers programs in maritime business, marine engineering, marine biology, Earth and environmental sciences, surf science, shipping, and logistics. In 2000, it partnered with the University of Exeter to create the Peninsula College of Medicine and Dentistry, ranked 8th in the UK for medicine in 2011. Its dental school, founded in 2006, provides free dental care to improve access in the South West.
The University of St Mark & St John, commonly known as Marjon, focuses on teacher training and provides programs both nationally and internationally.

Plymouth is home to two major colleges: City College Plymouth, serving around 26,000 students with programs up to Foundation degrees, and Plymouth College of Art, one of only four independent art and design colleges in the UK, offering courses in media and other fields since its founding 153 years ago.

Plymouth has 71 state primary schools, 13 secondary schools, eight special schools, and three selective grammar schools—Devonport High School for Girls, Devonport High School for Boys, and Plymouth High School for Girls—along with one independent school, Plymouth College.

The city hosted the Royal Naval Engineering College, established in 1880 in Keyham, where students trained for five years before finishing at Greenwich; it closed in 1910. A new college opened in Manadon in 1940, renamed Dockyard Technical College in 1959, and closed in 1994, with training moved to the University of Southampton.

Plymouth hosts several marine research organizations, including the Marine Biological Association (MBA), Plymouth Marine Laboratory, National Marine Aquarium, Sir Alister Hardy Foundation, Plymouth University's Marine Institute, and the Diving Diseases Research Centre, collectively forming the Plymouth Marine Sciences Partnership. The Plymouth Marine Laboratory studies climate change and sustainability, monitoring ocean acidity's impact on marine life and advising the UK government. It also researches algae for biofuels, wastewater treatment, and skincare products in collaboration with the Boots Group, leveraging algae's sun-protective compounds.

Plymouth's population was 256,384 in 2011, up from 240,720 in 2001, with the urban area reaching 260,203. The average household size was 2.3 people. Ethnically, 96.2% were White (92.9% White British), with Chinese being the largest minority at 0.5%. The White Irish group declined by 24% since 2001, while Other Asian and Black African populations grew by 360% and 351%, respectively. Population rose rapidly in the late 19th century but fell over 1.6% between 1931 and 1951.

Plymouth's economy had a gross value added of £5.169 billion in 2013, accounting for 25% of Devon's total. Its GVA per person was £19,943, below the national average of £23,755. The city's unemployment rate was 7.0% in 2014, exceeding both the South West and Great Britain averages by 2.0 and 0.8 percentage points, respectively.

Plymouth had higher poverty and deprivation levels than the national average in 2014, with 26.2% of its population in the poorest 20.4% nationally, and recorded the lowest life expectancy in the South West at 78.3 years for men and 82.1 for women.

Plymouth's economy has historically been maritime-focused, especially in defence, employing over 12,000 people with 7,500 in the armed forces. The city is home to the Plymouth Gin Distillery, which has produced gin since 1793 and gained global distribution through the Royal Navy, becoming the most widely exported gin by the 1930s with a protected origin status. Since the 1980s, defence employment has declined significantly, and the public sector now dominates, particularly in administration, health, education, medicine, and engineering.

Devonport Dockyard, the UK's sole naval base for refitting nuclear submarines, contributes an estimated 10% to Plymouth's economy. The city hosts the largest concentration of marine and maritime businesses in the southwest, with 270 firms in the sector. Major employers include the university, with nearly 3,000 staff, and Tamar Science Park, which supports 500 jobs across 50 companies. Plymouth is also home to headquarters of several firms, such as Hemsley Fraser.

Plymouth's city centre features a post-war, largely pedestrianised shopping area, including the grade II listed Pannier Market, completed in 1959 and named for its "basket market" meaning. The city ranks among the top five in the South West and 29th nationally for retail space, and was an early adopter of the Business Improvement District scheme. The Tinside Pool, located at the base of the Hoe, is a grade II listed lido restored to its 1930s appearance in 1998 with a £3.4 million investment.

Plymouth Council, supported by the Plymouth Chamber of Commerce and architect David Mackay, is leading an urban redevelopment initiative called "Vision for Plymouth," which includes constructing shopping centres, a cruise terminal, a boulevard, and aiming to increase the city's population to 300,000 through the development of 33,000 new homes.

In 2004, the old Drake Circus shopping centre and Charles Cross car park were demolished and replaced by a new shopping centre, which opened in October 2006 and faced early criticism for being outdated. Meanwhile, the Theatre Royal’s TR2 education and production centre in Cattedown was shortlisted for the 2003 RIBA Stirling Prize.

Plymouth plans to relocate its City Council headquarters to the site of the demolished Bretonside bus station, with the civic centre land to be sold. Proposals also include tearing down Plymouth Pavilions to create a canal boulevard connecting Millbay to the city centre, as part of broader regeneration efforts at Millbay involving residential, retail, office, and ferry port developments.

The A38, known as 'The Parkway' in Plymouth, runs east-west across the city's northern edge, separating urban and suburban areas. It links Plymouth to the M5 near Exeter to the east and connects Cornwall and Devon via the Tamar Bridge to the west. Regular bus services are operated by Plymouth Citybus, First South West, and Target Travel, with three Park and ride sites at Milehouse, Coypool (Plympton), and George Junction (Plymouth City Airport), all run by First South West.

The issue of reduced low frequency bass in third generation iPod models has been observed in various audio testing scenarios. A key contributor to this phenomenon is the use of undersize DC blocking capacitive components, typically found in consumer-grade headphones, in conjunction with their low impedance characteristics. Together, these factors form an inherent high pass filter that attenuate low-end frequencies, leading to a diminished bass experience. 

Similar capacitor designs were also employed in fourth generation Ipod models. However, using higher impedance headphones tends to mitigate this issue, while driving loads with high impedance (such as line level signals) completely mask the reduced output effect. In contrast, first generation ipod shuffle models employ a different output circuitry, featuring dual transistor stages, resulting in no noticeable low bass reduction across various loads.

For iPod models released before 2010, equaliser (equalizer) settings could distort bass sounds on various songs, particularly those with demanding bass lines. Distortion occurred when equalizers, such settings as RnB, rock, acoustic, bass booster, amplified digital sound levels beyond software limits, resulting in clipping on low-frequency instruments. The distortion was not exclusive to demanding songs but also occurred on less demanding tracks.

Users can also rate songs stored on their iPod, with these ratings being synchronously transferred to and from the associated iTunes music collection. When an individual sets their connected iPod to operate in manual sync mode, rather than automatic, they may access and play music from a secondary computing system. However, any new additions or modifications made to their music collections on this secondary system will revert upon reconnecting the iPod for synchronization with its primary host and associated library of music. Conversely, if a manual or automatic synchronization is desired with an alternate computing setup, doing so will result in the complete replacement of an existing iPod library with that of its new host system's music repository.

Portuguese is the official language of Portugal. It is a Romance language that originated in the region comprising present-day Galicia and northern Portugal, evolving from Galician-Portuguese, which served as the common language of both Galician and Portuguese peoples until Portugal's independence. Notably, in northern Portugal, many cultural similarities with Galicia persist. Galicia holds consultative observer status in the Community of Portuguese Language Countries. According to Ethnologue, Portuguese and Spanish share a lexical similarity of 89%, allowing educated speakers of each language to communicate with relative ease.

The Portuguese language evolved from the Latin spoken by Romanized pre-Roman peoples of the Iberian Peninsula approximately two millennia ago, including the Celts, Tartessians, Lusitanians, and Iberians.
