During the 15th and 16th centuries, Portuguese spread globally as Portugal established a colonial and commercial empire from 1415 to 1999. Today, Portuguese is spoken natively on five continents, with Brazil having the largest number of native speakers—approximately 200 million as of 2012.

The adult literacy rate in Portugal is 99 percent, with primary school enrollment rates approaching 100 percent. In the OECD's Programme for International Student Assessment (PISA) 2009, the average 15-year-old Portuguese student scored 489 points in reading, mathematics, and science—slightly below the OECD average of 493—placing Portugal at a level comparable to students from the United States, Sweden, Germany, Ireland, France, Denmark, the United Kingdom, Hungary, and Taipei. More than 35 percent of college-age citizens (aged 20) are enrolled in higher education institutions, compared to 50 percent in the United States and 35 percent across OECD nations. Portugal is both a destination and a leading source of international students. In 2005, the total number of higher education students, including domestic and international, reached 380,937.

The Bologna Process has been implemented in Portuguese universities and polytechnic institutes since 2006. Admission to state-run higher education institutions is competitive, with a *numerus clausus* system enforced via a national student admissions database. In addition to regular admissions, institutions may offer supplementary places through extraordinary admission processes. These may apply to athletes, mature applicants (aged 23 or over), international students, students from Lusophone countries, holders of degrees from other institutions, transfer students, former students seeking readmission, and applicants requesting a course change. Such admissions are governed by specific standards and regulations established by each institution or department.

While most student expenses are publicly funded, rising tuition fees and the enrollment of non-traditional students—such as working professionals, businesspeople, parents, and retirees, often attending part-time or evening classes—have led many departments to derive substantial revenue from additional enrollments. This contributes to the institution's gross tuition income without necessarily compromising educational quality, as measured by metrics such as student-teacher ratios, computer access, and classroom sizes.

Mortality from cardiovascular diseases (CVD) exceeds the eurozone average; however, its two principal components, ischaemic heart disease and cerebrovascular disease, exhibit inverse trends compared to the Eur-A region. Cerebrovascular disease is the leading cause of death in Portugal, accounting for 17% of fatalities. The cancer mortality rate in Portugal is 12% lower than the Eur-A average, but it is declining less rapidly. Cancer incidence is elevated among children and women under 44 years of age. While lung cancer (increasing slowly among women) and breast cancer (decreasing rapidly) are less common, cervical and prostate cancers occur more frequently. Portugal reports the highest diabetes mortality rate in the Eur-A, with a marked rise since the 1980s.

Individuals are generally aware of their health status, the positive and negative impacts of their behavior on health, and their utilization of healthcare services. However, personal perceptions of health may diverge from administrative and clinical data regarding illness prevalence in populations. Consequently, household-level survey data based on self-reports serve to complement other health status and service-use indicators. In Portugal, only one-third of adults rated their health as good or very good (Kasmel et al., 2004), the lowest proportion among reporting Eur-A countries, reflecting the nation's comparatively unfavorable mortality and selected morbidity conditions.

Kanye Omari West (/ˈkɑːnjeɪ/; born June 8, 1977) is an American rapper, record producer, fashion designer, and entrepreneur. He is widely regarded as one of the most influential musicians of the 21st century, known for both his acclaimed artistic output and his controversial public persona.

Kanye West was raised in Chicago and briefly attended art school before gaining recognition as a producer for Roc-A-Fella Records in the early 2000s, where he produced hit singles for artists including Jay-Z and Alicia Keys. Intent on pursuing a solo career as a rapper, he released his debut album *The College Dropout* in 2004 to widespread commercial and critical success, and founded the record label GOOD Music. West subsequently explored a range of musical styles on later albums, such as the baroque-influenced *Late Registration* (2005), the arena-inspired *Graduation* (2007), and the stark, polarizing *808s & Heartbreak* (2008). In 2010, he released his critically acclaimed fifth album, the maximalist *My Beautiful Dark Twisted Fantasy*, and the following year collaborated with Jay-Z on the joint album *Watch the Throne* (2011). West's abrasive sixth album, *Yeezus*, was released in 2013 to further critical praise. After a series of recording delays and work on non-musical projects, his seventh album, *The Life of Pablo*, was released in 2016.

Kanye West is among the best-selling music artists in history, with over 32 million albums and 100 million digital downloads sold globally. He has received 21 Grammy Awards, ranking him as one of the most awarded artists ever and the most Grammy-decorated artist of his generation. Three of his albums appear on Rolling Stone's 2012 list of the "500 Greatest Albums of All Time," while two of his albums were placed first and eighth, respectively, on Pitchfork's The 100 Best Albums of 2010–2014. West has also been featured on several Forbes annual lists. Time magazine included him in its list of the 100 most influential people in the world in both 2005 and 2015.

At age 10, West relocated to Nanjing, China, with his mother, who was teaching at Nanjing University through an exchange program. His mother noted that West was the sole foreign student in his class but adapted readily and rapidly acquired Mandarin, though he later lost fluency. Reflecting on his high school academic performance, West stated, "I got A's and B's. And I'm not even frontin'."

West displayed an early affinity for the arts, beginning to write poetry at the age of five. His mother noted that his interest in drawing and music became apparent during the third grade. Raised in an urban environment,[which?] West immersed himself in the local hip hop scene. He started rapping in the third grade and began composing music by the seventh grade, later selling his compositions to other artists. At thirteen, West wrote a rap song titled "Green Eggs and Ham" and convinced his mother to pay for studio time at a rate of $25 per hour. The studio was a rudimentary basement setup with a microphone suspended from the ceiling by a wire clothes hanger. Although his mother had reservations, she supported his pursuits. West later connected with producer and DJ No I.D., forming a close friendship. No I.D. became West's mentor, teaching him sampling and beat programming after West acquired his first sampler at age 15.

After graduating from high school, West was awarded a scholarship to attend the American Academy of Art in Chicago in 1997, where he initially studied painting. He soon transferred to Chicago State University to pursue English. However, West concluded that his academic commitments were hindering his music career, and at age 20, he left college to focus on music. His decision disappointed his mother, a professor at the university, who later remarked, "It was drummed into my head that college is the ticket to a good life... but some career goals don't require college. For Kanye to make an album called *College Dropout* it was more about having the guts to embrace who you are, rather than following the path society has carved out for you."

Kanye West began his music production career in the mid‑1990s, creating beats mainly for emerging local artists. He developed a distinctive style that often used sped‑up vocal samples from classic soul records. His first official production credits came at age nineteen, when he produced eight tracks on *Down to Earth* (1996), the debut album of Chicago rapper Grav. For a period, West worked as a ghost producer for Deric "D‑Dot" Angelettie. Due to his association with D‑Dot, West was unable to release a solo album at the time; instead, he co‑founded and became a member and producer of the Go‑Getters, a Chicago rap group formed in the late 1990s. The group consisted of West, GLC, Timmy G, Really Doe, and Arrowstar, and was managed by John "Monopoly" Johnson, Don Crowley, and Happy Lewis under the management firm Hustle Period. After participating in promotional photo shoots and radio appearances, the Go‑Getters released their sole studio album, *World Record Holders*, in 1999. The album featured additional Chicago rappers such as Rhymefest, Mikkey Halsted, Miss Criss, and Shayla G. Production was handled by West, Arrowstar, Boogz, and Brian "All Day" Miller.

During the late 1990s, West worked extensively as a producer for several prominent artists and groups. He produced the third track on Foxy Brown's second studio album, *Chyna Doll*, which became the first hip-hop album by a female rapper to debut at number one on the U.S. Billboard 200 chart in its first week of release. For Harlem World's sole album, *The Movement*, West produced three tracks in collaboration with Jermaine Dupri and the production duo Trackmasters; these songs featured appearances by Nas, Drag-On, and R&B singer Carl Thomas. West also co-produced the ninth track on *World Party*—the final Goodie Mob album to include all four original members before their disbandment—with his manager Deric "D-Dot" Angelettie. Near the end of the decade, West produced six songs for *Tell 'Em Why U Madd*, an album released by Angelettie under the alias The Madd Rapper, a fictional character originally created for a skit on The Notorious B.I.G.'s posthumous album *Life After Death*. These tracks included guest verses from rappers such as Ma$e, Raekwon, and Eminem.

West's breakthrough occurred in 2000 when he began producing for artists on Roc-A-Fella Records. He gained significant recognition for his work on Jay-Z's influential 2001 album *The Blueprint*, which is widely credited with revitalizing the rapper's career. Frequently ranked among the greatest hip-hop albums, *The Blueprint*'s critical and commercial success generated considerable interest in West as a producer. As an in-house producer for Roc-A-Fella, he produced tracks for other label artists such as Beanie Sigel, Freeway, and Cam'ron, and also created hit songs for Ludacris, Alicia Keys, and Janet Jackson.

Despite his success as a producer, West's primary ambition was to become a rapper. Although he had honed his rapping skills long before his production career, he faced significant challenges in gaining acceptance as a rapper and securing a record deal. Multiple record labels dismissed him due to his divergence from the gangsta persona that dominated mainstream hip hop at the time. Following a series of negotiations with Capitol Records, West was ultimately denied an artist contract.

According to Capitol Records A&R executive Joe Weinberger, Kanye West nearly secured a deal with the label, but another executive persuaded Capitol's president to reject it. Eager to prevent West from signing with a competing label, then-Roc-A-Fella Records co-president Damon Dash reluctantly agreed to bring West onto the roster. Jay-Z later acknowledged that Roc-A-Fella was initially hesitant to promote West as a rapper, noting that many within the label primarily viewed him as a producer and that his background differed from those of his labelmates.

West's breakthrough occurred on October 23, 2002, when, after working late at a California recording studio, he fell asleep while driving home and was involved in a near-fatal car accident. The crash shattered his jaw, requiring reconstructive surgery that wired it shut. Inspired by the experience, West recorded the song "Through the Wire" just two weeks after being hospitalized, performing with his jaw still wired. The track detailed his ordeal and helped establish the groundwork for his debut album; West later stated, "all the better artists have expressed what they were going through," and described the album as "my medicine," noting that the creative process distracted him from his pain. "Through the Wire" first appeared on West's December 2002 mixtape *Get Well Soon...*. Concurrently, he announced he was working on an album titled *The College Dropout*, which he said would explore the theme of making independent decisions rather than conforming to societal expectations.

West produced much of his debut album in brief sessions, often completing tracks in under fifteen minutes while transporting old disks and demos in a Louis Vuitton backpack between his home and the studio. He recorded the remainder of the album in Los Angeles during his recovery from a car accident. After completion, the album was leaked months ahead of its scheduled release. West used the leak as an opportunity to reassess the work, leading to extensive remixing, remastering, and revisions before the official release. Several tracks originally intended for the album, such as "Keep the Receipt" featuring Ol' Dirty Bastard and "The Good, the Bad, and the Ugly" featuring Consequence, were ultimately removed. West meticulously refined the production, incorporating string arrangements, gospel choirs, enhanced drum programming, and new verses. His perfectionism resulted in three delays to the album's release, which was initially planned for August 2003.

*The College Dropout* was released by Roc-A-Fella Records in February 2004, debuting at number two on the Billboard 200. Its lead single, "Through the Wire", peaked at number fifteen on the Billboard Hot 100 and remained on the chart for five weeks. The follow-up single, "Slow Jamz", featuring Twista and Jamie Foxx, achieved greater commercial success, becoming the first number-one hit for all three artists. Upon its release, the album received widespread critical acclaim, was named the year's best album by two major music publications, and has since been frequently cited as one of the most significant hip-hop albums and artistic debuts. Its fourth single, "Jesus Walks", which addresses themes of faith and Christianity, expanded West's audience; despite predictions from industry executives that its overtly religious content would hinder radio play, the song reached the top 20 of the Billboard Hot 100. *The College Dropout* was eventually certified triple platinum in the United States and earned West ten Grammy Award nominations, winning for Best Rap Album. Around this time, West founded the record label and management company GOOD Music, which later signed artists and producers such as John Legend and No I.D. A hallmark of West's production on the album was his use of sped-up vocal samples from soul records. However, following the album's success, the technique became widely imitated. Citing both market saturation and a personal desire to move beyond the style, West began pursuing new sonic directions.

Beginning his second album that fall, West invested two million dollars and spent over a year crafting the project. He drew significant inspiration from *Roseland NYC Live*, a 1998 live album by English trip hop group Portishead, which was recorded with the New York Philharmonic Orchestra. Early in his career, the album had motivated West to incorporate string arrangements into his hip-hop productions. While financial constraints limited the use of live instruments on his debut, his subsequent commercial success allowed him to hire a string orchestra for *Late Registration*. West collaborated with American film score composer Jon Brion, who served as co-executive producer on several tracks. Although Brion had no prior experience in hip-hop, he and West found they could work productively together after discovering that neither confined his musical knowledge or vision to a single genre. By the end of 2005, *Late Registration* had sold over 2.3 million units in the United States. Industry observers regarded it as the only successful major album release of the fall season, which had been affected by steadily declining CD sales.

While West had faced controversy a year earlier after storming out of the 2004 American Music Awards upon losing the Best New Artist award, his first major controversy occurred shortly after the release of *Late Registration*, during a benefit concert for Hurricane Katrina victims. In September 2005, NBC televised *A Concert for Hurricane Relief*, featuring West as a speaker. While presenting alongside actor Mike Myers, West deviated from the prepared script. After Myers continued reading as planned, West, when speaking again, stated, "George Bush doesn't care about black people." The remark reached a wide audience across the United States, eliciting mixed reactions; President George W. Bush later described it as one of the most "disgusting moments" of his presidency. West generated further controversy in January 2006 by appearing on the cover of *Rolling Stone* wearing a crown of thorns.

Fresh from touring with U2 on their Vertigo Tour the previous year, Kanye West sought to create anthemic rap songs suited to large arenas. He incorporated synthesizers into his hip-hop production, adopted slower tempos, and experimented with electronic music influenced by 1980s sounds. Beyond U2, West drew inspiration from arena rock acts such as the Rolling Stones and Led Zeppelin in melody and chord progression. Aiming for a more introspective and personal lyrical approach on his third studio album—part of a planned tetralogy with educational themes—he also studied folk and country singer-songwriters like Bob Dylan and Johnny Cash to refine his wordplay and storytelling.

West's third studio album, *Graduation*, drew significant attention when its release date set up a sales competition against rapper 50 Cent's album *Curtis*. Upon their release in September 2007, *Graduation* outsold *Curtis* by a substantial margin, debuting at number one on the U.S. Billboard 200 chart with 957,000 copies sold in its first week. The album continued West's streak of critical and commercial success, and its lead single, "Stronger", became his third number-one hit. The track, which samples French house duo Daft Punk, is credited with encouraging hip-hop artists to incorporate house and electronica elements into their music, as well as contributing to the revival of disco and electro-infused music in the late 2000s. Ben Detrick of *XXL* described the sales competition between *Curtis* and *Graduation* as a pivotal moment that altered hip-hop's direction and opened opportunities for rappers who diverged from the hardcore-gangster mold, stating, "If there was ever a watershed moment to indicate hip-hop's changing direction, it may have come when 50 Cent competed with Kanye in 2007 to see whose album would claim superior sales."

*808s & Heartbreak* was released by Island Def Jam in November 2008, timed to capitalize on the Thanksgiving weekend. The album makes extensive use of the Roland TR-808 drum machine and explores themes of love, loneliness, and heartache. Critical reception was generally positive, though somewhat more mixed than that of West's earlier work. Despite this, the record's singles achieved strong chart success: the lead single "Love Lockdown" debuted at number three on the Billboard Hot 100, earning the "Hot Shot Debut" designation, while the follow-up "Heartless" debuted at number four, becoming West's second consecutive "Hot Shot Debut." Although initially met with some skepticism, *808s & Heartbreak* proved influential in hip-hop, encouraging other artists to pursue greater creative risks in their production.

In 2012, *Rolling Stone* journalist Matthew Trammell argued that the album was ahead of its time, stating, "Now that popular music has finally caught up to it, *808s & Heartbreak* has revealed itself to be Kanye’s most vulnerable work, and perhaps his most brilliant."

Following the widely publicized incident, West took a brief hiatus from music and focused on fashion before retreating to Hawaii for several months to write and record his next album. He brought in his preferred producers and artists to collaborate on and inspire the recordings, keeping engineers working around the clock and sleeping only intermittently. Noah Callahan-Bever, a Complex writer who attended the sessions, characterized the "communal" environment as follows: "With the right songs and the right album, he can overcome any and all controversy, and we are here to contribute, challenge, and inspire." The project featured contributions from a range of artists, including longtime associates Jay-Z, Kid Cudi, and Pusha T, as well as unconventional collaborations such as with Bon Iver's Justin Vernon.

*My Beautiful Dark Twisted Fantasy*, the fifth studio album by American rapper and producer Kanye West, was released in November 2010 to widespread critical acclaim. Many reviewers considered it his finest work and a definitive comeback following a period of public controversy. Departing from the minimalist style of his previous album, *808s & Heartbreak* (2008), *My Beautiful Dark Twisted Fantasy* embraces a maximalist approach, incorporating lush orchestration and dense production while exploring themes of celebrity, excess, and personal turmoil. The album spawned several successful singles, including the international hit "All of the Lights" and the Billboard-charting songs "Power", "Monster", and "Runaway". The latter was accompanied by a 35-minute short film of the same name. Concurrent with the album's promotion, West launched the GOOD Fridays initiative through his website, offering free downloads of previously unreleased songs each Friday from August 20 to December 17, 2010; several of these tracks were later included on the album. *My Beautiful Dark Twisted Fantasy* was certified platinum in the United States. Its omission from the Album of the Year category at the 54th Grammy Awards was described by multiple media outlets as a snub.

Following a headlining performance at Coachella 2011, which *The Hollywood Reporter* called "one of the greatest hip-hop sets of all time," West released the collaborative album *Watch the Throne* with Jay-Z. The album employed a sales strategy that made it available digitally weeks before its physical release, helping it become one of the few major-label albums in the internet era to avoid being leaked prior to its official issue. "Niggas in Paris" emerged as the record's highest-charting single, reaching number five on the Billboard Hot 100. In 2012, West released the compilation album *Cruel Summer*, featuring tracks by artists from his record label GOOD Music. *Cruel Summer* produced four singles, two of which charted within the top twenty of the Hot 100: "Mercy" and "Clique." West also directed a film of the same name, which premiered at the 2012 Cannes Film Festival in a custom pyramid-shaped screening pavilion equipped with seven screens.

Recording sessions for West's sixth solo studio album began in early 2013, taking place in the living room of his personal loft at a Paris hotel. Aiming to subvert commercial expectations, West reunited with close collaborators and experimented with incorporating elements of Chicago drill, dancehall, acid house, and industrial music. Drawing primary inspiration from architecture, West's perfectionism led him to enlist producer Rick Rubin just fifteen days before the album's deadline to simplify its sound, adopting a more minimalist aesthetic. Early promotion for the album included global video projections of its music and televised live performances. Titled *Yeezus*, the album was released on June 18, 2013, to widespread critical acclaim. It became West's sixth consecutive number-one debut on the Billboard 200, though it also marked his lowest first-week sales for a solo project. In July 2013, Def Jam released "Black Skinhead" to radio as the album's lead single. On September 6, 2013, West announced his first solo tour in five years to support *Yeezus*, with American rapper Kendrick Lamar joining as the supporting act.

In June 2013, Kanye West and television personality Kim Kardashian announced the birth of their first child, North West. The couple announced their engagement in October 2013, attracting widespread media attention. That November, West stated he had begun work on his next studio album, aiming for a mid-2014 release with production by Rick Rubin and Q-Tip. In December 2013, Adidas announced an official apparel collaboration with West, scheduled to premiere the following year. West and Kardashian married in a private ceremony in Florence, Italy, in May 2014, with numerous artists and celebrities in attendance.

On December 31, 2014, West released the single "Only One", featuring Paul McCartney. In January 2015, he released "FourFiveSeconds", a collaboration with Rihanna and McCartney. West also appeared on the *Saturday Night Live* 40th Anniversary Special, premiering a new song titled "Wolves" featuring Sia and fellow Chicago rapper Vic Mensa. In February 2015, he launched his Adidas clothing collaboration, Yeezy Season 1, which received generally positive reviews and included the Yeezy Boost sneakers. The single "All Day", featuring Theophilus London, Allan Kingdom, and Paul McCartney, was released in March 2015. West performed the song at the 2015 BRIT Awards alongside several US rappers and UK grime MCs, including Skepta, Wiley, Novelist, Fekky, Krept & Konan, Stormzy, Allan Kingdom, Theophilus London, and Vic Mensa. He premiered the second iteration of his clothing line, Yeezy Season 2, at New York Fashion Week in September 2015.

Kanye West initially announced a new album titled *So Help Me God* for a planned 2014 release. In March 2015, he revealed that the album would instead be tentatively named *SWISH*. Later that month, the School of the Art Institute of Chicago awarded West an honorary doctorate in recognition of his contributions to music, fashion, and popular culture, granting him the honorary title of Doctor of Fine Arts. The following month, West headlined the Glastonbury Festival in the United Kingdom, despite a petition signed by nearly 135,000 people opposing his appearance. During the performance, he told the audience, "You are now watching the greatest living rock star on the planet." Media coverage of his set was sharply divided, including on social media platforms such as Twitter. *NME* noted that booking West had been controversial and that the show "appeared to polarise both Glastonbury goers and those who tuned in to watch on their TVs," while also observing that "he's letting his music speak for and prove itself." *The Guardian* described his performance as having "a potent ferocity," but added that there were "gaps and stutters," and that he cut "a strangely lone figure in front of the vast crowd."

In December 2015, Kanye West released the song "Facts." He announced via Twitter in January 2016 that his album, then titled *SWISH*, would be released on February 11, following the release of the new single "Real Friends" and a preview of "No More Parties in L.A." featuring Kendrick Lamar. This period also revived West's GOOD Fridays initiative, in which he released new singles weekly. On January 26, 2016, West revealed he had renamed the album from *SWISH* to *Waves* and announced the premiere of his Yeezy Season 3 clothing line at Madison Square Garden.

In early 2016, several weeks before the album's scheduled release, West became involved in a brief public dispute on Twitter with rapper Wiz Khalifa. The altercation drew in their mutual ex-partner, Amber Rose, who objected to West's mention of her and Khalifa's child. The feud included allegations by Rose regarding her past relationship with West and attracted considerable media coverage. By February 2, 2016, West and Khalifa had reconciled.

Shortly before the album's release, West changed the title again, this time to *The Life of Pablo*. On February 11, he premiered the album at Madison Square Garden during the Yeezy Season 3 presentation. After the preview, West stated he would revise the tracklist further and delayed the release to complete recording on the track "Waves" at the request of co-writer Chance the Rapper. The album was released exclusively on Tidal on February 14, 2016, following a performance on *Saturday Night Live*.

Kanye West's musical career has been characterized by frequent stylistic shifts, as he has explored a diverse range of musical approaches and genres. He has cited A Tribe Called Quest, Stevie Wonder, Michael Jackson, George Michael, LL Cool J, Phil Collins, and Madonna as early influences. West has described David Bowie as one of his "most important inspirations" and identified producer Puff Daddy as the "most important cultural figure in my life." Early in his career, West pioneered a production style known as "chipmunk soul," which employed pitched-up vocal samples—often from soul and R&B songs—combined with his own drum programming and instrumentation. His first major release featuring this soul-sampling approach was "This Can't Be Life," a track from Jay-Z’s album *The Dynasty: Roc La Familia*. West has acknowledged Wu-Tang Clan producer RZA as an influence on his style and named Wu-Tang members Ghostface Killah and Ol' Dirty Bastard as inspirations. RZA responded positively to the comparisons, telling *Rolling Stone*, "All good. I got super respect for Kanye [...] [he] is going to inspire people to be like him." West further refined his sound on his 2004 debut album, *The College Dropout*. After an unfinished version was leaked, he meticulously reworked the production, incorporating string arrangements, gospel choirs, and enhanced drum programming.

With his third album, *Graduation* (2007), West shifted away from the sonic palette of his earlier work toward a more atmospheric, rock-influenced, and electronic-oriented sound. This evolution was informed by his engagement with diverse genres, including European Britpop and Euro-disco, American alternative and indie rock, and his Chicago house roots. To achieve this, West reduced the live instrumentation prominent on his previous album, instead employing dense, gothic synthesizers, distorted synth chords, rave stabs, house beats, electro-disco rhythms, and a variety of modulated electronic textures and digital audio effects. He also drew melodic and harmonic inspiration from arena rock acts such as The Rolling Stones, U2, and Led Zeppelin.

West's fourth studio album, *808s & Heartbreak* (2008), represented a significant departure from his earlier work, moving away from conventional rap and hip hop toward a stark electropop style. The album's production relied heavily on digital synthesis, the Roland TR-808 drum machine, and prominent use of Auto-Tune on vocals. Inspired by artists such as Gary Numan, TJ Swan, and Boy George, West adopted a minimalist yet functional approach in the studio, experimenting with Auto-Tune to create an electronic aesthetic and manipulating the 808's pitch to achieve distorted, synthetic textures. He also contrasted mechanical sounds with traditional elements like taiko drums and monastic choirs. Musically, the album is characterized by austere production, dense percussion, extended string arrangements, droning synthesizers, and somber piano lines, drawing comparisons to 1980s post-punk and new wave. West later expressed a personal affinity for the British post-punk band Joy Division. In a 2012 article, *Rolling Stone* critic Matthew Trammell argued that the album was ahead of its time, noting that "now that popular music has finally caught up to it, *808s & Heartbreak* has revealed itself to be Kanye’s most vulnerable work, and perhaps his most brilliant."

*My Beautiful Dark Twisted Fantasy*, the fifth studio album by Kanye West, has been recognized by critics for its maximalist aesthetic and its synthesis of stylistic elements from West's earlier albums. According to Simon Vozick-Levinson of *Entertainment Weekly*, these recurring elements include "the luxurious soul of 2004's *The College Dropout*, the symphonic pomp of *Late Registration*, the gloss of 2007's *Graduation*, and the emotionally exhausted electro of 2008's *808s & Heartbreak*." Sean Fennessey of *The Village Voice* observed that on his previous albums, West "absorb[ed] the gifts of his handpicked collaborators, and occasionally elevat[ed] them," citing Jon Brion's contributions to *Late Registration*, DJ Toomp's work on *Graduation*, and Kid Cudi's role on *808s & Heartbreak*.

Describing his sixth studio album *Yeezus* (2013) as "a protest to music," Kanye West adopted an abrasive style that drew from industrial music, acid house, dancehall, punk, electro, and Chicago drill. Influenced by the minimalist architecture of Le Corbusier and largely electronic in composition, the album utilizes distorted drum machines and synthesizers that evoke malfunctioning equipment, alongside low‑resolution samplers that impart a pixelated digital quality to otherwise analog sounds. The production incorporates audio glitches reminiscent of CD skips or corrupted MP3 files, while Auto‑Tuned vocals are modulated to near‑indecipherable extremes. The album continues West's eclectic approach to sampling, featuring excerpts from Nina Simone's "Strange Fruit," an obscure Hindi recording on "I Am a God," and a sample from the 1970s Hungarian rock group Omega on "New Slaves." Additionally, "On Sight" interpolates a melody from "Sermon (He'll Give Us What We Really Need)" by the Holy Name of Mary Choral Family. *Rolling Stone* characterized the album as a "brilliant, obsessive‑compulsive career auto‑correct."

In September 2005, West announced plans to release his Pastelle Clothing line in spring 2006, stating, "Now that I have a Grammy under my belt and Late Registration is finished, I am ready to launch my clothing line next spring." Development continued over the next four years, with West previewing several items, but the line was ultimately canceled in 2009. That same year, West collaborated with Nike to launch the Air Yeezy sneaker; a second version followed in 2012. In January 2009, he debuted his first shoe line for Louis Vuitton during Paris Fashion Week, which was released in summer 2009. West has also designed footwear for Bape and the Italian brand Giuseppe Zanotti.

On December 3, 2013, Adidas officially announced a collaboration agreement with Kanye West. Following months of speculation, West confirmed the launch of the Adidas Yeezy Boost line via a Twitter post that directed followers to the domain yeezy.supply. In 2015, West introduced his Yeezy Season apparel collection, debuting Season 1 in partnership with Adidas early that year. The Adidas Yeezy Boost release and the broader Adidas collaboration were presented in New York City on February 12, 2015, with a live stream broadcast to 50 cinemas across 13 countries. An initial release of 9,000 pairs was made available exclusively in New York City through the Adidas mobile application, selling out within ten minutes. A worldwide release followed on February 28, 2015, limited to select boutique retailers and Adidas stores in the United Kingdom. Later that year, West presented Yeezy Season 2 during New York Fashion Week. On February 11, 2016, he premiered Yeezy Season 3 at Madison Square Garden, alongside a preview of his album *The Life of Pablo*.

In August 2008, West announced plans to open 10 Fatburger restaurants in the Chicago area, with the first scheduled to open in Orland Park in September 2008. A second location opened in January 2009, while a third was under consideration but never finalized. Through his company, KW Foods LLC, West acquired the franchise rights for the chain in Chicago. Ultimately, only two locations opened in 2009. The Orland Park restaurant closed in February 2011, followed by the remaining Beverly location later that year.

In 2004, shortly after the release of his debut album *The College Dropout*, Kanye West founded the record label and production company GOOD Music in partnership with Sony BMG. The label's inaugural roster included West alongside John Legend and Common. GOOD Music has since been home to artists such as West, Big Sean, Pusha T, Teyana Taylor, Yasiin Bey (also known as Mos Def), D'banj, and John Legend, as well as producers including Hudson Mohawke, Q-Tip, Travis Scott, No I.D., Jeff Bhasker, and S1. Ten albums released by the label have been certified gold or higher by the Recording Industry Association of America (RIAA). In November 2015, West appointed Pusha T as the new president of GOOD Music.

On January 5, 2012, Kanye West announced the founding of the creative content company DONDA, named after his late mother, Donda West. In his statement, West declared that the company would "pick up where Steve Jobs left off," operating as "a design company which will galvanize amazing thinkers in a creative space to bounce their dreams and ideas," with the aim of creating "products and experiences that people want and can afford." West has maintained a notably secretive approach to the company's operations, eschewing an official website and social media presence. He described DONDA's creative philosophy as bringing "creatives in a room together with like minds" to "simplify and aesthetically improve everything we see, taste, touch, and feel." Contemporary observers have noted a consistent minimalist aesthetic in DONDA's creative projects.

In 2003, Kanye West and his mother founded the Kanye West Foundation in Chicago. Its mission was to combat dropout and illiteracy rates by collaborating with community organizations to offer music education to underprivileged youth. In 2007, West and the foundation partnered with Strong American Schools for its "Ed in '08" campaign. As a spokesman, West appeared in a series of public service announcements for the organization and hosted an inaugural benefit concert that August.
In 2008, after the death of West's mother, the foundation was renamed the Dr. Donda West Foundation. It ceased operations in 2011.

West has also participated in numerous charitable events and community initiatives, including fundraisers and benefit concerts for Hurricane Katrina relief, the Kanye West Foundation, the Millions More Movement, 100 Black Men of America, Live Earth, World Water Day rallies and marches, and Nike runs. Additionally, he appeared in an MTV special assisting young Iraq War veterans dealing with debt and post-traumatic stress disorder upon returning home.

Throughout his career, West has been an outspoken and controversial figure, drawing both criticism and praise from various quarters, including the mainstream media, fellow artists and entertainers, and two U.S. presidents. On September 2, 2005, during NBC's *A Concert for Hurricane Relief*, a benefit for Hurricane Katrina victims, West—who was a featured speaker—accused President George W. Bush of not caring about African Americans. While presenting alongside actor Mike Myers, West departed from the prepared script to condemn the media's depiction of hurricane victims, stating:

Myers spoke next and continued reading from the script. When it was West's turn to speak again, he stated, "George Bush doesn't care about black people." At that moment, telethon producer Rick Kaplan cut off West's microphone and switched the broadcast to Chris Tucker, who remained unaware of the interruption for several seconds. Despite this, West's remark was heard by much of the United States.

In a November 2010 taped interview with Matt Lauer for the *Today* show, Kanye West expressed regret for his earlier criticism of President George W. Bush, stating, "I would tell George Bush in my moment of frustration, I didn't have the grounds to call him a racist." He added, "I believe that in a situation of high emotion like that we as human beings don't always choose the right words." Bush had previously described West's comment—made in the aftermath of Hurricane Katrina—as "one of the most disgusting moments" of his presidency. The following day, in a live interview with Lauer, Bush responded to the apology, saying he appreciated the rapper's remorse. "I'm not a hater," Bush remarked. "I don't hate Kanye West. I was talking about an environment in which people were willing to say things that hurt. Nobody wants to be called a racist if in your heart you believe in equality of races."

Reactions to the apology were mixed. Some observers felt West had no need to apologize; Def Jam co-founder Russell Simmons argued, "It was not the particulars of your words that mattered, it was the essence of a feeling of the insensitivity towards our communities that many of us have felt for far too long." Bush himself was receptive, noting, "I appreciate that. It wasn't just Kanye West who was talking like that during Katrina, I cited him as an example, I cited others as an example as well. You know, I appreciate that."

In September 2013, Kanye West faced widespread criticism from human rights organizations for performing at the wedding of the grandson of authoritarian President Nursultan Nazarbayev in Kazakhstan. He attended the event as a personal guest of Nazarbayev, despite Kazakhstan's reputation for having one of the world's poorest human rights records. Other prominent Western artists, such as Sting, had previously canceled performances in the country due to human rights concerns. West was reportedly compensated US$3 million for his appearance. This contrasted with his prior involvement in cultural boycotts, including joining Shakira and Rage Against the Machine in refusing to perform in Arizona following the 0 implementation of stop-and-search laws targeting potential undocumented immigrants.

In late 2013, West posted a series of critical tweets aimed at talk show host Jimmy Kimmel. This followed a September 25 segment on Kimmel’s ABC program *Jimmy Kimmel Live!*, which featured two children reenacting West’s recent interview with Zane Lowe on BBC Radio 1, during which West had declared himself “the biggest rock star on the planet.” The following night, Kimmel stated that West had called him shortly before taping to demand an apology.

During a November 26, 2013 radio interview, Kanye West commented on his perception of President Barack Obama's challenges in advancing policies in Washington, D.C., stating: "Man, let me tell you something about George Bush and oil money and Obama and no money. People want to say Obama can't make these moves or he's not executing. That's because he ain't got those connections. Black people don't have the same level of connections as Jewish people...We ain't Jewish. We don't got family that got money like that." In response, the Anti-Defamation League criticized the remarks as perpetuating an "age-old canard that Jews are all-powerful and control the levers of power in government." On December 21, 2013, West walked back his original statement in an interview with a Chicago radio station, saying, "I thought I was giving a compliment, but if anything it came off more ignorant. I don’t know how being told you have money is an insult."
In February 2016, West sparked further controversy by posting a tweet that appeared to defend Bill Cosby, who faced sexual assault allegations from more than 50 women.

In 2004, West began a series of public incidents at music award ceremonies. At the 2004 American Music Awards, he left the auditorium abruptly after losing the Best New Artist award to country singer Gretchen Wilson. He later stated, "I felt like I was definitely robbed [...] I was the best new artist this year." Following the announcement of the 2006 Grammy nominations, West remarked that he would "really have a problem" if he did not win Album of the Year, adding, "I don't care what I do, I don't care how much I stunt – you can never take away from the amount of work I put into it. I don't want to hear all of that politically correct stuff." On November 2, 2006, after his video for "Touch the Sky" did not win Best Video at the MTV Europe Music Awards, West walked onstage during the presentation of the award to Justice and Simian for "We Are Your Friends" and contended that he should have received the honor. The outburst drew criticism from numerous international news organizations. On November 7, 2006, West publicly apologized for the incident during his opening performance for U2's Vertigo Tour concert in Brisbane. He later parodied the event in a sketch on the September 2007 season premiere of *Saturday Night Live*'s 33rd season.

On September 9, 2007, West suggested that his race may have contributed to being passed over to open the 2007 MTV Video Music Awards (VMAs), a role given instead to Britney Spears; he remarked, "Maybe my skin’s not right." West performed at the ceremony but lost all five awards for which he was nominated, including Best Male Artist and Video of the Year. Following the event, he expressed visible frustration at having lost at the VMAs for two consecutive years, declaring he would not return to MTV. In subsequent radio interviews, West stated that he had envisioned opening the VMAs with his song "Stronger." He also commented that Spears had not had a hit record in some time and accused MTV of exploiting her for ratings.

On August 30, 2015, Kanye West received the Michael Jackson Video Vanguard Award at the MTV Video Music Awards. During his acceptance speech, he remarked, "Y'all might be thinking right now, 'I wonder did he smoke something before he came out here?' And the answer is: 'Yes, I rolled up a little something. I knocked the edge off.'" He concluded by announcing, "I have decided in 2020 to run for president."

Music fans worldwide have used Change.org to petition against Kanye West's inclusion in various events. The largest such effort, which was unsuccessful, targeted the 2015 Glastonbury Festival, gathering over 133,000 signatures from individuals who expressed a preference for a rock band as the headliner. On July 20, 2015, within five days of West being announced as the headlining artist for the closing ceremonies of the 2015 Pan American Games, a Change.org petition started by user XYZ amassed more than 50,000 signatures calling for his removal, arguing that the headlining performer should be Canadian. During his performance at the Pan American Games closing ceremony, near the conclusion of his set, West ended the show by throwing a malfunctioning microphone into the air and walking offstage.

West began an intermittent relationship with fashion designer Alexis Phifer in 2002; the couple became engaged in August 2006 but ended their engagement after 18 months in 2008. He subsequently dated model Amber Rose from 2008 until mid‑2010. In April 2012, West began a relationship with reality television personality and longtime friend Kim Kardashian. The couple became engaged in October 2013 and married on May 24, 2014, at Forte di Belvedere in Florence, Italy. Their private ceremony attracted widespread media coverage, and West later expressed dissatisfaction with the couple's portrayal in the press. They have two children: daughter North "Nori" West (born June 15, 2013) and son Saint West (born December 5, 2015). In April 2015, West and Kardashian traveled to Jerusalem to have North baptized in the Armenian Apostolic Church at the Cathedral of St. James. Their high-profile careers and public status have drawn sustained media attention to their relationship; *The New York Times* described their marriage as "a historic blizzard of celebrity."

On November 10, 2007, at approximately 7:35 p.m., paramedics responding to an emergency call transported Donda West, the mother of musician Kanye West, to Centinela Freeman Hospital in Marina del Rey, California. She was unresponsive upon arrival at the emergency room. After attempts at resuscitation, physicians pronounced her dead at around 8:30 p.m.; she was 58 years old. In January 2008, the Los Angeles County Coroner's Office reported that West died of coronary artery disease exacerbated by "multiple post-operative factors" following cosmetic surgery. She had undergone liposuction and breast reduction procedures. Beverly Hills plastic surgeon Andre Aboolian had previously declined to perform the surgery due to a pre-existing health condition that increased her risk of heart attack. Aboolian referred her to an internist for cardiac evaluation, but she did not consult the recommended physician. Instead, the surgeries were performed by another doctor, Jan Adams.

Adams expressed condolences to Donda West's family but refrained from publicly discussing the procedure, citing confidentiality. Following West's death, her family, represented by celebrity attorney Ed McPherson, filed complaints with the Medical Board against Adams and Aboolian for alleged breaches of patient confidentiality. Adams had previously been under scrutiny by the medical board. He appeared on *Larry King Live* on November 20, 2007, but departed before speaking. Two days later, he returned to the program with his attorney, stating he intended to "defend himself." Adams remarked that the recently released autopsy results "spoke for themselves." The final coroner's report, issued on January 10, 2008, concluded that West died from "coronary artery disease and multiple post-operative factors due to or as a consequence of liposuction and mammoplasty."

Donda West's funeral and burial took place in Oklahoma City on November 20, 2007. Following the service, West performed his first concert after her death at The O2 in London on November 22. During the show, he dedicated performances of "Hey Mama" and a cover of Journey's "Don't Stop Believin'" to his mother, a tribute he continued at all subsequent dates of his Glow in the Dark Tour.
At a December 2008 press conference in New Zealand, West publicly addressed his mother's death for the first time, stating, "It was like losing an arm and a leg and trying to walk through that."
The "Donda West Law," signed by California Governor Arnold Schwarzenegger, requires patients to obtain medical clearance before undergoing elective cosmetic surgery.

In December 2006, Robert "Evel" Knievel filed a lawsuit against Kanye West for trademark infringement over West's music video for "Touch the Sky." Knievel objected to the video's sexually suggestive content, in which West portrays a character called "Evel Kanyevel" and attempts to launch a rocket across a canyon. The suit alleged that the video unlawfully used Knievel's trademarked name and likeness, and that its "vulgar and offensive" imagery harmed his reputation. Knievel sought monetary compensation and a court order to halt distribution of the video. West's legal team contended that the work constituted protected satire under the First Amendment. Shortly before his death in November 2007, Knievel reached an amicable settlement after a personal visit from West, whom he later described as "a wonderful guy and quite a gentleman."

On September 11, 2008, Kanye West and his road manager and bodyguard, Don "Don C." Crowley, were arrested at Los Angeles International Airport and charged with felony vandalism following an altercation with paparazzi, during which they damaged the photographers' cameras. West was subsequently released from the Los Angeles Police Department's Pacific Division station in Culver City after posting a $20,000 bail bond. On September 26, 2008, the Los Angeles County District Attorney's Office announced that it would not pursue felony charges against West related to the incident. The case was instead referred to the city attorney's office, which on March 18, 2009, charged West with one count each of misdemeanor vandalism, grand theft, and battery, while charging Crowley with three counts of each offense. The arraignment for West and Crowley, originally scheduled for April 14, 2009, was postponed.

On November 14, 2008, West was arrested at the Hilton hotel near Gateshead following an altercation with a photographer outside the Tup Tup Palace nightclub in Newcastle upon Tyne. He was subsequently released without charge, as confirmed by a police spokesperson.

On July 19, 2013, Kanye West was departing from Los Angeles International Airport when he was surrounded by numerous paparazzi. West grew increasingly agitated as photographer Daniel Ramos repeatedly questioned why individuals were not permitted to speak in his presence. West responded, "I told you don't talk to me, right? You trying to get me in trouble so I steal off on you and have to pay you like $250,000 and shit." He then allegedly charged at Ramos, seizing both the photographer and his camera. The incident, recorded by TMZ, lasted several seconds until a woman's voice was heard urging West to stop. West subsequently released Ramos and his camera before driving away. Medics were later called to assist Ramos. Initially, West faced potential felony charges of attempted robbery, but these were reduced to misdemeanor counts of criminal battery and attempted grand theft. In March 2014, West was sentenced to two years' probation for misdemeanor battery, along with requirements to complete 24 anger management sessions, perform 250 hours of community service, and pay restitution to Ramos.

Following the success of his song "Jesus Walks" from the album *The College Dropout*, West was asked about his religious beliefs and stated, "I will say that I'm spiritual. I have accepted Jesus as my Savior. And I will say that I fall short every day." In September 2014, during a concert, he also identified himself as a Christian.

Kanye West is widely regarded as one of the most critically acclaimed artists of the 21st century, earning praise from music critics, fans, fellow musicians, and cultural figures. AllMusic editor Jason Birchmeier noted his impact, writing, "As his career progressed throughout the early 21st century, West shattered certain stereotypes about rappers, becoming a superstar on his own terms without adapting his appearance, his rhetoric, or his music to fit any one musical mold." Jon Caramanica of *The New York Times* described West as "a frequent lightning rod for controversy, a bombastic figure who can count rankling two presidents among his achievements, along with being a reliably dyspeptic presence at award shows (when he attends them)." Ben Westhoff, senior editor at *Village Voice Media*, called him the greatest hip hop artist of all time, arguing that "he's made the best albums and changed the game the most, and his music is the most likely to endure." *Complex* magazine labeled him the 21st century's "most important artist of any art form, of any genre." *The Guardian* has compared West to David Bowie, contending that "there is nobody else who can sell as many records as West does (30m-odd album sales and counting) while remaining so resolutely experimental and capable of stirring things up culturally and politically."

West's middle-class background, flamboyant fashion sense, and outspokenness distinguished him from many of his contemporaries in hip hop. Early in his career, he was among the first prominent rappers to publicly criticize the widespread homophobia within the genre. The 2007 sales competition between 50 Cent's *Curtis* and West's *Graduation* marked a shift in hip hop's direction, paving the way for artists who diverged from the hardcore gangster persona. *The Guardian* critic Rosie Swash described the rivalry as a historic moment that "highlighted the diverging facets of hip-hop in the last decade; the former was gangsta rap for the noughties, while West was the thinking man's alternative." *Rolling Stone* credited West with reshaping mainstream hip hop by "establishing a style of introspective yet glossy rap," and characterized him as "as interesting and complicated a pop star as the 2000s produced—a rapper who mastered, upped and moved beyond the hip-hop game, a producer who created a signature sound and then abandoned it to his imitators, a flashy, free-spending sybarite with insightful things to say about college, culture and economics, an egomaniac with more than enough artistic firepower to back it up." His 2008 album *808s & Heartbreak* polarized critics and audiences upon release but achieved commercial success and exerted a lasting stylistic influence on hip hop and pop music. The album's emphasis on emotional vulnerability and introspection helped lay the groundwork for a subsequent wave of artists—including Frank Ocean, The Weeknd, Drake, Future, Kid Cudi, Childish Gambino, and others—who often eschewed conventional rap braggadocio in favor of personal themes. According to *XXL* writer Ben Detrick, West effectively spearheaded a movement of artists such as Kid Cudi, Wale, Lupe Fiasco, and Drake, who generally avoided subject matter centered on gun violence or drug trafficking.

A significant number of artists and other public figures have cited the work of Kanye West as an influence or have praised it. Within hip hop, these include RZA of the Wu-Tang Clan, Chuck D of Public Enemy, and DJ Premier of Gang Starr. Rappers Drake and Casey Veggies have acknowledged direct influence from West. Outside of rap, artists such as English singer-songwriters Adele and Lily Allen, New Zealand musician Lorde, the rock band Arctic Monkeys, pop singer Halsey, Sergio Pizzorno of the English rock band Kasabian, and the American indie rock group MGMT have also cited West as an influence. Experimental and electronic musicians, including James Blake, Daniel Lopatin, and Tim Hecker, have noted his work as an inspiration. Lou Reed, the experimental rock pioneer and founder of the Velvet Underground, reviewed West's album *Yeezus* and wrote, "the guy really, really, really is talented. He's really trying to raise the bar. No one's near doing what he’s doing, it’s not even on the same planet." Other notable musicians such as Paul McCartney and Prince have also commended West's work. Tesla CEO and inventor Elon Musk praised West in a piece for *Time* magazine's list of the 100 most influential people, writing:

Kanye West's first six solo studio albums have all been certified platinum and have garnered numerous awards and critical acclaim. Each album achieved commercial success, with his sixth solo album, *Yeezus*, marking his fifth consecutive U.S. number-one album upon release. As of December 2012, six of West's singles had surpassed three million digital sales in the United States: "Gold Digger" (3,086,000), "Stronger" (4,402,000), "Heartless" (3,742,000), "E.T." (over 4,000,000), "Love Lockdown" (over 3,000,000), and "Niggas in Paris" (over 3,000,000). This placed him third in overall digital sales for the preceding decade. With over 30 million digital songs sold in the United States, West ranks among the best-selling digital artists of all time.

As of 2013, West had won a total of 21 Grammy Awards, ranking him among the most awarded artists in history. About.com placed him at number eight on its "Top 50 Hip-Hop Producers" list. On May 16, 2008, MTV named West the year's top "Hottest MC in the Game." He was later voted MTV's Man of the Year on December 17, 2010. Billboard ranked West third on its list of the Top 10 Producers of the Decade. He ties with Bob Dylan for the most number-one albums on the annual Pazz & Jop critics' poll, each with four albums topping the list. West has been included twice in *Time* magazine's 100 annual list of the world's most influential people and has appeared in several Forbes annual lists.

In its 2012 list of the "500 Greatest Albums of All Time," *Rolling Stone* included three albums by Kanye West: *The College Dropout* at number 298, *Late Registration* at number 118, and *My Beautiful Dark Twisted Fantasy* at number 353.

On August 19, 2014, the online music publication Pitchfork ranked *My Beautiful Dark Twisted Fantasy* as the best album of the decade "so far"—covering the period from 2010 to 2014—while *Yeezus* placed eighth on a list of 100 albums. That same week, the song "Runaway" (featuring Pusha T) was ranked third in the publication's list of the 200 best tracks released since 2010.

West's outspoken views and activities beyond music have attracted substantial mainstream attention. He has frequently generated controversy and public scrutiny for his behavior at award ceremonies, on social media, and in other public forums. Among his most widely publicized remarks are his statement during a 2005 live television broadcast for Hurricane Katrina relief that President George W. Bush "doesn't care about black people," and his interruption of singer Taylor Swift at the 2009 MTV Video Music Awards. As a designer, West has undertaken collaborations with brands such as Nike, Louis Vuitton, and A.P.C. on apparel and footwear; his most prominent venture is the Yeezy partnership with Adidas, which began in 2013. He is also the founder and head of the creative content company DONDA.

Buddhism (/ˈbudɪzəm/) is a nontheistic religion or philosophical tradition (Sanskrit: धर्म dharma; Pali: धम्म dhamma) encompassing diverse traditions, beliefs, and spiritual practices based largely on teachings attributed to Gautama Buddha, known as the Buddha ("the awakened one"). According to Buddhist tradition, the Buddha lived and taught in the eastern part of the Indian subcontinent, in present-day Nepal, between the 6th and 4th centuries BCE. He is regarded by Buddhists as an awakened or enlightened teacher who shared insights to help sentient beings end suffering by eliminating ignorance and craving. This is held to be achieved through direct understanding and perception of dependent origination and the Four Noble Truths.

Comprehensive schools are designed to provide an equitable curriculum to all students, without selection based on financial considerations or academic attainment. As a result, these schools offer a broader curriculum that includes practical subjects such as design and technology, as well as vocational learning, which are often less prevalent or absent in grammar schools. 

However, providing cost-effective post-16 education poses challenges for smaller comprehensive schools due to the need for a variety of courses to accommodate a wider curriculum with comparatively fewer students. Consequently, many schools have increased in size, and numerous local authorities have organized secondary education into 11–16 schools, with post-16 provisions typically offered by Sixth Form colleges and Further Education Colleges. 

While comprehensive schools do not select students based on academic achievement or aptitude, demographic factors contribute to significant variations in the attainment profiles among different schools. Additionally, government initiatives, such as the City Technology Colleges and Specialist Schools programs, have introduced complexities that challenge the comprehensive ideal.

In these schools, children could be selected based on their curriculum aptitude related to the school's specialization, although the institutions maintained quotas from each quartile of the attainment spectrum to ensure that they were not selective by attainment alone. A challenge associated with this approach is determining whether the quotas should be derived from a normal distribution or from the specific attainment distribution within the immediate catchment area. 

In the selective school system, which persists in several regions of the United Kingdom, admission is contingent upon selection criteria, most commonly involving cognitive tests. Although comprehensive schools were introduced in England and Wales in 1965, there remain 164 selective grammar schools currently in operation, a relatively small number compared to the approximately 3,500 state secondary schools in England.

Most comprehensive schools serve children between the ages of 11 and 16; however, in certain areas, there are comprehensive middle schools. Additionally, in some regions, the secondary education structure is divided into two tiers, catering to students aged 11 to 14 and those aged 14 to 18, which roughly corresponds to the American middle school (or junior high school) and high school systems, respectively. With the implementation of key stages in the National Curriculum, some local authorities transitioned from the middle school system back to 11–16 and 11–18 schools, ensuring that the transition between educational levels aligns with the conclusion of one key stage and the commencement of another.

Comprehensive schools were originally conceived as "neighbourhood" institutions intended to serve all students within a designated catchment area. Current educational reforms, including the Academies Programme, Free Schools, and University Technical Colleges, are likely to influence the comprehensive ideal; however, it is still premature to assess the extent of this impact.

Germany has a comprehensive school system known as the Gesamtschule. Unlike other German schools, such as the Gymnasium and the Realschule, which have strict entrance requirements, the Gesamtschule does not impose such criteria. It offers a range of educational tracks, including college preparatory classes for high-achieving students, general education classes for average students, and remedial courses for those who require additional support. Depending on their academic performance, students attending a Gesamtschule can graduate with the Hauptschulabschluss, the Realschulabschluss, or the Abitur.

The percentage of students attending a Gesamtschule varies by Bundesland. In the state of Brandenburg, more than 50% of all students attended a Gesamtschule in 2007, whereas in the state of Bavaria, less than 1% did.

Starting in the 2010/2011 academic year, Hauptschulen were merged with Realschulen and Gesamtschulen to create a new type of comprehensive school in the German states of Berlin and Hamburg. In Hamburg, this new institution is referred to as Stadtteilschule, while in Berlin it is called Sekundarschule (see: Education in Berlin, Education in Hamburg).

The "Mittelschule" is an educational institution in certain states of Germany that offers regular and remedial classes but does not provide college preparatory courses. In some states, the Hauptschule is not present, and any student who has not been accepted into another school is required to attend the Mittelschule. Students may receive the Hauptschulabschluss or the Mittlere Reife, but not the Abitur.

Comprehensive schools have faced accusations of grade inflation following a study indicating that Gymnasium senior students of average mathematical ability ranked at the bottom of their class, with an average grade of "Five," denoting "Failed." In contrast, Gesamtschule senior students of similar ability found themselves in the upper half of their class, achieving an average grade of "Three Plus." The establishment of a central Abitur examination in the State of North Rhine-Westphalia revealed that Gesamtschule students performed worse than predicted based on their grades or class rank. 

Barbara Sommer, the Education Minister of North Rhine-Westphalia from the Christian Democratic Union, remarked on the significant performance gap between comprehensive schools and Gymnasiums in the central Abitur examination. She expressed confusion regarding the Social Democratic Party of Germany's intentions to abolish the Gymnasium, asserting that "the comprehensives do not help students achieve." Sommer further criticized the tendency of comprehensive schools to attribute their challenges to the social backgrounds of their students, stating, "What kind of attitude is this to blame their own students?" She referred to the Abitur awarded by the Gymnasium as the "true Abitur," contrasting it with the "Abitur light" conferred by the Gesamtschule.

In response, Sigrid Beer of Alliance '90/The Greens claimed that comprehensive schools were structurally discriminated against by the government, which she argued favored Gymnasiums. She emphasized that many students awarded the Abitur by comprehensive schools came from "underprivileged groups," characterizing any derision toward their academic performance as "a piece of impudence."

Gesamtschulen may pose a risk to academically gifted working-class students, according to several studies. Research has indicated that an achievement gap emerges between working-class students attending comprehensive schools and their middle-class peers. Additionally, working-class students enrolled in Gymnasium or Realschule tend to outperform their counterparts from similar backgrounds attending comprehensive schools. Notably, it is the students attending Hauptschule who exhibit the lowest academic performance.

A study conducted by Helmut Fend, a long-time advocate of comprehensive schools, revealed that these institutions do not significantly benefit working-class students. Fend compared the outcomes of alumni from the tripartite system with those from comprehensive schools. Although working-class alumni of comprehensive schools earned better school diplomas by the age of 35, they occupied similar occupational positions as their counterparts from the tripartite system and were equally unlikely to graduate from college.

Gibraltar established its first comprehensive school in 1972. For students aged 12 to 16, two comprehensive schools serve boys and girls separately. Additionally, students have the option to continue into the sixth form to complete their A-levels.

Comprehensive schools were introduced in Ireland in 1966 through an initiative by Patrick Hillery, the Minister for Education, aimed at providing a broader range of educational opportunities compared to the vocational school system, which was the only state-controlled school system at the time. Prior to this, education in Ireland was predominantly influenced by religious affiliations, particularly through the voluntary secondary school system. Although the comprehensive school system remains relatively small, it has been to some extent superseded by the community school concept. The Irish term for a comprehensive school is 'scoil chuimsitheach.'

In Ireland, comprehensive schools were an early model of state education introduced in the late 1960s. This model was largely supplanted by the secular community school model that emerged in the 1970s. The comprehensive model generally included older schools that were under the ownership of Roman Catholic or Protestant denominations, which continued to manage these institutions as patrons or trustees. The state retains ownership of the school property, which is held in trust by the trustees in perpetuity. This model was implemented to make state schools more acceptable to the predominantly conservative society of the time.

The introduction of the community school model in the 1970s marked a significant shift by removing the denominational basis of schools; however, religious interests were invited to be represented on the Boards of Management. Community schools are categorized into two models: the community school, which is vested in the Minister for Education, and the community college, which is vested in the local Education and Training Board. Community colleges typically represent amalgamations of unviable local schools functioning under the framework of a new community school model, whereas community schools have generally been established as entirely new institutions.

The first comprehensive schools were established after the Second World War. In 1946, for instance, Walworth School became one of five 'experimental' comprehensive schools initiated by the London County Council. Another early comprehensive school was Holyhead County School in Anglesey, which opened in 1949. Additional early examples of comprehensive schools include Woodlands Boys School in Coventry, founded in 1954, and Tividale Comprehensive School in Tipton.

This policy was implemented through Circular 10/65, which instructed local education authorities to prepare for the conversion to a comprehensive system. 

Under the previous system, students took the 11+ examination in their final year of primary education, determining their placement in one of three types of secondary schools: secondary modern, secondary technical, or grammar schools, based on their perceived ability. However, secondary technical schools were never widely established. For two decades, the education system effectively operated under a bipartite structure, resulting in intense competition for the limited grammar school places, which constituted between 15% and 25% of total secondary school placements, varying by location.

In 1970, Margaret Thatcher was appointed Secretary of State for Education in the newly formed Conservative government. She removed the obligation for local authorities to convert to comprehensive schools; however, many local authorities had already made significant progress in this direction, making it prohibitively expensive to reverse the process. As a result, more comprehensive schools were established under Mrs. Thatcher than under any other Education Secretary.

By 1975, the majority of local authorities in England and Wales had abandoned the 11-plus examination in favor of a comprehensive education system. Over the course of the preceding decade, many secondary modern schools and grammar schools were amalgamated to create large neighborhood comprehensives, while several new schools were constructed to accommodate the growing student population. By the mid-1970s, the comprehensive system had been nearly fully implemented, with virtually no secondary modern schools remaining. Many grammar schools were either closed or converted to comprehensive status. Some local authorities, including Sandwell and Dudley in the West Midlands, transitioned all of their state secondary schools to comprehensive schools during the 1970s.

In 1976, future Labour Prime Minister James Callaghan initiated what became known as the "Great Debate" on the education system. He identified several areas that required close examination: the need for a core curriculum, the validity and application of informal teaching methods, the role of school inspections, and the future of the examination system. Comprehensive schools remain the most prevalent type of state secondary school in England and the only type in Wales, accounting for approximately 90% of pupils, or 64% when excluding schools with low-level selection. This statistic varies by region.

Since the 1988 Education Reform Act, parents have the right to choose which school their child will attend or to opt for home education instead. The concept of "school choice" introduces competition among state schools, marking a fundamental shift from the original "neighbourhood comprehensive" model. This change aims to compel schools perceived as inferior to either improve their standards or, if they fail to attract students, to close down. Current government policy promotes 'specialisation,' allowing parents to select secondary schools that align with their child's interests and skills. Most initiatives emphasize parental choice and information, creating a pseudo-market incentive to encourage the establishment of better schools. This rationale has supported the controversial league tables of school performance.

Scotland's educational system differs significantly from that of England and Wales, while still adhering to the principles of comprehensive education. It features distinct ages of transfer, unique examinations, and a different philosophy regarding choice and provision. All publicly funded primary and secondary schools in Scotland operate as comprehensive institutions. Since 2005, the Scottish Government has rejected proposals for specialist schools.

Education in Northern Ireland exhibits some differences from the systems employed in other parts of the United Kingdom; however, it is more akin to the systems in England and Wales than to that of Scotland.

The region was historically dominated by Bantu-speaking tribes, who established trade connections leading into the Congo River basin. Congo-Brazzaville was formerly part of the French colony of Equatorial Africa. Following its independence in 1960, the former colony of French Congo became the Republic of the Congo. From 1970 to 1991, the People's Republic of the Congo functioned as a Marxist–Leninist one-party state. Multi-party elections have been conducted since 1992; however, a democratically elected government was overthrown during the Republic of the Congo Civil War in 1997, and President Denis Sassou Nguesso has been in power for 26 of the past 36 years.

The political stability and development of hydrocarbon production have positioned the Republic of Congo as the fourth largest oil producer in the Gulf of Guinea. This status has afforded the country a relative prosperity, despite the poor condition of its infrastructure and public services, as well as an uneven distribution of oil revenues.

Bantu-speaking peoples, who established tribes during the Bantu expansions, largely displaced and absorbed the region's earliest inhabitants, the Pygmy peoples, around 1500 BC. The Bakongo, a Bantu ethnic group that also inhabited parts of present-day Angola, Gabon, and the Democratic Republic of the Congo, formed the foundation for the ethnic affinities and rivalries among these countries. Several Bantu kingdoms—most notably the Kongo, Loango, and Teke—developed trade links that extended into the Congo River basin.

The area north of the Congo River came under French sovereignty in 1880 following Pierre de Brazza's treaty with Makoko of the Bateke. This territory was initially referred to as French Congo and was renamed Middle Congo in 1903. In 1908, France established French Equatorial Africa (AEF), which included Middle Congo, Gabon, Chad, and Oubangui-Chari (now the Central African Republic). Brazzaville was designated as the federal capital of this federation. Economic development during the first 50 years of colonial rule in the Congo focused primarily on the extraction of natural resources. The methods employed were often brutal; the construction of the Congo–Ocean Railroad after World War I is estimated to have resulted in at least 14,000 deaths.

During the Nazi occupation of France in World War II, Brazzaville served as the symbolic capital of Free France from 1940 to 1943. The Brazzaville Conference of 1944 marked the beginning of significant reforms in French colonial policy. As a result of its central geographic location within French Equatorial Africa (AEF) and its status as the federal capital, Congo benefited from increased postwar investment in colonial administration and infrastructure. Additionally, the adoption of the 1946 constitution, which established the Fourth Republic, led to the creation of a local legislature for the region.

Following the revision of the French constitution that established the Fifth Republic in 1958, the French Equatorial Africa (AEF) dissolved into its constituent territories, each of which became an autonomous colony within the French Community. During these reforms, Middle Congo was renamed the Republic of the Congo in 1958 and adopted its first constitution in 1959.
