Tensions between the pro-Opangault Mbochis and the pro-Youlou Balalis led to a series of riots in Brazzaville in February 1959, which were suppressed by the French Army.

Marien Ngouabi, who participated in the coup, assumed the presidency on December 31, 1968. One year later, President Ngouabi declared Congo as Africa's first "people's republic," officially naming it the People's Republic of the Congo. He also announced the decision of the National Revolutionary Movement to change its name to the Congolese Labour Party (PCT). Ngouabi survived an attempted coup in 1972 but was ultimately assassinated on March 16, 1977. Following his assassination, an 11-member Military Committee of the Party (CMP) was established to lead an interim government, with Joachim Yhombi-Opango serving as President of the Republic. Two years later, Yhombi-Opango was ousted from power, and Denis Sassou Nguesso became the new president.

Sassou Nguesso aligned the country with the Eastern Bloc and signed a twenty-year friendship pact with the Soviet Union. Over the years, he increasingly relied on political repression rather than patronage to sustain his dictatorship.

Pascal Lissouba served as Congo's first elected president from 1992 to 1997 during a period characterized by multi-party democracy. He endeavored to implement economic reforms supported by the International Monetary Fund (IMF) to liberalize the economy. In June 1996, the IMF approved a three-year Enhanced Structural Adjustment Facility (ESAF) amounting to SDR 69.5 million (approximately US$100 million) and was poised to announce a renewed annual agreement when civil war erupted in Congo in mid-1997.

Congo's democratic progress was disrupted in 1997 when Lissouba and Sassou engaged in a power struggle during a civil war. As the presidential elections scheduled for July 1997 approached, tensions between the Lissouba and Sassou factions escalated. On June 5, President Lissouba's government forces surrounded Sassou's compound in Brazzaville, leading Sassou to order members of his private militia, known as the "Cobras," to resist. This marked the beginning of a four-month conflict that resulted in the destruction or damage of much of Brazzaville and caused tens of thousands of civilian casualties. In early October, the Angolan socialist regime initiated an invasion of Congo with the aim of installing Sassou in power. By mid-October, the Lissouba government had fallen, and Sassou subsequently declared himself president.

In the controversial elections of 2002, Sassou won nearly 90% of the votes cast. His main rivals, Lissouba and Bernard Kolelas, were barred from competing, and the only other credible opponent, Andre Milongo, urged his supporters to boycott the elections before ultimately withdrawing from the race. A new constitution, ratified by referendum in January 2002, conferred additional powers upon the president, extended his term to seven years, and established a new bicameral assembly. International observers criticized the organization of both the presidential election and the constitutional referendum, noting their resemblance to the practices of Congo's one-party state era. Following the presidential elections, hostilities resumed in the Pool region between government forces and rebels led by Pastor Ntumi; a peace treaty to resolve the conflict was signed in April 2003.

Sassou won the subsequent presidential election in July 2009. According to the Congolese Observatory of Human Rights, a non-governmental organization, the election was characterized by "very low" voter turnout as well as "fraud and irregularities."

Congo-Brazzaville has maintained a multi-party political system since the early 1990s; however, this system is significantly dominated by President Denis Sassou Nguesso, who has faced little serious competition in the presidential elections conducted during his tenure. Sassou Nguesso is supported by his party, the Congolese Labour Party (French: Parti Congolais du Travail), along with a variety of smaller political parties.

Internationally, Sassou's regime has faced significant scrutiny due to revelations of corruption, despite efforts to suppress such information. A French investigation uncovered over 110 bank accounts and numerous opulent properties in France. In response, Sassou characterized the embezzlement investigations as "racist" and "colonial."

On March 27, 2015, Sassou Nguesso announced that his government would hold a referendum to amend the 2002 constitution, enabling him to seek a third consecutive term in office. On October 25, the referendum was conducted, with the government asserting that the proposal was approved by 92 percent of voters, with a participation rate of 72 percent among eligible voters. However, the opposition, which had boycotted the referendum, contended that the government's statistics were misleading and described the vote as a sham.

In 2008, the primary media outlets were government-owned; however, an increasing number of privately operated media platforms were emerging. There was one government-owned television station and approximately ten small private television channels.

Many Pygmies are born into relationships with Bantus, a situation often described as slavery. The Congolese Human Rights Observatory reports that Pygmies are treated as property, similar to "pets." On December 30, 2010, the Congolese parliament enacted a law aimed at promoting and protecting the rights of indigenous peoples. This legislation is the first of its kind in Africa and represents a significant advancement for indigenous communities on the continent.

Congo is situated in the central-western region of sub-Saharan Africa, straddling the Equator between latitudes 4°N and 5°S, and longitudes 11°E and 19°E. It is bordered to the south and east by the Democratic Republic of the Congo, while Gabon lies to the west, and Cameroon and the Central African Republic are located to the north. To the southwest, it is adjacent to Cabinda, an exclave of Angola. The country has a brief coastline along the Atlantic Ocean.

The southwestern region of the country features a coastal plain primarily drained by the Kouilou-Niari River. The interior comprises a central plateau situated between two basins to the north and south. Forests in this area are experiencing increasing pressure from exploitation.

Since the country is situated on the Equator, its climate remains consistent throughout the year, with an average daytime temperature of a humid 24 °C (75 °F) and nighttime temperatures generally ranging from 16 °C (61 °F) to 21 °C (70 °F). The average annual rainfall varies significantly, ranging from 1,100 millimeters (43 inches) in the southern Niari Valley to over 2,000 millimeters (79 inches) in central regions of the country. The dry season occurs from June to August, while the majority of the country experiences a wet season characterized by two peaks in rainfall: one from March to May and another from September to November.

In the 2006–07 period, researchers from the Wildlife Conservation Society conducted a study of gorillas in the densely forested areas of the Ouesso district in the Sangha Region. They estimated a population of approximately 125,000 Western Lowland Gorillas, whose relative isolation from humans has been largely maintained by the presence of inhospitable swamps.

The economy is characterized by a combination of village agriculture and handicrafts, alongside an industrial sector primarily focused on petroleum, support services, and a government that faces challenges such as budgetary constraints and overstaffing. Petroleum extraction has overtaken forestry as the cornerstone of the economy. In 2008, the oil sector accounted for 65% of the Gross Domestic Product (GDP), 85% of government revenue, and 92% of exports. Additionally, the country possesses significant untapped mineral resources.

However, the government has mortgaged a significant portion of its petroleum earnings, leading to a revenue shortage. The devaluation of Franc Zone currencies by 50% on January 12, 1994, caused inflation to soar to 46% that same year, although inflation has since subsided.

Economic reform efforts persisted with the backing of international organizations, particularly the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund. However, the reform program encountered significant setbacks in June 1997 when civil war erupted. Following the conclusion of the war and Sassou Nguesso's return to power in October 1997, he publicly expressed a commitment to advancing economic reforms, privatization, and renewing cooperation with international financial institutions. Nonetheless, economic progress was severely hindered by declining oil prices and the resurgence of armed conflict in December 1998, which exacerbated the republic's budget deficit.

The current administration oversees a fragile internal peace while confronting significant economic challenges, including the need to stimulate recovery and alleviate poverty, despite experiencing record-high oil prices since 2003. Natural gas and diamonds have emerged as substantial exports for the Democratic Republic of the Congo; however, the country was excluded from the Kimberley Process in 2004 due to allegations that a majority of its diamond exports were being smuggled from the neighboring Democratic Republic of Congo. It was readmitted to the group in 2007.

The Republic of the Congo possesses significant untapped deposits of base metals, gold, iron, and phosphate. The country is a member of the Organization for the Harmonization of Business Law in Africa (OHADA). In 2009, the Congolese government signed an agreement to lease 200,000 hectares of land to South African farmers in an effort to reduce its reliance on imports.

Transport in the Republic of the Congo encompasses land, air, and water transportation. The country's rail system, established by forced laborers during the 1930s, continues to function today. Additionally, there are over 1,000 kilometers of paved roads and two major international airports—Maya-Maya Airport and Pointe-Noire Airport—which offer flights to Paris and various African cities. The Republic of the Congo also features a significant port on the Atlantic Ocean at Pointe-Noire, as well as additional ports along the Congo River in Brazzaville and Impfondo.

Consequently, the Republic of the Congo is one of the most urbanized countries in Africa, with approximately 70% of its total population residing in a few urban centers, particularly in Brazzaville and Pointe-Noire, as well as in smaller towns and villages along the 534-kilometer (332-mile) railway that connects these two cities. In rural areas, industrial and commercial activities have seen a significant decline in recent years, leaving local economies increasingly reliant on government support for sustenance and development.

The population of the Republic of the Congo is ethnically and linguistically diverse, with Ethnologue recognizing 62 spoken languages within the country. This population can be categorized into three main groups. The Kongo represent the largest ethnic group, constituting approximately half of the population. Key subgroups of the Kongo include the Laari, who reside in the Brazzaville and Pool regions, and the Vili, found around Pointe-Noire and along the Atlantic coast. The second largest group is the Teke, who inhabit areas to the north of Brazzaville and account for 17% of the population. The Boulangui (M’Boshi) live in the northwest and Brazzaville, making up 12% of the population. Additionally, Pygmies comprise about 2% of the total population of Congo.

Before the 1997 war, approximately 9,000 Europeans and other non-Africans resided in the Congo, the majority of whom were French. Today, only a fraction of this population remains. Currently, around 300 American expatriates live in the Congo.

According to the CIA World Factbook, the population of the Republic of the Congo is predominantly composed of Catholics (33.1%), Awakening Lutherans (22.3%), and other Protestants (19.9%). Followers of Islam constitute 1.6% of the population, a figure influenced primarily by an influx of foreign workers in urban centers.

Public expenditure on health was 8.9% of GDP in 2004, while private expenditure accounted for 1.3%. As of 2012, the prevalence of HIV/AIDS among individuals aged 15 to 49 years was 2.8%. Health expenditure per capita was US$30 in 2004. A significant portion of the population suffers from undernourishment, with malnutrition being a notable issue in Congo-Brazzaville. In the early 2000s, there were 20 physicians per 100,000 people.

As of 2010, the maternal mortality rate was 560 deaths per 100,000 live births, while the infant mortality rate stood at 59.34 deaths per 1,000 live births. Female genital mutilation (FGM) is uncommon in the country, occurring only in specific geographic regions.

Public expenditure as a percentage of GDP was lower between 2002 and 2005 compared to 1991. Although public education is theoretically free and mandatory for children under the age of 16, in practice, there are additional expenses. The net primary enrollment rate was 44% in 2005, significantly lower than the 79% recorded in 1991. The country has universities, and education is compulsory for children between the ages of six and sixteen. Students who complete six years of primary education and seven years of secondary education receive a baccalaureate. At the university level, students can earn a bachelor's degree in three years and a master's degree after an additional four years. Marien Ngouabi University, which offers courses in medicine, law, and various other fields, is the only public university in the country. Instruction at all educational levels is conducted in French, and the educational system is largely modeled after the French system. The educational infrastructure has suffered significant degradation due to political and economic crises, resulting in a lack of seating in most classrooms, forcing children to sit on the floor. Some enterprising individuals have established private schools; however, these institutions often lack the necessary technical expertise and familiarity with the national curriculum to provide effective education. Families frequently enroll their children in private schools, only to later discover that they are unable to afford the associated costs.

A prime minister is the highest-ranking minister in the cabinet of the executive branch of government, typically found in parliamentary or semi-presidential systems. In many of these systems, the prime minister has the authority to select and dismiss other cabinet members and allocate government posts. Generally, the prime minister serves as the presiding member and chairman of the cabinet. In a minority of systems, particularly in semi-presidential systems, the prime minister is the official responsible for managing the civil service and executing the directives of the head of state.

In parliamentary systems modeled after the Westminster system, the prime minister serves as the presiding and actual head of government, as well as the head of the executive branch. In these systems, the head of state or the head of the state's official representative—such as a monarch, president, or governor-general—typically occupies a largely ceremonial role, although they may possess reserve powers.

The Prime Minister is typically, but not always, a member of Parliament and is expected, along with other ministers, to facilitate the passage of bills through the legislature. In certain monarchies, the monarch may also exercise executive powers, known as the royal prerogative, which are constitutionally vested in the crown and can be enacted without the approval of Parliament.

In addition to serving as the head of government, a prime minister may hold other roles or titles. For instance, the Prime Minister of the United Kingdom also serves as the First Lord of the Treasury and Minister for the Civil Service. Prime ministers may occupy multiple ministerial positions; during the Second World War, Winston Churchill was also the Minister of Defence, despite the absence of a formal Ministry of Defence at that time. In the current cabinet of Israel, Benjamin Netanyahu concurrently holds the titles of Minister of Communications, Foreign Affairs, Regional Cooperation, Economy, and Interior.

The term "prime minister" or "Premier Ministre" was first used by Cardinal Richelieu when he was appointed to head the royal council of France in 1625. Subsequently, Louis XIV and his successors generally sought to avoid conferring this title upon their chief ministers.

The term "prime minister," as it is understood today, originated in the 18th century in the United Kingdom, where it was initially used in a disparaging manner by members of Parliament to refer to Sir Robert Walpole. Over time, the title evolved into an honorific and continues to be regarded as such in the 21st century.

The monarchs of England and the United Kingdom appointed ministers in whom they placed significant trust, and who were regarded as the heads of government. Notable examples include Thomas Cromwell under Henry VIII, William Cecil, Lord Burghley under Elizabeth I, Edward Hyde, Earl of Clarendon under Charles II, and Sidney Godolphin under Queen Anne. These ministers held various formal titles but were commonly referred to as "the minister," "the chief minister," "the first minister," and ultimately "the prime minister."

The authority of these ministers was wholly reliant on the personal favor of the monarch. While managing the parliament was an essential skill for holding high office, their power did not rely on securing a parliamentary majority. Although a cabinet existed, it was appointed entirely by the monarch, who typically presided over its meetings.

When a monarch became dissatisfied with a first minister, the minister could be dismissed, or worse: Cromwell was executed, and Clarendon was exiled after falling out of favor. To prevent any one minister from accumulating excessive power, kings sometimes divided authority among two or more ministers. For instance, during the latter part of Anne's reign, Tory ministers Harley and St John shared power.

In the mid-17th century, following the English Civil War (1642–1651), Parliament strengthened its position in relation to the monarchy and gained additional power through the Glorious Revolution of 1688 and the subsequent passage of the Bill of Rights in 1689. The monarch could no longer establish laws or impose taxes without parliamentary permission, thereby integrating the House of Commons into the government structure. This period marks the emergence of a modern style of prime minister.

A pivotal moment in the evolution of the prime ministership occurred with the death of Queen Anne in 1714 and the subsequent accession of King George I to the throne. George, who spoke no English and spent much of his time in Hanover, possessed little knowledge of or interest in the intricacies of English governance. Consequently, it became inevitable that the king's first minister would assume the role of de facto head of government.

From 1721, the Whig politician Robert Walpole held office for twenty-one years. Walpole chaired cabinet meetings, appointed all other ministers, dispensed royal patronage, and filled the House of Commons with his supporters. Under Walpole's leadership, the doctrine of cabinet solidarity emerged. He mandated that no minister, apart from himself, engage in private dealings with the king, and required that once the cabinet reached a consensus on a policy, all ministers must publicly defend it or resign. As the later Prime Minister Lord Melbourne remarked, "It matters not what we say, gentlemen, so long as we all say the same thing."

Walpole consistently denied that he held the title of "prime minister." Throughout the 18th century, parliamentarians and legal scholars maintained that no such position was recognized by the Constitution. Both George II and George III made significant efforts to restore the personal power of the monarchy; however, the growing complexity and expense of governance rendered a minister capable of commanding the loyalty of the House of Commons increasingly essential. The prolonged tenure of wartime prime minister William Pitt the Younger (1783–1801), coupled with the mental illness of George III, further solidified the power associated with the role. The title was first documented in government records during the administration of Benjamin Disraeli, but it did not appear in the formal British Order of Precedence until 1905.

By the late 20th century, the majority of countries worldwide were governed by a prime minister or an equivalent minister, functioning under either a constitutional monarchy or a ceremonial presidency. The primary exceptions to this system have been the United States and the presidential republics in Latin America, which are modeled after the U.S. system, where the president directly wields executive authority.
Sheikh Khalifah bin Sulman Al Khalifah has served as Bahrain's Prime Minister since 1970, making him the longest-serving non-elected prime minister in the world.

The position of prime minister exists in both constitutional monarchies—such as Belgium, Denmark, Japan, Luxembourg, the Netherlands, Norway, Malaysia, Morocco, Spain, Sweden, Thailand, Canada, Australia, New Zealand, and the United Kingdom—and in parliamentary republics where the head of state is an elected official, including Finland, the Czech Republic, France, Greece, Hungary, India, Indonesia, Ireland, Pakistan, Portugal, Montenegro, Croatia, Bulgaria, Romania, Serbia, and Turkey. Additionally, alternative titles that are often equivalent in meaning to, or translated as, "prime minister" include "First Minister," "Premier," "Chief Minister," "Chancellor," "Taoiseach," "Statsminister," and "Secretary of State."

This contrasts with the presidential system, in which the president (or an equivalent position) serves as both the head of state and the head of government. In certain presidential or semi-presidential systems, such as those in France, Russia, and South Korea, the prime minister is typically an official appointed by the president, although such appointments usually require approval from the legislature. The prime minister is responsible for implementing the directives of the president and managing the civil service. In the People's Republic of China, the head of government is known as the Premier of the State Council, while in the Republic of China (Taiwan), the premier is also appointed by the president but does not require legislative approval.

The appointment of the Prime Minister of France does not require approval from Parliament; however, Parliament has the authority to compel the resignation of the government. In such systems, it is possible for the President and the Prime Minister to belong to different political parties if the legislature is controlled by a party that differs from that of the President. This situation is commonly referred to as political cohabitation.
The Constitution of Bangladesh delineates the functions and powers of the Prime Minister, as well as the procedures for their appointment and dismissal.

Canada's constitution is characterized as a 'mixed' or hybrid constitution, which means it is partially formally codified and partially uncodified. Initially, the constitution did not reference a prime minister; instead, the specific duties and method of appointment for the prime minister were governed by conventions. The Constitution Act, 1982, introduced a brief mention of the "Prime Minister of Canada," although this reference pertains solely to the composition of conferences involving federal and provincial first ministers.
The Constitution of the Czech Republic clearly delineates the functions and powers of the Prime Minister, as well as the procedures for their appointment and dismissal.

The constitution of the United Kingdom is uncodified and largely unwritten, and it does not explicitly mention the position of prime minister. Although the role has effectively existed for centuries, its first reference in official state documents did not appear until the first decade of the twentieth century. Consequently, it is often stated that the position "does not exist," with several instances of Parliament affirming this claim. The prime minister serves in the cabinet solely by virtue of holding another office, typically that of First Lord of the Treasury (a position in commission), or, more rarely, Chancellor of the Exchequer, the last individual to occupy this role being Arthur Balfour in 1905.

Most prime ministers in parliamentary systems are not appointed for a specific term and may remain in power through multiple elections and parliamentary sessions. For instance, Margaret Thatcher was appointed prime minister only once, in 1979. She held office continuously until 1990, although she utilized the assembly of each House of Commons following a general election to reshuffle her cabinet.

Some states have a term of office for the prime minister that is linked to the duration of the parliament's term. For instance, in Ireland, the Taoiseach is formally 'renominated' following each general election. However, some constitutional experts have raised questions about whether this process aligns with the provisions of the Irish Constitution, which seem to indicate that a Taoiseach should remain in office without the need for renomination unless they have clearly lost the general election. Typically, the prime minister is selected from the political party that holds a majority of seats in the lower house of parliament.

In parliamentary systems, governments are typically required to maintain the confidence of the lower house of parliament. However, a small minority of parliaments grant the upper house the authority to block supply, effectively making the cabinet accountable to both houses. In practice, upper houses, even when vested with this power, rarely exercise it. When a government loses a vote of confidence, has a motion of no confidence passed against it, or loses supply, most constitutional systems mandate one of the following actions:

The latter effectively enables the government to present the opposition of parliament to the electorate. However, in many jurisdictions, a head of state may refuse a parliamentary dissolution, necessitating the resignation of the prime minister and their government. In most modern parliamentary systems, the prime minister is the individual who determines when to request a parliamentary dissolution.

Older constitutions often vest the power of parliamentary dissolution in the cabinet. In the United Kingdom, for example, the tradition that the prime minister requests a dissolution of Parliament dates back to 1918. Prior to that time, the entire government made the request. Similarly, while the modern 1937 Irish Constitution grants the Taoiseach the authority to make this request, the earlier 1922 Irish Free State Constitution conferred this power to the Executive Council, which was the designation for the Irish cabinet at that time.

In Australia, the Prime Minister is expected to resign if they lose the majority support of their party under a spill motion, as demonstrated by the experiences of Tony Abbott, Julia Gillard, and Kevin Rudd.

In the Russian Constitution, the head of government is officially titled the Chairman of the Government. In Ireland, the prime minister is referred to as the Taoiseach, which is translated into English as "prime minister." In Israel, the equivalent position is known as Rosh HaMemshalah, meaning "head of the government." It is important to note that, in many instances, the term "prime minister" is commonly used but not the official title for the office-holder; for example, the Spanish prime minister is referred to as the President of the Government (Presidente del Gobierno).

Other common titles for the head of government include President of the Council of Ministers (as seen in Italy, where it is referred to as "Presidente del Consiglio dei Ministri"), President of the Executive Council, and Minister-President. In Scandinavian countries, the prime minister is designated as "statsminister" in their native languages, which translates to "minister of state." In federal systems, the head of government for subnational entities, such as provinces, is most commonly referred to as the premier, chief minister, governor, or minister-president.

The convention in the English language is to refer to nearly all national heads of government as "prime minister," sometimes modified to the equivalent term "premier," regardless of the official title used in their respective countries. Exceptions to this convention include Germany and Austria, where the heads of government are typically referred to as "Chancellor"; Monaco, where the head of government is called the "Minister of State"; and Vatican City, where the title of head of government is "Secretary of State." In Ireland, the head of government is occasionally referred to as "Taoiseach" by English speakers. A notable case is the President of Iran, who, while not the head of state, serves as the head of government and is referred to as "president" in both Persian and English.

In non-Commonwealth countries, the prime minister may be entitled to the style of "Excellency," similar to that of a president. In some Commonwealth countries, prime ministers and former prime ministers are styled "Right Honourable" due to their positions, as seen in the case of the Prime Minister of Canada. In the United Kingdom, prime ministers and former prime ministers may also be styled "Right Honourable"; however, this designation is not a result of their role as head of government but rather a privilege associated with their current membership in Her Majesty's Most Honourable Privy Council.

In the United Kingdom, where devolved government is established, the leaders of the Scottish, Northern Irish, and Welsh Governments are designated as First Ministers. In India, the Prime Minister is referred to as "Pradhan Mantri," which translates to "prime minister." In Pakistan, the title for the prime minister is "Wazir-e-Azam," meaning "Grand Vizier."

The executive office of the Prime Minister is typically referred to as the Office of the Prime Minister in Canada and other Commonwealth countries, while in the United Kingdom, it is known as the Cabinet Office. In some instances, the Prime Minister's office may also encompass the role of the Cabinet. In other nations, it is designated as the Prime Minister's Department or the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, as is the case in Australia.

Institute of technology (also known as university of technology, polytechnic university, technikon, and technical college) refers to a diverse array of educational institutions that offer various types of degrees and operate at different levels within the educational system. These institutions may provide higher education, advanced engineering, and scientific research, or they may focus on professional vocational education, specializing in fields such as science, engineering, and technology, or other technical subjects. Additionally, the term may refer to secondary education schools that concentrate on vocational training.[citation needed] The abbreviation for institute of technology is IT, which should not be confused with information technology.
While the terms "institute of technology" and "polytechnic" are often used interchangeably, the preference for one term over the other varies by country.[citation needed]

A regular international ferry service operated by Brittany Ferries departs from Millbay, carrying both vehicles and foot passengers to Roscoff in France and Santander in Spain. The service is provided by three vessels: the MV Armorique, MV Bretagne, and MV Pont-Aven. A passenger ferry also runs between Stonehouse and the Cornish hamlet of Cremyll, a route believed to have been in continuous operation since 1204. Additionally, a pedestrian ferry connects the Mayflower Steps to Mount Batten, while the Torpoint Ferry provides a crossing for both vehicles and pedestrians across the River Tamar, serving as an alternative to the Tamar Bridge.

Plymouth City Airport, located approximately 4 miles (6 km) north of the city centre, served as the regional airport for Plymouth. It was the base for Air Southwest, a local airline that operated scheduled services to various destinations across the United Kingdom and Ireland. In June 2003, the South West Regional Development Agency published a report assessing the future of aviation in the region, which recommended the closure of Plymouth City Airport in favour of expanding Exeter International Airport and Newquay Cornwall Airport to better serve the wider south-west area; however, the report acknowledged that this outcome would not be optimal for Plymouth itself. In April 2011, it was announced that the airport would cease operations, with the final flight taking place on 23 December 2011. Subsequently, FlyPlymouth has proposed plans to reopen the airport by 2018, aiming to restore commercial air services with daily flights to multiple destinations, including London.

Plymouth railway station, opened in 1877, is managed by Great Western Railway and serves as a hub for services operated by CrossCountry. The city's smaller stations are served by local services on the Tamar Valley Line and the Cornish Main Line. Great Western Railway has recently faced criticism due to extensive reductions in rail services across the South West, with significant impacts on Plymouth. In response, the three Members of Parliament representing the region's major political parties have jointly advocated for the preservation of rail services, emphasizing their critical importance to the local economy.

The Exeter to Plymouth railway line, formerly operated by the London and South Western Railway (LSWR), has been the subject of proposals for reopening in order to provide a resilient, all-weather rail connection between Cornwall, Plymouth, and the wider UK rail network. One such proposal involves reinstating the route from Tavistock to Bere Alston to enable through services to Plymouth. On 4 February 2014, during a period of severe weather marked by high winds and powerful waves, the sea wall at Dawlish was breached, resulting in the collapse of approximately 40 metres (130 ft) of the structure and the erosion of supporting ballast beneath the adjacent railway track. This incident led to the closure of the main line along the south coast of Devon. Emergency repairs were undertaken by Network Rail, and the line was subsequently reopened on 4 April 2014. In response to the widespread disruption caused by storm damage to the coastal route at Dawlish, Network Rail has since evaluated the feasibility of restoring the inland route between Tavistock and Okehampton, and onward to Exeter, as a strategic alternative to enhance network resilience.

Plymouth has around 150 churches, including the Roman Catholic Cathedral of St Mary and St Boniface in Stonehouse, consecrated in 1858. The city's oldest place of worship is St Andrew's Church, an Anglican parish church situated at the top of Royal Parade. As the largest parish church in Devon, it has served as a site of Christian worship since at least AD 800. Plymouth is also home to five Baptist churches, more than twenty Methodist chapels, and thirteen Roman Catholic churches. In 1831, the first Brethren assembly in England—part of a conservative, non-denominational Evangelical movement—was established in the city. This led to the movement being commonly known as the Plymouth Brethren, although its origins were not specifically local.

According to the 2011 census, 58.1% of the population identified as at least nominally Christian, and 0.8% identified as Muslim, with all other religious groups each accounting for less than 0.5%. The proportion of people reporting no religion was 32.9%, exceeding the national average of 24.7%. A further 7.1% did not state a religious affiliation. Compared to the 2001 census, the number of Christians and Jews declined by 16% and 7% respectively, while adherents of all other religions increased, and the non-religious population nearly doubled.

Union Street, constructed in 1815, lies at the heart of Plymouth's historical and cultural landscape. Known historically as the "servicemen's playground," it served as a primary destination for Royal Navy sailors seeking entertainment. By the 1930s, the street hosted around 30 pubs and attracted notable performers such as Charlie Chaplin, who performed at the New Palace Theatre. Today, Union Street remains Plymouth's principal late-night entertainment district, though it is frequently associated with public order issues during closing times.

Outdoor events and festivals are regularly held in the area, including the annual British Firework Championships in August, which draws tens of thousands of spectators along the waterfront. In August 2006, the world record for the largest number of simultaneous fireworks was broken by Roy Lowry of the University of Plymouth over Plymouth Sound. Since 1992, *Music of the Night* has been performed at the Royal Citadel by the 29 Commando Regiment Royal Artillery alongside local performers to raise funds for local and military charities.

The city's main theatres include the Theatre Royal, with a capacity of 1,315, the Drum Theatre, which seats 200, and The TR2, a production and creative learning centre. Plymouth Pavilions serves as a multi-purpose venue hosting music concerts, basketball matches, and stand-up comedy performances. The city has three cinemas: Reel Cinema at Derrys Cross, Plymouth Arts Centre on Looe Street, and a Vue cinema located at Barbican Leisure Park. The Plymouth City Museum and Art Gallery, operated by Plymouth City Council, offers free admission and features six galleries. The Plymouth Athenaeum, a society dedicated to advancing knowledge in science, technology, literature, and art, maintains a library specializing in local interests. It also housed a theatre from 1961 to 2009.

Plymouth serves as the regional television centre for BBC South West. A team of journalists is based in the city for ITV West Country, following the merger with ITV West that led to the closure of ITV Westcountry on 16 February 2009. The city's primary local newspapers are *The Herald* and the *Western Morning News*. Key local radio stations include Radio Plymouth, BBC Radio Devon, Heart South West, and Pirate FM.

Plymouth is home to Plymouth Argyle F.C., a professional football club competing in EFL League Two, the fourth tier of the English football league system. The team plays its home matches at Home Park, a stadium located in Central Park. The club's nickname, "The Pilgrims," references the group of English nonconformists who departed from Plymouth for the New World aboard the *Mayflower* in 1620. In addition to Plymouth Argyle, the city hosts four Non-League football clubs: Plymouth Parkway F.C., which plays at Bolitho Park; Elburton Villa F.C., based at Haye Road; Vospers Oak Villa F.C., located at Weston Mill; and Plymstock United F.C., which plays at Deans Cross. All four clubs compete in the South West Peninsula League.

Other sports clubs in Plymouth include Plymouth Albion R.F.C. and the Plymouth Raiders basketball team. Plymouth Albion Rugby Football Club, founded in 1875, is a rugby union club currently competing in the third tier of professional English rugby; they play their home matches at Brickfields. The Plymouth Raiders compete in the British Basketball League, the top division of British basketball, and play at the Plymouth Pavilions entertainment complex; the club was established in 1983. Plymouth Cricket Club was formed in 1843, with its current first team playing in the Devon Premier League. The Plymouth Devils are a speedway team that competes in the British Premier League. Plymouth was formerly home to an American football team, the Plymouth Admirals, who were active until 2010. The city also hosts Plymouth Marjons Hockey Club, whose men's first team competed in the National League during the most recent season.

Plymouth is a prominent centre for water sports, particularly scuba diving and sailing. The Port of Plymouth Regatta, one of the oldest regattas in the world, has been held annually since 1823. In September 2011, Plymouth hosted the America's Cup World Series for nine days.

Since 1973, Plymouth's water supply has been managed by South West Water. Prior to this, the Plymouth County Borough Corporation was responsible for supplying water to the area. Before the 19th century, two leats were constructed to provide drinking water to the town, both transporting water from Dartmoor. The first of these, known as Plymouth Leat or Drake's Leat, was completed on 24 April 1591 and was designed to channel water from the River Meavy. The second, the Devonport Leat, was built to supply fresh water to the growing town of Devonport and its expanding dockyard. It drew water from three rivers on Dartmoor: the West Dart, the Cowsic, and the Blackabrook. Although it appears to have begun carrying water as early as 1797, the leat was officially completed in 1801. Originally intended to deliver water directly to Devonport, the course was later modified and shortened; today, it supplies water to Burrator Reservoir. Located approximately 5 miles (8 km) north of Plymouth, Burrator Reservoir was constructed in 1898 and expanded in 1928, and now serves as a primary source for the city's water supply.

Plymouth City Council is responsible for waste management throughout the city, while South West Water manages sewerage services. Electricity in Plymouth is supplied through the National Grid and distributed locally by Western Power Distribution. On the outskirts of Plympton lies the Langage Power Station, a combined cycle gas-powered facility that began generating electricity for the city at the end of 2009.

Her Majesty's Courts Service operates a Magistrates' Court and a Combined Crown and County Court in Plymouth. The Plymouth Borough Police, established in 1836, was later integrated into the Devon and Cornwall Constabulary. Police stations are located at Charles Cross and Crownhill, the latter serving as the divisional headquarters, with additional smaller stations in Plympton and Plymstock. The city hosts one of the regional divisional offices of the Devon and Cornwall Area Crown Prosecution Service. Plymouth is served by five fire stations situated in Camel's Head, Crownhill, Greenbank, Plympton, and Plymstock, all part of the Devon and Somerset Fire and Rescue Service. The Royal National Lifeboat Institution maintains a presence at Millbay Docks, operating both an Atlantic 85-class and a Severn-class lifeboat.

Plymouth is served by the Plymouth Hospitals NHS Trust, with the city's primary NHS hospital being Derriford Hospital, located approximately 4 miles (6 km) north of the city centre. The Royal Eye Infirmary is situated within Derriford Hospital. Emergency medical services are provided by the South Western Ambulance Service NHS Foundation Trust, which operates across Plymouth and the wider south-west region; the trust's headquarters are based in Exeter.

Ford Park Cemetery, a mid-19th-century burial ground, was reopened in 2007 by a successful trust. The City Council operates two large early 20th-century cemeteries at Weston Mill and Efford, each equipped with crematoria and chapels. Additionally, there is a privately owned cemetery on the outskirts of the city, Drake Memorial Park, where graves are not marked with headstones but instead by brass plaques set into the ground.

After the English Civil War, the Royal Citadel was constructed in 1666 on the eastern end of Plymouth Hoe to defend the port from naval attacks, suppress Parliamentary sympathies in Plymouth, and serve as a military training facility. Guided tours are available during the summer months. Further west stands Smeaton's Tower, originally built in 1759 as a lighthouse on rocks located 14 miles (23 km) offshore. It was dismantled and subsequently rebuilt—its upper two-thirds reconstructed on Plymouth Hoe—in 1877. The tower is open to the public, offering panoramic views of Plymouth Sound and the city from its lantern room. Plymouth contains 20 war memorials, nine of which are located on The Hoe, including the Plymouth Naval Memorial, which commemorates those lost in the First and Second World Wars, and the Armada Memorial, erected to mark the defeat of the Spanish Armada.

The early port settlement of Plymouth, originally known as "Sutton," corresponds to the present-day Barbican area and features 100 listed buildings, along with the highest concentration of cobbled streets in Britain. The Pilgrim Fathers departed for the New World in 1620 from near the Mayflower Steps, a commemorative site located on Sutton Pool. Adjacent to the pool is the National Marine Aquarium, which houses 400 marine species and contains the deepest aquarium tank in the United Kingdom.
Located on the northern outskirts of the city, Crownhill Fort is a well-preserved example of a "Palmerston's Folly." Owned by the Landmark Trust, it is open to the public.

To the west of the city lies Devonport, one of Plymouth's historic districts. As part of a millennium regeneration initiative, the Devonport Heritage Trail was established, featuring more than 70 waymarkers that delineate the route and highlight points of historical interest.

Plymouth is frequently used as a base for visitors exploring Dartmoor, the Tamar Valley, and the beaches of south-east Cornwall. Nearby attractions include the coastal villages of Kingsand and Cawsand, as well as Whitsand Bay, all of which are popular with tourists.

The Roland Levinsky Building, a prominent landmark of the University of Plymouth, is situated in the city's central quarter. Designed by the renowned architect Henning Larsen, the building was officially opened in 2008 and serves as the home of the University's Faculty of Arts. Widely acclaimed for its architectural significance and aesthetic appeal, it has consistently been regarded as one of the most striking university buildings in the United Kingdom.

People from Plymouth are known as Plymothians, or more informally as Janners. The term "Janner" refers to a person from Devon, originating from "Cousin Jan"—a local variant of the name John—and is used more specifically within naval communities to denote individuals from the Plymouth area.

Sir Francis Drake, the Elizabethan navigator, was born in Tavistock and served as mayor of Plymouth. He became the first Englishman to circumnavigate the globe and earned the nickname *El Draco*—"The Dragon"—from the Spanish due to his numerous raids on their ships. He died of dysentery in 1596 off the coast of Puerto Rico. In 2002, the Ministry of Defence approved a mission to recover his remains and return them to Plymouth. His cousin and contemporary, John Hawkins, was also a native of Plymouth. Sir Joshua Reynolds, painter and founding president of the Royal Academy, was born and educated in Plympton, now part of Plymouth. William Cookworthy, born in Kingsbridge, established a successful porcelain business in the city and was a close associate of John Smeaton, the engineer who designed the Eddystone Lighthouse. On 26 January 1786, Benjamin Robert Haydon, an English painter known for his grand historical works, was born in Plymouth. Dr William Elford Leach FRS, a pioneering naturalist who helped lay the groundwork for Charles Darwin's work, was born at Hoe Gate in 1791.

Robert Falcon Scott and Frank Bickerton, both Antarctic explorers, lived in Plymouth. The city has also been home to artists such as Beryl Cook, whose paintings capture aspects of Plymouth's cultural life, and Robert Lenkiewicz, who explored themes of vagrancy, human sexuality, and suicide in his work and resided in the city from the 1960s until his death in 2002. David McKee, illustrator and creator of the children's series *Mr Benn* and *King Rollo*, was born and raised in South Devon and studied at Plymouth College of Art. Jazz musician John Surman, born in nearby Tavistock, maintains strong ties to the region, reflected in his 2012 album *Saltash Bells*. Keith Rowe, pioneer of the prepared guitar and a key figure in avant-garde music, was born in Plymouth and later co-founded the free improvisation group AMM in London in 1965 and MIMEO in 1997. Musician and film director Cosmo Jarvis has lived in various towns across South Devon and has filmed music videos in and around Plymouth. The city is also associated with actors Sir Donald Sinden and Judi Trott. George Passmore, one half of the Turner Prize-winning artistic duo Gilbert and George, was born in Plymouth, as was Labour politician Michael Foot, whose family resided at Trematon Castle.

Notable athletes from Plymouth include swimmer Sharron Davies, diver Tom Daley, dancer Wayne Sleep, and footballer Trevor Francis. Among other former residents are William Henry Wills, a composer, journalist, and newspaper editor; composer Ron Goodwin; journalist Angela Rippon; and comedian Dawn French. Canadian politician and legal scholar Chris Axworthy was born in Plymouth. American-based actor Donald Moffat, known for portraying American Vice President Lyndon B. Johnson in *The Right Stuff* and fictional President Bennett in *Clear and Present Danger*, was also born in the city.

Heresy refers to a belief or theory that significantly deviates from established doctrines or accepted norms, particularly within a religious context. A person who holds or promotes such beliefs is known as a heretic. Heresy is distinct from apostasy, which involves the formal renunciation of one's religion, principles, or cause, and from blasphemy, which constitutes irreverent speech or actions directed toward God or sacred entities.

The term is commonly used to describe violations of significant religious doctrines, but it also refers to viewpoints that are strongly opposed to widely accepted principles. It is particularly applied in the context of Christianity, Judaism, Islam, and Marxism.

In various historical Christian, Islamic, and Jewish cultures, the expression of beliefs deemed heretical has, at times, been punished not only with excommunication but also with capital punishment, a practice that persists in certain jurisdictions today.

The term *heresy* derives from the Greek αἵρεσις (*hairesis*), originally meaning "choice" or "thing chosen." Over time, it came to denote the "party or school of a man's choice" and referred to the process by which a young person would examine various philosophical doctrines to determine how to live. In modern usage, *heresy* is primarily employed within Christian, Jewish, or Islamic contexts, carrying nuanced meanings in each tradition. The founder or leader of a heretical movement is known as a *heresiarch*, while those who adhere to or propagate heretical beliefs are termed *heretics*. The academic study of heresy is called *heresiology*.

According to Titus 3:10, a divisive individual should be admonished twice before being separated from the community. The Greek term for "divisive person" subsequently became a technical designation in the early Church for a particular kind of heretic—one who sowed discord and promoted schism. In contrast, sound doctrine is so termed not only because it strengthens believers in the faith, but also because it safeguards the community against the corrupting influence of false teachers.

The Church Fathers frequently associated Jews and Judaism with heresy, viewing doctrinal deviations from orthodox Christianity as manifestations of a fundamentally Jewish spirit. Tertullian suggested that Jewish influence was a primary source of Christian heresy, stating, "From the Jew the heretic has accepted guidance in this discussion [that Jesus was not the Christ]." Similarly, Saint Peter of Antioch described Christians who rejected the veneration of religious images as possessing "Jewish minds," thereby equating theological dissent with Jewish belief.

The term "heresy" gained widespread usage through Irenaeus of Lyon in his second-century work *Adversus Haereses* (*Against Heresies*), in which he sought to define and discredit theological opponents within the early Christian community. Irenaeus characterized mainstream Christian beliefs and doctrines as orthodox—derived from the Greek ὀρθός (orthos, meaning "straight") and δόξα (doxa, meaning "belief")—while labeling the teachings of groups such as the Gnostics as heretical. To bolster his position, he emphasized the doctrine of apostolic succession, asserting that authentic Christian teaching was preserved through a continuous line of bishops tracing back to the apostles.

Constantine the Great, who jointly issued the Edict of Milan with Licinius to establish religious toleration for Christianity within the Roman Empire, was the first Roman emperor to be baptized and established significant precedents for imperial religious policy. As emperor, he held the title of Pontifex Maximus, the chief priest of the College of Pontiffs (Collegium Pontificum), which granted him authority over the recognized religious institutions of ancient Rome. In response to the theological controversy sparked by Arius, Constantine convened the First Council of Nicaea in 325 CE—the first of what would later be recognized as the ecumenical councils—and used imperial authority to enforce doctrinal orthodoxy throughout the Christian Church.

The first recorded use of the term in a legal context occurred in AD 380 with the issuance of the Edict of Thessalonica by Theodosius I, which established Christianity as the state religion of the Roman Empire. Prior to this edict, the Church lacked official state support for enforcing doctrinal orthodoxy or addressing what it deemed heresy through formal legal mechanisms. The edict effectively aligned imperial authority with ecclesiastical power, resulting in a convergence of church and state functions. One significant consequence of this integration was the delegation of state enforcement powers to church authorities. This enhancement of ecclesiastical jurisdiction enabled church leaders to impose severe penalties, including capital punishment, on individuals accused of heresy.

Within six years of the official criminalization of heresy by the Roman Emperor, Priscillian, the first Christian heretic known to have been executed, was condemned in 386 by secular Roman authorities on charges of sorcery and put to death along with four or five followers. His accusers, however, were later excommunicated by Ambrose of Milan and Pope Siricius, who, while opposing Priscillian’s teachings, regarded capital punishment as at best inappropriate and typically as unequivocally evil. In the years following the Reformation, various Protestant churches also carried out executions of individuals deemed heretics, including Catholics. The last known execution of a heretic under the authority of the Roman Catholic Church occurred in 1826, when Spanish schoolmaster Cayetano Ripoll was sentenced to death. The total number of individuals executed as heretics by ecclesiastical authorities throughout history remains unknown. One of the earliest recorded uses of the term "heretically" appears in the Nag Hammadi text *Apocalypse of Peter*, which states: "they will cleave to the name of a dead man, thinking that they will become pure. But they will become greatly defiled and fall into the name of error and into the hands of an evil cunning man and a manifold dogma, and they will be ruled heretically."

In the Roman Catholic Church, obstinate and willful manifest heresy is regarded as a spiritual separation from the Church, even prior to the formal act of excommunication. The *Codex Justinianus* (1:5:12) designates as heretics "everyone who is not devoted to the Catholic Church and to our Orthodox holy Faith." Throughout its history, the Church has rigorously opposed Christian movements it deemed heretical. Before the 11th century, such challenges typically arose from individual preachers or localized sects, including Arianism, Pelagianism, Donatism, Marcionism, and Montanism. The westward spread of the nearly Manichaean Paulician movement contributed to the emergence of prominent heresies in Western Europe during the 11th and 12th centuries. One of the earliest was Bogomilism, which arose in the region of modern-day Bosnia—a geographical and religious crossroads between Eastern and Western Christianity. By the 11th century, more organized groups such as the Patarini, the Dulcinians, the Waldensians, and the Cathars began to appear in urban centers across northern Italy, southern France, and Flanders.

In France, the Cathars evolved into a widespread popular movement, and their beliefs began to spread to other regions. In response, the Roman Catholic Church launched the Albigensian Crusade—commonly known as the Cathar Crusade—to eradicate Catharism, which it deemed heretical, in the Languedoc region. The suppression of heresy became a central justification for the establishment of the Inquisition (Inquisitio Haereticae Pravitatis, or "Inquiry into Heretical Perversity") and later played a significant role in fueling the European wars of religion associated with the Protestant Reformation.

Galileo Galilei was brought before the Roman Inquisition on charges of heresy for advocating heliocentric views that contradicted established Church doctrine. He was found "vehemently suspect of heresy" for holding the beliefs that the Sun is stationary at the center of the universe, that the Earth is not at the center and moves, and that it is permissible to consider an opinion as probable even after it has been declared contrary to Holy Scripture. As a result, he was required to "abjure, curse, and detest" these opinions. Although he recanted his views, he was sentenced to lifelong house arrest, during which he remained under confinement until his death.

Pope St. Gregory the Great made numerous polemical statements regarding Judaism and the Jewish people in his writings, reflecting the theological attitudes prevalent in late antiquity. He characterized Jews as adversaries of Christ, asserting that "the more the Holy Spirit fills the world, the more perverse hatred dominates the souls of the Jews." Gregory equated various heresies with Judaism, referring to them collectively as "Jewish" and warning that Judaism could "pollute [Catholics] and deceive them with sacrilegious seduction." This conflation of Jews and heretics was not unique to Gregory but also appeared in several instances within Roman Christian legal and ecclesiastical traditions.

In Eastern Christianity, the term "heresy" most commonly denotes beliefs that were condemned as heretical by the first seven Ecumenical Councils.[citation needed] Following the Great Schism and the Protestant Reformation, various Christian churches have also applied the concept in formal proceedings against individuals and groups deemed to hold doctrines contrary to established orthodoxy. The Eastern Orthodox Church explicitly rejects early Christian heresies, including Arianism, Gnosticism, Origenism, Montanism, the teachings of the Judaizers, Marcionism, Docetism, Adoptionism, Nestorianism, Monophysitism, Monothelitism, and Iconoclasm.

In his 1543 treatise *On the Jews and Their Lies*, Martin Luther, a central figure of the German Reformation, asserts that Jewish history had been "assailed by much heresy" and claims that Christ, as the divine Logos, has eradicated Jewish heresy and continues to do so "as it still does daily before our eyes." He denounces Jewish prayer as "blasphemous" (sic) and false, and characterizes Jews collectively as spiritually "blind" and "surely possessed by all devils." Luther refers to members of the Roman Catholic Church as "papists" and heretics, and expresses particular opposition to the practice of Jewish circumcision, which he views as a spiritual aberration.

In 16th-century England, the European Reformation precipitated a series of executions on charges of heresy. During the thirty-eight-year reign of Henry VIII, approximately sixty individuals—primarily Protestants—were put to death for heresy, while a larger number of Catholics were executed on political grounds, such as treason, for refusing to acknowledge the king's supremacy over the Church of England; among the most notable were Sir Thomas More and Cardinal John Fisher. Under Edward VI, the heresy laws were repealed in 1547 but reinstated in 1554 under Mary I. Nevertheless, two religious radicals were executed during Edward’s reign—one for rejecting the reality of the Incarnation, the other for denying the divinity of Christ. During Mary’s reign, following the restoration of papal jurisdiction, around 290 people were burned at the stake between 1555 and 1558. Upon ascending the throne, Elizabeth I retained the legal concept of heresy in principle, but its application was significantly curtailed by the Act of Supremacy 1559. The roughly 180 Catholics executed during her 45-year reign were condemned not for heresy per se, but for being perceived as members of a subversive fifth column. The last execution in England for beliefs deemed heretical occurred under James VI and I in 1612, though the charge was formally one of blasphemy. In Scotland—which remained an independent kingdom at the time—a later execution took place in 1697 when Thomas Aikenhead was convicted, among other charges, of denying the doctrine of the Trinity.

Another example of the persecution of heretics under Protestant rule was the execution of the Boston martyrs in 1659, 1660, and 1661. These executions were carried out by the Puritan leadership of the Massachusetts Bay Colony, who held both political and ecclesiastical authority at the time. The colonial leaders sought to establish what they envisioned as a "pure" theocratic society, strictly governed by their interpretation of Reformed Protestantism.[citation needed] In this context, the beliefs and practices of the Quakers—members of the Religious Society of Friends—were regarded as heretical and subversive. As a result, the colony enacted laws prohibiting Quaker worship and presence, leading to the arrest, trial, and eventual execution of several individuals. These measures were intended to eliminate what the authorities perceived as dangerous religious dissent.[citation needed] It is also noteworthy that the Eastern Orthodox and Oriental Orthodox Churches have historically regarded Puritan theology itself as heterodox or heretical.

The era of mass persecution and execution of heretics under the banner of Christianity ended in 1826 with the execution of Cayetano Ripoll, the last person condemned as a heretic by the Catholic Inquisition.

Although formal charges of heresy have become less common in modern times compared to earlier periods, they still occur within Christian churches. In Protestant denominations, controversies often center on issues such as modern biblical criticism and theological understandings of the nature of God. Within the Catholic Church, the Congregation for the Doctrine of the Faith evaluates writings for "ambiguities and errors," typically avoiding the explicit use of the term "heresy" while addressing doctrinal concerns.

Due to the modern negative connotations associated with the term "heretic"—such as those linked to the Spanish Inquisition—the word is less frequently used today. The concept of Christian heresy raises broader questions about who holds authority over spiritual truth, a theme explored by Jorge Luis Borges in his short story "The Theologians," included in the collection *Labyrinths*.

Ottoman Sultan Selim I, known as Selim the Grim, regarded the Shia Qizilbash as heretics and is reported to have declared that "the killing of one Shiite brings as much spiritual reward as the killing of seventy Christians."

In some contemporary countries and regions where Sharia law is formally applied, heresy remains a capital offense. A prominent example is the 1989 fatwa issued by the Iranian government, which called for the assassination of author Salman Rushdie and offered a substantial financial reward to anyone who carried it out, following the declaration that his writings constituted heresy.

Orthodox Judaism regards deviations from traditional Jewish principles of faith as heretical. In particular, the more right-wing segments of Orthodox Judaism maintain that any Jew who rejects the literal interpretation of Maimonides' 13 Principles of Faith is considered a heretic. Consequently, most Orthodox authorities view Reform and Reconstructionist Judaism as heretical movements, and regard much of Conservative Judaism as heretical as well. However, the liberal wing of Modern Orthodoxy tends to be more tolerant toward Conservative Judaism, especially its right-leaning elements, due to significant theological and practical commonalities between these branches.

The use of Scientology techniques in a manner differing from L. Ron Hubbard's original teachings is termed "squirreling" within the Church of Scientology and is regarded by adherents as a serious violation akin to high treason. The Religious Technology Center has actively pursued legal action against unauthorized groups that practice or disseminate Scientology teachings outside the official Church structure.

In other contexts, the term "heresy" does not necessarily carry pejorative connotations and may even be used complimentary in environments that value innovation, particularly when describing ideas that fundamentally challenge the status quo within any field of knowledge or practice. The scientist and author Isaac Asimov discussed heresy as an abstract concept in his essay *Forward: The Role of the Heretic*, where he examined religious, political, socioeconomic, and scientific forms of heresy. Asimov categorized scientific heretics into two groups: endoheretics, who arise from within the scientific community, and exoheretics, who originate from outside it. He identified distinguishing characteristics for each group and provided illustrative examples. Asimov argued that established scientific orthodoxy is generally effective at defending itself against endoheretics—through mechanisms such as control over science education, research funding, and publication—but is far less capable of resisting exoheretics. He acknowledged, through historical precedent, that many ideas once deemed heretical have eventually become accepted as orthodox.

Robert T. Bakker, a revisionist paleontologist and author of *The Dinosaur Heresies*, challenged the prevailing orthodoxy in dinosaur science, which he regarded as dogmatic. While expressing respect for past and present dinosaur paleontologists, he criticized the field for insufficiently scrutinizing established views, stating, "I have enormous respect for dinosaur paleontologists past and present. But on average, for the last fifty years, the field hasn't tested dinosaur orthodoxy severely enough" (p. 27). His proposals, including new taxonomic terminology, met resistance from many taxonomists who viewed such changes as potentially destabilizing to the traditional classification system (p. 462). The book significantly influenced public and scientific perceptions of dinosaurs, notably inspiring aspects of *Jurassic Park*. Illustrations by Bakker depict dinosaurs in dynamic, active postures—contrasting sharply with the conventional image of slow, sluggish reptiles. Bakker is considered a prominent example of a recent scientific endoheretic, one who challenges established doctrines from within the scientific community.

Immanuel Velikovsky is an example of a modern scientific outsider who lacked formal scientific credentials and did not publish in peer-reviewed scientific journals. Although his specific claims have been widely rejected by the scientific community, the broader concept of catastrophic change—such as extinction events and the theory of punctuated equilibrium—has gained increasing acceptance in recent decades.

The term *heresy* is often employed as an ideological label for contemporary figures, as heresy inherently implies a contrast with an established orthodoxy. Modern usages—such as "Wall Street heresy," "Democratic heresy," or "Republican heresy"—are typically metaphorical and frequently carry an implicit comparison between doctrinal conformity in religious contexts and perceived orthodoxy in fields like geology, biology, or politics. These extended metaphorical applications highlight both the divergence of an individual's views from mainstream consensus and the audacity involved in articulating such dissenting perspectives.

The Warsaw Pact, formally known as the Treaty of Friendship, Cooperation, and Mutual Assistance (and occasionally referred to informally as WarPac, by analogy with NATO), was a collective defense treaty established during the Cold War between the Soviet Union and seven of its satellite states in Central and Eastern Europe. Functioning as the military counterpart to the Council for Mutual Economic Assistance (Comecon)—the economic organization coordinating communist states in the region—the pact was formed in response to the integration of West Germany into NATO under the Paris Agreements of 1954, which came into effect in 1955. While officially framed as a defensive alliance to counter perceived Western threats, the Warsaw Pact also served as a mechanism for the Soviet Union to consolidate and maintain political and military control over its allies in the region.

Instead, their rivalry was primarily ideological. Both organizations spurred the expansion and integration of military forces within their respective geopolitical blocs. The most significant military action undertaken by the Warsaw Pact was the 1968 invasion of Czechoslovakia, which involved all member states except Romania and Albania. The Pact effectively ceased to function as the Revolutions of 1989 swept across Eastern Europe, beginning with the rise of the Solidarity movement in Poland and its electoral victory in June 1989.

The Warsaw Treaty Organization had a dual structure: the Political Consultative Committee was responsible for political affairs, while the Combined Command of Pact Armed Forces oversaw multinational military forces, with its headquarters located in Warsaw, Poland. The Supreme Commander of the Unified Armed Forces of the Warsaw Treaty Organization, who exercised command and control over the military forces of all member states, concurrently held the position of First Deputy Minister of Defense of the Soviet Union. Similarly, the Chief of the Combined Staff of the Unified Armed Forces of the Warsaw Treaty Organization also served as the First Deputy Chief of the General Staff of the Soviet Armed Forces. As a result, despite its formal status as an international collective security alliance, the organization was effectively dominated by the Soviet Union.

The formation of the Warsaw Pact was primarily motivated by the Soviet Union's objective to exert political and military dominance over Central and Eastern Europe, driven by both ideological and geostrategic considerations. Ideologically, the Soviet Union positioned itself as the authoritative interpreter of socialism and communism, asserting its leadership over the international socialist movement. This self-appointed role justified intervention in any socialist state perceived to be deviating from orthodox communist principles or undermining the authority of its ruling Communist Party—a policy later formalized as the Brezhnev Doctrine. From a geostrategic perspective, the Soviet Union sought to establish a buffer zone against potential aggression from Western Europe, ensuring the security of its borders by maintaining strong influence over neighboring states.

Prior to the establishment of the Warsaw Pact, Czechoslovak leadership, concerned about the prospect of a rearmed Germany, sought to establish a security alliance with East Germany and Poland. These nations strongly opposed the remilitarization of West Germany. The Warsaw Pact was primarily formed in response to the integration of West Germany into NATO and its subsequent rearmament. Soviet leaders, along with many European countries on both sides of the Iron Curtain, viewed the resurgence of German military power as a direct threat, with memories of German militarism still fresh among Soviet and Eastern European populations. Given that the Soviet Union already maintained bilateral treaties with all of its Eastern European satellite states, the Pact was long regarded as redundant. Due to its hasty formation, NATO officials dismissed it as a "cardboard castle." Earlier, in March 1954, the USSR—motivated by fears of renewed German militarism in West Germany—had formally requested admission to NATO.

The Soviet Union's proposal to join NATO emerged in the aftermath of the Berlin Conference held between January and February 1954. During the conference, Soviet Foreign Minister Vyacheslav Molotov put forward a series of proposals calling for German reunification and the establishment of a pan-German government through free elections, contingent upon the withdrawal of all foreign military forces from Germany and the country's adoption of neutrality. These proposals were rejected by the foreign ministers of the United States, the United Kingdom, and France—John Foster Dulles, Anthony Eden, and Georges Bidault, respectively.

Calls for German reunification were not new. As early as 20 March 1952, the so-called "Stalin Note" had initiated diplomatic discussions proposing the reunification of East and West Germany under conditions of neutrality and the withdrawal of occupying forces. However, the Western powers—particularly the United States, the United Kingdom, and France—rejected the initiative, insisting that a unified Germany remain non-neutral and retain the right to join the European Defence Community (EDC) and rearm. In Paris, James C. Dunn of the United States, in discussions with Eden, Konrad Adenauer of West Germany, and Robert Schuman of France, emphasized that the primary objective should be to avoid substantive negotiations with the Soviet Union and instead accelerate progress on establishing the European Defence Community.

Historian John Lewis Gaddis has observed that Western capitals exhibited little interest in exploring the Soviet overtures seriously. According to historian Rolf Steininger, Chancellor Konrad Adenauer was deeply skeptical of neutrality, believing it would inevitably lead to Soviet domination—"neutralization means sovietization." Adenauer also harbored concerns that German reunification could undermine the political dominance of his Christian Democratic Union (CDU) in the Bundestag, particularly given the potential electoral strength of leftist parties in the Soviet-occupied East.

One month later, the proposed European Treaty was rejected not only by supporters of the European Defense Community (EDC) but also by Western opponents of the EDC—such as French Gaullist leader Georges Bidault (often confused with Palewski in some accounts)—who regarded it as "unacceptable in its present form because it excludes the USA from participation in the collective security system in Europe." In response, the Soviet Union submitted a new proposal to the governments of the United States, the United Kingdom, and France, offering to accept American participation in the proposed General European Agreement. Furthermore, in an effort to counter Western objections that the Soviet initiative was "directed against the North Atlantic Pact and its liquidation," the USSR declared its "readiness to examine jointly with other interested parties the question of the participation of the USSR in the North Atlantic bloc," while clarifying that "the admittance of the USA into the General European Agreement should not be conditional on the three Western powers agreeing to the USSR joining the North Atlantic Pact."

All proposals, including the Soviet Union's request to join NATO, were swiftly rejected by the governments of the United Kingdom, the United States, and France. A notable stance was that of British General Hastings Ismay, a proponent of NATO expansion, who asserted that NATO "must grow until the whole free world gets under one umbrella." Regarding the USSR's 1954 application to join the alliance, Ismay remarked that "the Soviet request to join NATO is like an unrepentant burglar requesting to join the police force," underscoring the deep ideological divide and mutual distrust between the Western bloc and the Soviet Union during the Cold War.

In April 1954, Konrad Adenauer made his first visit to the United States, where he met with Richard Nixon, Dwight D. Eisenhower, and John Foster Dulles. Although the ratification of the European Defense Community (EDC) was pending, U.S. officials informed Adenauer that the EDC would need to be integrated within the framework of NATO.

Memories of the Nazi occupation remained vivid, and French opposition to German rearmament persisted. On 30 August 1954, the French National Assembly rejected the European Defence Community (EDC) treaty, leading to its collapse and thwarting a key objective of U.S. policy in Europe: the integration of West Germany into the Western military alliance. In response, the U.S. Department of State began developing alternative strategies. These included inviting West Germany to join NATO directly or, should France continue to block such efforts, pursuing measures to achieve German rearmament outside the NATO framework.

On 23 October 1954—just nine years after the Allied victory over Nazi Germany, which ended World War II in Europe—the accession of the Federal Republic of Germany to the North Atlantic Treaty was formally decided. The integration of West Germany into the alliance, which took effect on 9 May 1955, was described by Halvard Lange, Norway's Minister of Foreign Affairs at the time, as "a decisive turning point in the history of our continent." In November 1954, the Soviet Union proposed a new European Security Treaty in a final effort to prevent the remilitarization of West Germany and its alignment against Soviet interests, but the proposal was unsuccessful.

On 14 May 1955, the Soviet Union and seven other European countries established the Warsaw Pact, reaffirming their commitment to a system of European collective security based on the participation of all European states regardless of their social and political systems. This treaty was formed in response to the integration of the Federal Republic of Germany into the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO). The participating states declared that "a remilitarized Western Germany and the integration of the latter in the North-Atlantic bloc [...] increase the danger of another war and constitute a threat to the national security of the peace-loving states; [...] in these circumstances, the peace-loving European states must take the necessary measures to safeguard their security."

One of the founding members of the Warsaw Pact, East Germany was permitted by the Soviet Union to rearm, leading to the establishment of the National People's Army as the country's armed forces in response to the rearmament of West Germany.

The eight member states of the Warsaw Pact committed to the collective defense of any member subjected to armed attack.
