In domestic dogs, sexual maturity begins around six to twelve months for both males and females, although it may be delayed until two years of age in some large breeds. This is when female dogs will experience their first estrus cycle. They repeat these cycles every six months, during which the body prepares for pregnancy. At the peak of the cycle, females enter estrus and become mentally and physically receptive to mating. Since eggs remain viable and fertilizable for up to a week after ovulation, it is possible for a female to mate with multiple males.

Dogs typically give birth approximately 58 to 68 days after fertilization, averaging around 63 days, although the gestation period can vary. An average litter consists of about six puppies, but this number can vary significantly depending on the dog's breed. Generally, toy breeds give birth to one to four puppies per litter, while much larger breeds can have up to an average of twelve puppies.

Sterilization is a procedure typically performed to eliminate animals' reproductive ability and reduce their sexual urges by removing the testicles of males or the ovaries and uterus of females. Due to the excessive increase in the dog population in some countries, many animal control organizations, such as the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals (ASPCA), recommend sterilizing dogs not intended for further breeding to prevent unwanted litters and avoid the need for euthanasia in the future.

Neutering reduces problems caused by hypersexuality, especially in male dogs. In spayed female dogs, the likelihood of developing certain types of cancer affecting the mammary glands, ovaries, and other reproductive organs is lower. However, neutering increases the risk of urinary incontinence in female dogs and prostate cancer in males; it also raises the risk of osteosarcoma, hemangiosarcoma, cruciate ligament tears, obesity, and diabetes in both sexes.

According to tradition, they add the title "Cardinal" (abbreviated as Card.) after personal names and before surnames, for example, "John Cardinal Doe" or in Latin "Ioannes Cardinalis Cognomen." Some writers, such as James-Charles Noonan, believe that the form used in signatures when referring to a cardinal should be used in English. Official sources like the Archdiocese of Milwaukee and the Catholic News Agency state that the correct form for referring to a cardinal in English is usually "Cardinal [First Name] [Last Name]." This rule is also noted in style guides not related to the Catholic Church. This style is also commonly found on the websites of the Vatican and bishops' conferences. When Eastern patriarchs are elevated to the rank of cardinal, they usually use "Cardinal of the Holy Church" (Sanctae Ecclesiae Cardinalis) as their full title, which may be because they do not belong to the Roman clergy.

In Latin, the order of Cardinal [Last Name]’s [First Name] is used when the cardinal protodeacon announces the election of a new pope: “Annuntio vobis gaudium magnum; habemus Papam: Eminentissimum ac Reverendissimum Dominum, Dominum (First Name) Sanctae Romanae Ecclesiae Cardinalem (Last Name), ...” (which means: “I announce to you a great joy; we have a pope: the Most Eminent and Most Reverend Lord, Lord (First Name) Cardinal (Last Name) of the Holy Roman Church, ...”) This assumes that the new pope was a cardinal before becoming pope; the last election of a non-cardinal becoming pope was in 1378.

Although some current bishops of dioceses are regularly promoted to cardinals, certain countries have the right through agreements to have at least one cardinal (usually by elevating their archbishop to the cardinalate), no diocese has actual cardinal rights, even if its bishop is a metropolitan.

Cardinal (a bishop of the rank of cardinal) is one of the highest-ranking bishops in the Catholic Church. Although most cardinals are also bishops in modern times, the term "cardinal" specifically refers to those who serve as titular bishops of "suburban" dioceses.

In the early days, the privilege of electing the pope was not limited to cardinals; for centuries, those elected were often priests from Rome, rather than bishops from elsewhere. To maintain the apostolic succession, the person must already be a bishop to be consecrated as pope. The rule still is that if the elected pope is not yet a bishop, he will be consecrated by the dean of the College of Cardinals, who is the cardinal of Ostia.

There are seven suburban dioceses: Ostia, Albano, Porto and Santa Rufina, Palestrina, Sabina and Mentana, Frascati, and Velletri. Velletri was merged with Ostia from 1150 until 1914, when Pope Pius X separated them again, but stipulated that whichever cardinal becomes the dean of the College of Cardinals would retain the suburban diocese he already held, and would add the diocese of Ostia to it, thus there are still only six cardinal bishops.

Since 1962, the relationship between the cardinal and the archdiocese has been merely nominal, with no real management authority. Each archdiocese has its own bishop, except for Ostia, which is administered by a papal delegate appointed by the cardinal protector of the Diocese of Rome.

Cardinals (Latin: sanctae romanae ecclesiae cardinalis, literally meaning "Cardinal of the Holy Roman Church") are senior religious leaders and princes of the church, who are typically (and now, in the case of cardinals appointed within the voting age) bishops who have been ordained in the Catholic Church. The cardinals of the church are collectively referred to as the College of Cardinals. The responsibilities of cardinals include attending meetings of the College of Cardinals and providing service to the Pope either individually or in groups as requested. Most cardinals also have additional responsibilities, such as leading a diocese or archdiocese, or managing a department of the Roman Catholic Church. The primary duty of a cardinal is to elect the Pope when there is a vacancy in the papacy. During the vacancy between the death or resignation of the Pope and the election of his successor, the daily governance of the Holy See is held by the College of Cardinals. The right to enter the secret conclave to elect the Pope is limited to those who are under 80 years old on the day the vacancy occurs.

Cardinals enjoy "judicial privilege" in canon law (that is, exemption from being judged by ordinary ecclesiastical courts): only the Pope has the authority to adjudicate their cases within the church's jurisdiction (involving spiritual matters or matters related to the spiritual, or concerning violations of church law and any issues containing elements of sin, where responsibility must be determined and appropriate ecclesiastical penalties imposed). The Pope can decide the case himself or delegate the decision to a court, usually a court of the Roman Curia or a diocese. Without such a delegation, no ecclesiastical court, even the Roman Rota, has the authority to hear ecclesiastical law cases against cardinals. However, cardinals, like others, remain subject to civil and criminal law.

To symbolize the connection with the Pope, the Pope gives each new cardinal a gold ring, which Catholic faithful kiss when greeting the cardinal (similar to the bishop's episcopal ring). The Pope chooses the design on the outside of the ring: during the papacy of Benedict XVI, the outside features a modern depiction of Jesus being crucified, with Mary and John on either side. The inside of the ring contains the Pope's coat of arms.

In the past, when the pope appointed new cardinals at consistory meetings, he would bestow upon them a wide-brimmed hat known as the "galero." This custom was discontinued in 1969, and the current vesting ceremony uses a red biretta. However, the red galero still appears in the coats of arms of cardinals. Cardinals have the right to hang the galero in their cathedrals, and when a cardinal passes away, the galero is hung above his tomb. Some cardinals still make galeros, although it is not an official part of their attire.

Eastern Catholic Cardinals continue to wear their regular vestments in accordance with their liturgical traditions, although some may line their robes with scarlet and wear scarlet sashes, or in some cases, wear Eastern-style robes completely made of scarlet.

When wearing choir robes, Cardinals in the Latin Rite don scarlet garments—this blood-red color symbolizes the Cardinals' willingness to sacrifice for their faith. In addition to the always white zucchetto, the scarlet garments include a long robe, a short cape, and a small round hat (typically in scarlet). The Cardinals' small round hat is unique not only for its scarlet color but also because its top lacks the pom-pom or tassel commonly found on other high-ranking clerics' hats. Until the 1460s, Cardinals usually wore purple or blue capes unless granted the privilege to wear red while performing papal duties. Their regular robes are black but have scarlet trim and a scarlet belt. Occasionally, a Cardinal may wear a scarlet ferrarello, a shoulder cape that ties in a bow with narrow strips of fabric at the neck, with no "decorations" or trim on the cape. It is precisely because of the scarlet color of the Cardinals' attire that the similarly named birds are known for it.

If circumstances change such that the Pope believes a public appointment is safe, he can do so at any time. The relevant cardinal is on equal footing in the order of precedence with others who were elevated to the rank of cardinal at the time of his secret appointment. If the Pope dies before revealing the identity of the secret cardinal, the appointment of that cardinal will be null and void.

During the Western Schism, many cardinals were appointed by popes competing for the papal office. Starting from the reign of Pope Martin V, the appointments of cardinals were not publicly announced until later, referred to as "creati et reservati in pectore."

At different times, some cardinals only received the first tonsure and minor orders, but had not yet been ordained as deacons or priests. Although they were clergy, they were inaccurately referred to as "lay cardinals" and were allowed to marry. Theodor Melter was one of the last lay cardinals. When he died in 1899, he was the last living cardinal who had not been at least ordained as a priest. With the revision of the Code of Canon Law promulgated by Pope Benedict XV in 1917, only those already ordained as priests or bishops could be appointed as cardinals. Starting from the time of Pope John XXIII, priests appointed as cardinals must be ordained as bishops, unless they receive a dispensation.

A cardinal who is not a bishop still has the right to wear the episcopal vestments and other pontifical (episcopal insignia: mitre, crosier, zucchetto, pectoral cross, and ring). Even though he is not a bishop, every cardinal has both actual and honorary precedence over non-cardinal patriarchs as well as over archbishops and bishops who are not cardinals; however, he cannot exercise the functions exclusively reserved for bishops, such as ordination. The prominent priests who were not consecrated as bishops since 1962 when they were elevated to the cardinalate were over 80 years old or close to it, and thus no cardinal who is not a bishop has participated in the recent papal conclaves.

Until 1917, it was possible for someone who was not a priest but only in lower orders to become a cardinal (see "lay cardinals" below), but they were only admitted to the rank of cardinal deacons. For example, Reginald Pole was a cardinal for 18 years in the 16th century before being ordained a priest. In 1917, it was established that all cardinals, even cardinal deacons, must be priests, and in 1962, Pope John XXIII set the norm that all cardinals should be ordained as bishops, even if they are only priests at the time of their appointment. As a result of these two changes, Canon 351 of the 1983 Code of Canon Law requires that a cardinal must be at least of the rank of priest at the time of his appointment and that those who are not yet bishops must receive episcopal ordination. Several cardinals who were over 80 years old or close to it at the time of their appointment have received a dispensation from the rule that they must be bishops. All of these were appointed as cardinal deacons, but one of them, Roberto Tucci, lived long enough to exercise the right of option and be promoted to the rank of cardinal priest.

The Cardinal Chamberlain of the Holy Roman Church, supported by the Vice Chamberlain and the other prelates of the office known as the Apostolic Chamber, has functions that are essentially limited to a period of sede vacante of the papacy. He is to gather information on the financial situation of all administrations that depend on the Holy See and present the results to the College of Cardinals as they gather for the papal conclave.

The Cardinal Protodeacon, the highest-ranking Cardinal Deacon according to the order of appointment to the College of Cardinals, has the privilege of announcing the election and name of a new pope (after his consecration as a bishop) from the central balcony of St. Peter's Basilica in the Vatican City State. In the past, the Protodeacon also had the honor of bestowing the pallium on the new pope during papal coronations and crowning him with the papal tiara. However, Pope John Paul I chose not to be crowned in 1978 and opted for a simpler papal inauguration ceremony, and his three successors followed this example. As a result, the privilege of the Cardinal Protodeacon to crown a new pope has effectively ceased, although it could be revived if a future pope were to restore a coronation ceremony. Nevertheless, the Protodeacon still has the privilege of bestowing the pallium on a new pope during his papal inauguration. "In the name of the Roman Pontiff, he also bestows the pallium on metropolitans or gives the pallium to their representatives." The current Cardinal Protodeacon is Renato Raffaele Martino.

If they do not celebrate the Mass but still perform a liturgical function, such as the semi-annual Urbi et Orbi papal blessing, some papal masses, and some events at ecumenical councils, cardinal deacons can be recognized by the dalmatics they wear along with the simple white mitre (so-called mitra simplex).

Since 2005, there have been over 50 churches recognized as cardinal deaconates, although there were only 30 cardinals of the diaconate order. Cardinal deacons have long enjoyed the right, after 10 years as cardinal deacons, to "choose for the order of cardinal priests" (optation). In this elevation, they can take on a free "title" (a church assigned to a cardinal priest, such as the church in Rome with which he is associated) or their deaconal church can be temporarily elevated to the "title" of a cardinal priest for this occasion. Upon elevation to cardinal priests, they take their rank according to the day they were first appointed as cardinal deacons (and thus rank above cardinal priests who were elevated to the college after them, regardless of the order).

Cardinals who are raised to the diaconal orders are primarily officials of the Roman Curia who hold various offices in the church administration. Their number and influence have varied over the years. While the group was historically predominantly Italian, it has become more international in recent years. In 1939, about half were Italian, but that number was reduced to a third by 1994. Their influence in the election of the Pope was considered important; they are better informed and networked than the dispersed cardinals, but their degree of unity has varied. Under the decree of Pope Sixtus V in 1587, which established the maximum size of the College of Cardinals, there were 14 cardinal deacons. Later, that number was increased. Even in 1939, nearly half of the cardinals were members of the Curia. Pius XII reduced this percentage to 24 percent. John XXIII brought it back to 37 percent, but Paul VI lowered it to 27 percent, which John Paul II has maintained.

The cardinal deacons originally come from the seven deacons of the papal household and the seven deacons who oversaw the church's works in the neighborhoods of Rome during the early Middle Ages, when the church administration effectively was the government of Rome and provided all social services. The cardinal deacons are granted a title for one of these diaconates.

The cardinal deacons are the lowest-ranked cardinals. Cardinals who are elevated to the diaconate are either officials of the Roman Curia or priests who are elevated after their 80th birthday. However, bishops with diocesan responsibilities are appointed as cardinal priests.

The cardinal, who is the longest-serving member of the Order of Cardinal Priests, holds the title of Cardinal Protopriest. He had certain ceremonial duties in the conclave, which were effectively discontinued as he would generally have already reached the age of 80, at which cardinals are excluded from the conclave. The current Cardinal Protopriest is Paulo Evaristo Arns from Brazil.

The Dean of the College of Cardinals, or Cardinal Dean, is the primus inter pares of the College of Cardinals, elected by the Cardinal Bishops who hold suburban sees from among themselves, although this election must be approved by the Pope. Previously, the office of the Dean belonged by right to the longest-serving Cardinal Bishop.

In 1965, Pope Paul VI decreed in his Motu Proprio Ad Purpuratorum Patrum that patriarchs of the Eastern Catholic Churches who were appointed as cardinals (i.e., patriarch cardinals) would also be part of the episcopal office and would rank after the six cardinal bishops of the suburbicarian sees (who had been relieved of direct responsibilities for these sees three years earlier by Pope John XXIII). Patriarch cardinals do not receive a title of a suburbicarian see and therefore cannot elect or become dean. Currently, there are three Eastern patriarchs who are cardinal bishops:

The cardinal priests are the most numerous of the three orders of cardinals in the Catholic Church; they rank above the cardinal deacons and below the cardinal bishops. Those who are appointed as cardinal priests today are usually bishops of important dioceses worldwide, although some hold curial positions.

In modern times, the name "cardinal priest" is interpreted as a cardinal who belongs to the order of priests. However, originally this referred to certain key priests of important churches in the Diocese of Rome, who were recognized as the cardinal priests, the important priests chosen by the pope to advise him in his duties as bishop of Rome (the Latin word "cardo" means "hinge"). Certain clerics in many dioceses at that time, not just in Rome, were regarded as key personnel – the term gradually became exclusive to Rome to designate those entrusted with the election of the bishop of Rome, the pope.

While the cardinalate has long been extended beyond the Roman pastoral clergy and the Roman Curia, each cardinal priest has a titular church in Rome, even if they may be bishops or archbishops elsewhere, just as cardinal bishops are assigned one of the suburbicarian dioceses around Rome. Pope Paul VI abolished all administrative rights that cardinals had concerning their titular churches, although the name and coat of arms of the cardinal continue to be displayed in the church, and they are expected to celebrate Mass and preach there when it is convenient for them to be in Rome.

While the number of cardinals was low from the time of the Roman Empire until the Renaissance, often smaller than the number of recognized churches that had the right to a cardinal priest, the college expanded significantly in the 16th century. In 1587, Pope Sixtus V attempted to stop this growth by setting the maximum size of the college at 70, including 50 cardinal priests, about twice the historical number. This limit was maintained until 1958, and the list of titular churches was changed only in rare cases, usually when a building fell into disrepair. When Pope John XXIII abolished the limit, he began adding new churches to the list, a practice also followed by Pope Paul VI and John Paul II. Today, there are almost 150 titular churches from over 300 churches in Rome.

Iranian languages or Iranian tongues form a branch of the Indo-Iranian languages, which in turn are a branch of the Indo-European language family. Speakers of Iranian languages are known as Iranian peoples. Historical Iranian languages are grouped into three stages: Old Iranian (up to 400 BC), Middle Iranian (400 BC – 900 AD), and New Iranian (since 900 AD). Among the ancient Iranian languages, those that are best understood and documented are Old Persian (a language of Achaemenid Iran) and Avestan (the language of the Avesta). Middle Iranian languages included Middle Persian (a language of Sasanian Iran), Parthian, and Bactrian.

As of 2008, it was estimated that there were between 150 and 200 million native speakers of Iranian languages. Ethnologue estimates that there are 86 Iranian languages, the largest among them being Persian, Pashto, Kurdish, and Balochi.
The Iranian term applies to any language that descends from the ancestral Proto-Iranian language. Iranian derives from the Persian and Sanskrit word Arya.

All Iranian languages descend from a common ancestor, Proto-Iranian. In turn, along with Proto-Indo-Aryan and Nuristani languages, Proto-Iranian descends from a common ancestor, Proto-Indo-Iranian. It is believed that Indo-Iranian languages emerged in Central Asia. The Andronovo culture is the proposed candidate for the common Indo-Iranian culture around 2000 BC.

It was located precisely in the western part of Central Asia that borders present-day Russia (and present-day Kazakhstan). It was in relative proximity to other satem ethno-linguistic groups of the Indo-European family, such as Thracian, Balto-Slavic, and others, and to the original homeland of Proto-Indo-European (more specifically, the steppes of southern Russia north of the Caucasus), according to the reconstructed linguistic relationships of Proto-Indo-European.

Proto-Iranian dates from a time after the separation of Proto-Indo-Iranian, or the beginning of the second millennium BCE, when ancient Iranian languages began to dissociate and evolve separately as various Iranian tribes migrated and settled in vast regions of Southeast Europe, the Iranian plateau, and Central Asia.

The multitude of languages and Middle Iranian peoples indicates that a great linguistic diversity must have existed among the ancient speakers of Iranian languages. Among this variety of languages/dialects, only direct evidence of two has survived. They are:

Old Persian is the Old Iranian dialect as it was spoken in the southwest of Iran by the inhabitants of Parsa, who also gave their name to their region and their language. True Old Persian is best attested in one of the three languages of the Behistun inscription, composed around 520 BC, which is the last inscription (and the only inscription of significant length) in which Old Persian is still grammatically correct. Later inscriptions are relatively brief and generally consist of simple copies of words and phrases from earlier inscriptions, often with grammatical errors, suggesting that by the 4th century BC, the transition from Old Persian to Middle Persian was already well advanced, but efforts were still being made to maintain an "ancient" quality for official proclamations.

behdin). The language of the Avesta is subdivided into two dialects, conventionally called "Old Avestan (or 'Gathic')" and "Young Avestan." These terms, dating from the 19th century, are somewhat misleading since "Young Avestan" is not only much more recent than "Old Avestan," but also comes from a different geographical region. The Old Avestan dialect is very archaic and is roughly at the same stage of development as Vedic Sanskrit. In contrast, Young Avestan is roughly at the same linguistic stage as Old Persian, but due to its use as a sacred language, it has retained its "ancient" characteristics long after the ancient Iranian languages gave way to their Middle Iranian stage. Unlike Old Persian, which has Middle Persian as a known successor, Avestan does not have a clearly identifiable Middle Iranian stage (the effects of Middle Iranian are indistinguishable from those due to other causes).

These hypothetical ancient Iranian languages include Carduchi (the hypothetical predecessor of Kurdish) and Old Parthian. Furthermore, the existence of unrecorded languages can sometimes be deduced from the impact they had on neighboring languages. Such transfer is known to have occurred for Old Persian, which has (what is called) a "Median" substrate in part of its vocabulary. Additionally, foreign references to languages can also provide a clue about the existence of otherwise unrecorded languages, for example through toponyms/ethnonyms or in the recording of vocabulary, as Herodotus did for what he called "Scythian."

Conventionally, Iranian languages are grouped into "western" and "eastern" branches. These terms have little significance in relation to ancient Avestan, as this stage of the language may precede the establishment of Iranian peoples into western and eastern groups. Geographical terms also have little significance when applied to the more recent Avestan, as it is also unknown where this dialect (or these dialects) was spoken. It is only certain that Avestan (all forms) and Old Persian are distinct, and since Old Persian is "western," and Avestan was not Old Persian, Avestan has acquired a default attribution of "eastern." The confusion is compounded by the introduction of a western Iranian substrate into later Avestan compositions and writings undertaken in imperial power centers in western Iran (either in the southwest in Persia or in the northwest at Nisa/Parthia and Ecbatana/Media).

What is known in Iranian linguistic history as the "Middle Iranian" era is considered to begin around the 4th century BCE and extend until the 9th century. Linguistically, Middle Iranian languages are conventionally classified into two main groups, Western and Eastern.

The Western family includes the Parthian (Pahlavi Arsacid) and Middle Persian, while Bactrian, Sogdian, Khwarezmian, Saka, and Old Ossetic (Scytho-Sarmatian) fall into the Eastern category. The two languages of the Western group were linguistically very close to each other, but quite distinct from their Eastern counterparts. On the other hand, the Eastern group was an areal entity whose languages maintained some similarity to Avestan. They were inscribed in various alphabets derived from Aramaic which ultimately evolved from the Imperial Aramaic script of the Achaemenids, although Bactrian was written using an adapted Greek script.

Middle Persian (Pahlavi) was the official language under the Sassanian dynasty in Iran. It was in use from the 3rd century AD until the early 10th century. The script used for Middle Persian during this period underwent significant maturation. Middle Persian, Parthian, and Sogdian were also used as literary languages by the Manichaeans, whose texts also survive in various non-Iranian languages, from Latin to Chinese. Manichaean texts were written in a script very similar to the Syriac script.

The Islamic conquest also brought with it the adoption of Arabic script to write Persian and, much later, Kurdish, Pashto, and Balochi. The three were adapted to the script by adding some letters. This development probably occurred sometime in the second half of the 8th century when the ancient Middle Persian script began to decline in use. Arabic script continues to be used in contemporary modern Persian. Tajik script was first Latinized in the 1920s under the then Soviet nationality policy. However, the script was later Cyrillicized in the 1930s by the Soviet government.

The geographic regions where Iranian languages were spoken were displaced in various areas by newly arrived neighboring languages. Arabic spread to some parts of western Iran (Khuzestan), and Turkish languages spread across much of Central Asia, displacing various Iranian languages such as Sogdian and Bactrian in parts of what is now Turkmenistan, Uzbekistan, and Tajikistan. In Eastern Europe, which mainly encompasses the territory of present-day Ukraine, southern European Russia, and parts of the Balkans, the central region of the Scythian, Sarmatian, and Alan natives had been decisively occupied as a result of absorption and assimilation (for example, Slavicization) by the proto-Slavic population of the region by the 6th century AD. This resulted in the displacement and extinction of the once predominant Scythian languages of the region. The close relative of Sogdian, Yaghnobi, barely survives in a small area of the Zarafshan valley east of Samarkand, and Saka as Ossetian in the Caucasus, which is the only remnant of the once predominant Scythian languages in Eastern Europe proper and large parts of the North Caucasus. Several small Iranian languages in the Pamirs survive and are derived from Eastern Iranian.

Lighting or illumination is the deliberate use of light to achieve a practical or aesthetic effect. Lighting includes the use of artificial light sources, such as lamps and light fixtures, as well as natural lighting by capturing daylight. Natural lighting (using windows, skylights, or light shelves) is sometimes used as the main source of light during the day in buildings. This can save energy instead of using artificial lighting, which represents an important component of energy consumption in buildings. Proper lighting can enhance task performance, improve the appearance of an area, or have positive psychological effects on occupants.
Interior lighting is usually achieved through fixtures and is a key part of interior design. Lighting can also be an intrinsic component of landscaping projects.

This is often done with fluorescent lighting (available for the first time at the 1939 World's Fair) or with string lights, occasionally with neon lighting and, recently, with LED strip lighting. It is a form of backlighting.

Recessed lighting (often called "pot lights" in Canada, "can lights," or "high hats" in the U.S.) is popular, with fixtures mounted in the ceiling structure to appear flush with it. These recessed lights can use narrow beam or wider angle flood bulbs, both types of bulbs that have their own reflectors. There are also recessed lights with internal reflectors designed to accept standard 'A' type bulbs, which are generally less expensive than reflector bulbs. Recessed lights can be incandescent, fluorescent, HID (high-intensity discharge), or LED.

With the discovery of fire, the oldest form of artificial lighting used to illuminate an area were bonfires or torches. As early as 400,000 B.C., fire was lit in the caves of the Peking Man. Prehistoric people used primitive oil lamps to light their surroundings. These lamps were made from natural materials such as stones, shells, horns, and rocks, filled with fat, and had a fiber wick. The lamps typically used animal or vegetable fats as fuel. Hundreds of these lamps (hollow worked stones) have been found in the Lascaux caves in present-day France, dating back approximately 15,000 years. Oily animals (birds and fish) were also used as lamps after being threaded with a wick. Fireflies have been used as light sources. Candles and glass and ceramic lamps were also invented. Spiders were an early form of "luminaire."

Significant reductions in the cost of lighting occurred with the discovery of whale oil and kerosene. Gas lighting was affordable enough to power streetlights in major cities starting in the early 1800s, and it was also used in some commercial buildings and in the homes of wealthy individuals. The gas mantle increased the brightness of utilitarian lighting and kerosene lanterns. The next major drop in price occurred with the electric incandescent bulb.

Over time, electric lighting became ubiquitous in developed countries. Patterns of segmented sleep disappeared, the improvement of nighttime lighting made more activities possible at night, and more streetlights reduced urban crime.

The luminaires come in a wide variety of styles for different functions. The most important functions are to support the light source, provide directed light, and prevent visual glare. Some are very simple and functional, while others are works of art in themselves. Almost any material can be used, as long as it can tolerate excess heat and meets safety codes.

An important property of light fixtures is luminous efficacy or grid connection efficiency, which means the amount of usable light emitted by the fixture per energy used, usually measured in lumens per watt. A fixture that uses replaceable light sources may also have its efficiency cited as the percentage of light that passes from the "bulb" to the surroundings. The more transparent the lighting fixture, the higher the efficacy. Shading the light will typically decrease efficacy but increase directionality and the likelihood of visual comfort.

The color temperature of white light sources also affects their use in certain applications. The color temperature of a white light source is the temperature in Kelvin of an ideal black body emitter that most closely resembles the spectral characteristics of the lamp. An incandescent bulb has a color temperature of around 2800 to 3000 Kelvin; daylight is around 6400 Kelvin. Lamps with lower color temperatures have relatively more energy in the yellow and red parts of the visible spectrum, while higher color temperatures correspond to lamps with a more blue-white appearance. For critical inspection tasks or color matching, or for retail displays of food and clothing, the color temperature of the lamps will be selected for the best overall lighting effect.
Lighting is classified according to its intended use as general, accent, or task lighting, largely depending on the distribution of light produced by the fixture.

Track lighting, invented by Lightolier, was popular for a time because it was much easier to install than recessed lighting, and the individual fixtures are decorative and can easily target a wall. It has recently regained some popularity in low-voltage tracks, which often do not resemble their predecessors at all because they do not have the safety issues that line-voltage systems have, and are therefore less bulky and more decorative on their own. A central transformer powers all the fixtures on the track or rail with 12 or 24 volts, rather than having each fixture with its own linear to low-voltage transformer. There are traditional spots and floods, as well as other small pendant fixtures. A modified version of this is wire lighting, where the lights are hung from or attached to bare metal wires under tension.

A wall lamp is a fixed device, particularly one that shines upwards and sometimes downwards. A torchiere is an upward light intended for ambient lighting. It is usually a floor lamp but can be mounted on the wall like a wall lamp.

The portable or table lamp is probably the most common lighting fixture found in many homes and offices. The regular lamp and the shade found on a table provide general lighting, while the table lamp is considered task lighting. Magnifying lamps are also task lighting.

The illuminated ceiling was popular in the 1960s and 1970s but fell into disuse after the 1980s. It uses diffusion panels hung like a drop ceiling under fluorescent lamps and is considered general lighting. Other forms include neon, which is usually not intended to illuminate anything else but to actually be a work of art in itself. This would likely fall under accent lighting, although in a dark nightclub it could be considered general lighting.

In a cinema, the steps in the aisles are usually marked with a series of small lights for comfort and safety when the movie has started and the other lights are off. Traditionally, they consisted of small low-power and low-voltage lamps on a rail or transparent tube; these are quickly being replaced by LED-based versions.

The illuminated signs are used for lighting streets and sidewalks at night. Some manufacturers design LED lighting and photovoltaics to provide an energy-efficient alternative to traditional street lighting.
The floodlights can be used to illuminate outdoor play areas or work zones during nighttime hours. The most common type of floodlights are metal halides and high-pressure sodium lights.

Sometimes, security lighting can be used along roads in urban areas or behind houses or commercial establishments. These are extremely bright lights used to deter crime. Security lights may include floodlights.
The entrance lights can be used outside to illuminate and signal the entrance to a property. These lights are installed for safety, protection, and decoration.

Vehicles typically include headlights and taillights. The headlights are white or selectively yellow lights mounted at the front of the vehicle, designed to illuminate the upcoming road and make the vehicle more visible. Many manufacturers are turning to LED lights as an energy-efficient alternative to traditional headlights. The rear lights and brake lights are red and emit light backward, revealing the direction of the vehicle's movement to following drivers. The white reverse lights indicate that the vehicle's transmission is in reverse, warning anyone behind the vehicle that it is moving backward or is about to do so. The flashing turn indicators at the front, side, and rear of the vehicle indicate a planned change of position or direction. In the late 1950s, some car manufacturers began using electro-luminescence to illuminate the speedometers and other measuring devices in their cars or to draw attention to logos or other decorative elements.

Often referred to as "lamps," lamps are the removable and necessary part of a lighting fixture that converts electrical energy into electromagnetic radiation. While lamps were traditionally evaluated and advertised mainly based on energy consumption, expressed in watts, the spread of lighting technology beyond incandescent bulbs has eliminated the correlation of power with the amount of light produced. For example, a 60 W incandescent bulb produces about the same amount of light as a 13 W compact fluorescent lamp. Each of these technologies has different efficiencies in converting electrical energy into visible light. The emission of visible light is typically measured in lumens. This unit quantifies only visible radiation and excludes invisible infrared and ultraviolet radiation. A paraffin candle produces around 13 lumens, a 60-watt incandescent bulb produces about 700 lumens, and a 15-watt compact fluorescent lamp produces about 800 lumens, but the actual output varies depending on the specific design. The evaluation and advertising shift from watts to lumens, providing the buyer with an immediately applicable basis for choosing a lamp.

Lighting design as applied to the built environment is called "architectural lighting design." The lighting of structures considers aesthetic elements as well as practical parameters such as the amount of light required, the occupants of the structure, energy efficiency, and cost. Artificial lighting takes into account the amount of natural light entering an interior space using a daylight factor calculation. For simple installations, manual calculations based on data tables are used to provide an acceptable lighting design. More critical or optimized designs now regularly use mathematical modeling on computers with software like Radiance, which allows an architect to quickly undertake complex calculations to examine the benefits of a specific design.

In certain design cases, the materials used on walls and furniture play a crucial role in the effect of lighting. For example, dark paint tends to absorb light, making the space appear smaller and darker than it is, while light paint does the opposite. In addition to paint, reflective surfaces also have an impact on lighting design.

Photometric studies (which are sometimes referred to as "layouts" or "point-to-point") are often used to simulate lighting designs for projects before they are constructed or renovated. This allows architects, lighting designers, and engineers to determine whether a proposed lighting layout will provide the intended amount of light. They will also be able to assess the contrast relationship between bright and dark areas. In many cases, these studies refer to proposed lighting practices of IESNA or CIBSE for the type of application. Depending on the type of area, different design aspects may be emphasized for safety or practicality reasons (i.e., such as maintaining uniform light levels, avoiding glare, or highlighting specific areas). Specialized software is often used to create these, which typically combines the use of two-dimensional digital CAD drawings and lighting calculation software (i.e., AGi32 or Dialux).

The lighting illuminates the performers and artists in a live theatrical, dance, or musical performance and is selected and adjusted to create dramatic effects. Stage lighting uses general lighting technology in devices designed for easy adjustment of their output characteristics. The stage lighting setup is tailored for each scene of every production. Dimmer switches, colored filters, reflectors, lenses, moving or manually targeted lamps, and various types of floodlights and spots are some of the tools used by a stage lighting designer to produce the desired effects. A set of lighting cues is prepared so that the lighting operator can control the lights in sync with the performance. Complex theater lighting systems use computers to control the lighting instruments.

Film and television production uses many of the same tools and methods of stage lighting. Especially in the early days of these industries, very high levels of lighting were required, and the heat produced by lighting devices posed significant challenges. Modern cameras require less light, and modern light sources emit less heat.

The measurement of light or photometry generally concerns the amount of useful light that falls on a surface and the amount of light that comes from a lamp or other source, along with the colors that can be attributed to that light. The human eye reacts differently to light from various parts of the visible spectrum, so photometric measurements must take into account the brightness function when measuring the amount of useful light. The basic SI unit of measurement is the candela (cd), which describes luminous intensity; all other photometric units derive from the candela. Brightness, for example, is a measure of the density of luminous intensity in a specific direction. It describes the amount of light that passes through or is emitted from a specific area and falls within a given solid angle. The SI unit for brightness is candela per square meter (cd/m²). The CGS unit of brightness is the stilb, which equals one candela per square centimeter or 10 kcd/m². The amount of useful light emitted by a source or brightness is measured in lumens (lm).

The SI unit of luminous efficacy and luminous flux, which is the luminous power per unit area, is measured in lux. It is used in photometry as a measure of the intensity, as perceived by the human eye, of the light striking or passing through a surface. It is analogous to the radiometric unit of watts per square meter, but with the power at each wavelength weighted according to the luminosity function, a standardized model of human brightness perception. In English, the word "lux" is used in both singular and plural.

The Unified Glare Rating (UGR), Visual Comfort Probability, and Daylight Glare Index are among the most well-known measurement methods. In addition to these new methods, there are four main factors affecting the degree of discomfort glare; the brightness level of the glare source, the solid angle of the glare source, the background brightness level, and the position of the glare source within the field of view should be taken into account.

The lighting industry generally relies on two criteria to describe the color characteristics of a light source: correlated color temperature (CCT), which is commonly used as an indicator of the "warmth" or "coolness" of light emitted from a source, and color rendering index (CRI), which is a measure of a light source's ability to make objects appear natural.

For example, research suggests the use of another metric called the gamut area index (GAI) alongside the well-known CRI to meet the expectations of good color presentation in retail applications. GAI represents the relative distinction of object colors illuminated by a light source; the higher the GAI, the greater the visible saturation or vividness of the object colors. As a result, light sources that balance both CRI and GAI are generally preferred over those that only have a high CRI or only a high GAI.

Typical measurements of light are made using a dosimeter. Dosimeters measure the exposure level of an individual or an object to something in the environment, such as light dosimeters and ultraviolet dosimeters.

A personal circadian light meter called Daysimeter has been developed to specifically measure the amount of light entering the eye. This is the first device created to accurately measure and characterize the light entering the eye (intensity, spectrum, timing, and duration) that affects the biological clock of the human body.

The small device worn on the head measures the individual's daily rest and activity patterns, as well as exposure to short wavelength light that stimulates the circadian system. The device measures activity and light together at regular intervals and electronically stores and records the working temperature. The daysimeter can collect data for up to 30 days for analysis.

Determining lighting requirements is the fundamental concept of deciding how much illumination is needed for a specific task. Clearly, the amount of light required to illuminate a corridor is much less than that needed for a word processing workstation. Generally, the energy expended is proportional to the designed lighting level. For example, a lighting level of 400 lux may be chosen for a work environment that includes meeting rooms and conferences, while a level of 80 lux may be preferred for building corridors. If the corridor standard mimics the conference room requirements, then much more energy than necessary will be consumed. Unfortunately, even today, most lighting standards are set by industrial groups that produce and sell lighting, so there is a historical commercial bias in the design of most building lighting, particularly in office and industrial environments.

Lighting control systems help reduce energy use and costs by providing light only when and where it is needed. Lighting control systems typically use time schedules, occupancy sensing, and photocell control (i.e., daylight harvesting). Some systems also support demand response and automatically dim or turn off lights to take advantage of energy incentives. Lighting control systems are sometimes integrated into larger building automation systems.

Many new control systems utilize wireless network open standards (such as ZigBee) that offer advantages such as easier installation (no need to pull control cables) and interoperability with other building control systems based on different standards (such as security).

Occupancy sensors can control lighting to ensure operation in any situation where someone is present in the scanned area. When movement is no longer detected, the lights turn off. Passive infrared sensors respond to heat changes created by a moving person. The control must have an unobstructed view of the scanned building area. Doors, partitions, stairs, etc., will obstruct motion detection and reduce effectiveness. Best practices for passive infrared occupancy sensors are open areas with a clear view of the scanned area. Ultrasonic sensors transmit sounds above the human hearing range and monitor the time it takes for sound waves to return. The disruption in a pattern caused by any movement in the area triggers the control. Ultrasonic sensors can see around obstacles and are best suited for cabinets, shelves, restrooms, and open areas that require 360-degree coverage. Some occupancy sensors use both passive infrared and ultrasonic technology, but they are generally more expensive. They can be used to control a single lamp, a fixture, or multiple fixtures.

Daylight is the oldest method of indoor lighting. Daylight means designing a space to use as much natural light as possible. This reduces energy consumption and costs and requires less heating and cooling of the building. It has been proven that daylight has positive effects on patients and also contributes to work and school performance. Due to a lack of information showing potential energy savings, daylight applications are not yet popular among most buildings.

In recent years, light-emitting diodes (LEDs) are becoming increasingly efficient, leading to an extraordinary increase in the use of solid-state lighting. In many cases, controlling the light emission of LEDs can be achieved most effectively by using the principles of imaging optics.

Beyond energy factors, it is important not to overdesign lighting; otherwise, negative health effects may arise due to higher lighting levels, such as increased headache frequency, stress, and elevated blood pressure. Additionally, glare or excessive light can reduce worker productivity.

The analysis of lighting quality emphasizes the use of natural lighting, but also takes into account the spectral content if artificial light is to be used. Relying more on natural light will not only reduce energy consumption but will also have a positive impact on human health and performance. New studies have shown that students' performance is affected by the amount and duration of daylight in their regular schedules. Designing school facilities to integrate the right type of light at the right time and for the right duration can enhance student performance and well-being. Similarly, designing lighting systems that maximize the right amount of light at appropriate times for the elderly can help alleviate symptoms of Alzheimer's disease. The human circadian system adapts to a 24-hour light-dark cycle that mimics the natural light/dark pattern of the world. When these patterns are disrupted, they also disrupt the natural circadian cycle. Circadian disruption can lead to many health issues, including breast cancer, seasonal affective disorder, delayed sleep phase syndrome, and other disorders.

A study documented by Robert Ulrich in 1972 and 1981 investigated 23 surgical patients assigned to rooms with views of natural landscapes. The study concluded that patients assigned to rooms with windows that received ample natural light had shorter postoperative hospital stays compared to 23 matched patients in similar rooms facing a brick wall, received fewer negative assessments in nurse notes, and used less potent painkillers. This study suggests that the nature of the view and exposure to daylight are indeed healthier for patients compared to those exposed to a brick wall. In addition to increased work performance, the proper use of windows and daylight transcends the boundaries between pure aesthetics and overall health.

Alison Jing Xu, an assistant professor in management at the University of Toronto Scarborough, and Aparna Labroo from Northwestern University conducted a series of studies analyzing the correlation between lighting and human emotions. The researchers asked participants to evaluate the spiciness of chicken wing sauce, the aggressiveness of a fictional character, how attractive someone was, their feelings about certain words, and the taste of two fruit juices—all under different lighting conditions. In their studies, they found that both positive and negative human emotions were felt more intensely in bright light. Professor Xu stated, "We found that people prone to depression actually became more depressed on sunny days." They also discovered that dim lighting led to more rational decision-making and easier resolution of negotiations. In the dark, emotions are somewhat suppressed. However, in bright light, emotions are intensified.

In 1849, Canadian geologist Dr. Abraham Gesner developed a method for obtaining kerosene through the distillation of petroleum. The coal gas methods used for lighting since the 1820s were expensive. Gesner's kerosene was cheap, easy to produce, could be burned in existing lamps, and did not emit an unpleasant odor like most whale oil. It could be stored indefinitely without degrading, unlike whale oil. The American oil boom began in the 1850s. By the end of the decade, there were 30 kerosene plants operating in the United States. The cheaper and more efficient fuel began to eliminate whale oil from the market. John D. Rockefeller was the person most responsible for the commercial success of kerosene. By completely eliminating the need for whale oil lamps, he established a network of kerosene distillation plants that would later become Standard Oil. Such lamps could cause fires or emit carbon dioxide and could sometimes become problematic for asthma patients due to their odors.

Compact fluorescent lamps (also known as 'CFLs') use less power to provide the same amount of light as a bulb, but they contain mercury, which poses a waste hazard. Due to their ability to reduce electricity consumption, many organizations have taken measures to promote the adoption of CFLs. Some electric companies and local governments have subsidized CFLs or provided them free of charge to customers as a means to reduce electricity demand. For a specific light output, CFLs use between one-fifth and one-fourth of the power compared to an equivalent incandescent lamp. One of the simplest and quickest ways for a home or business to become more energy-efficient is to adopt CFLs as the primary light source, as recommended by the Climate Protection Alliance. Unlike incandescent lamps, CFLs require a bit of time to 'warm up' and reach full brightness. Caution should be exercised when choosing CFLs, as not all are suitable for dimming.

In 1964, CBS established its own distribution channel in the UK by acquiring Oriole Records. EMI continued to release Epic and Okeh label records under the Columbia brand in the UK until the distribution agreement with EMI expired in 1968, after which CBS took over distribution.
In 1965, after the record company became a global business, CBS executives began considering renaming their record subsidiary "Columbia Records" to "CBS Records."

At the end of 1965, Date's subsidiary label was also reactivated. The label released the first hit songs by Peaches & Herb and achieved several minor hits from various other artists. Date's most successful single was "Time of the Season" by The Zombies, which reached number 2 on the charts in 1969. The label ceased operations in 1970.

In 1966, CBS restructured its corporate organization, and Lieberson was promoted to head the newly formed "CBS-Columbia Group," which made the company, now renamed CBS Records, an independent division under the new group led by Clive Davis.

In March 1968, CBS and Sony established a Japanese joint venture, CBS/Sony Records. Since Sony was one of the companies that developed the compact disc (CD) digital music medium, the joint venture set up CD manufacturing facilities in Japan, enabling CBS to begin supplying the first CD releases for the U.S. market in 1983.

Columbia Records Group was successfully led by Clive Davis until 1972, when he was dismissed after being found to have misused company funds to support his personal lifestyle, including hosting an expensive bar mitzvah party for his son. He was initially succeeded by former head Goddard Lieberson, and then in 1975 by the colorful and controversial lawyer Walter Yetnikoff, who led the company until 1990.

In February 2016, musician Kesha accused music producer Dr. Luke of sexual assault, prompting over one hundred thousand people to sign a petition within twenty-four hours calling for a boycott of Sony Music and all its affiliated companies. Kesha requested the New York State Supreme Court to release her from her contract with Sony Music, but the court denied her request, sparking widespread public and media reaction.
In July 2013, Sony Music exited the Greek market due to the economic crisis. Albums by domestic and international artists released by Sony Music in Greece are handled by Feelgood Records.

Doug Morris, who previously led Warner Music Group and Universal Music, became Chairman and CEO of Sony Music Entertainment on July 1, 2011. After Morris took office, Sony Music underwent a reorganization. L.A. Reid joined the company as Chairman and CEO of Epic Records. Under Reid's leadership, several artists from Jive Records, formerly part of the RCA/Jive Label Group, moved to Epic Records. Peter Edge became the new CEO of the RCA Records division. In October 2011, RCA Music Group shut down Arista, J Records, and Jive Records, transferring their artists to RCA Records.

From the 1980s to the early 1990s, CBS Inc. in the United States operated a subsidiary label called CBS Associated Records. Tony Martell, a veteran Vice President of A&R at CBS and Epic Records, headed the label, which signed artists such as Ozzy Osbourne, The Fabulous Thunderbirds, Electric Light Orchestra, Joan Jett, and Henry Lee Summer. The label was part of CBS's subsidiary label structure (Epic/Portrait/Associated), shared national and regional staff with Epic Records, and was integrated into the CBS Records global distribution system.
In 1986, CBS sold its music publishing division, CBS Songs, for $125 million to Stephen Swid, Martin Bandier, and Charles Koppelman, forming the foundation of their SBK Entertainment company.

By 1987, CBS was the only one of the "Big Three" American television networks that still owned an affiliated record company. ABC had sold its record division to MCA Records in 1979, and in 1986, RCA, the parent company of NBC, was sold to General Electric, which subsequently divested all of RCA's other business units, including the record division (acquired by Ariola Records and later known as BMG).

On November 17, 1987, SCA acquired CBS Records, which represented artists such as Michael Jackson, for $2 billion. CBS Inc. (now CBS Corporation) retained the rights to the name "CBS" in the music recording field but granted Sony a temporary license to use the name. In 2006, CBS Corporation re-established a new CBS Records, with distribution handled by Sony through its subsidiary RED.
In 1989, CBS Records acquired Nashville music publisher Tree International Publishing for over $30 million, re-entering the music publishing industry.

The CEO of the RCA/Jive Label Group, Barry Weiss, left the company in March 2011 to become the new CEO of Island Def Jam and Universal Republic, both part of Universal Music Group. Weiss had been CEO of the RCA/Jive Label Group since 2008 and had led Jive Records since 1991.

On October 11, 2011, Doug Morris announced that Mel Lewinter had been appointed Executive Vice President for Label Strategy. Previously, Lewinter had been Chairman and CEO of the Universal Motown Republic Group. In January 2012, Dennis Kooker was appointed President of Global Digital Business and U.S. Sales.

In August 2004, Sony formed a joint venture with the equal partner Bertelsmann by merging Sony Music and Germany's Bertelsmann Music Group to establish Sony BMG Music Entertainment. However, Sony continued to operate its Japanese music business independently from Sony BMG, while BMG Japan was included in the merger.

On July 1, 2009, SME and IODA announced their global strategic partnership to leverage combined worldwide online retail distribution networks and complementary technologies to support independent labels and music industry rights holders.
In March 2010, Sony Corp entered into a partnership with The Michael Jackson Company with a contract worth over $250 million, the largest deal in music history.

The merger made Columbia and Epic sister labels to RCA Records, which was once owned by RCA, a company that also owned CBS's rival NBC. Additionally, it initiated the process of bringing BMG's Arista Records back under common ownership with its former parent company, Columbia Pictures, a Sony division since 1989, while simultaneously bringing Arista founder Clive Davis back into the company. Davis remains at Sony Music as Chief Creative Officer.
In 1995, Sony and Michael Jackson formed a joint venture that combined Sony's music publishing operations with Jackson's ATV Music to create Sony/ATV Music Publishing.

On January 1, 1991, Sony renamed the record company to Sony Music Entertainment (SME), fulfilling the conditions of the 1988 takeover offer, which provided only a time-limited license for the CBS brand. The CBS Associated label was renamed Epic Associated. Also on January 1, 1991, Sony reintroduced the Columbia label worldwide, which had previously been used only in the United States and Canada, after acquiring the international rights to the brand from EMI in 1990. Japan is the only country where Sony does not hold rights to the Columbia name, as it is controlled there by Nippon Columbia, an independent company. Therefore, Sony Music Entertainment Japan still does not use the Columbia brand for recordings from the Columbia label released in other countries when issued in Japan. The owner of the Columbia Records brand in Spain was Bertelsmann Music Group Germany, which Sony Music subsequently acquired through a merger in 2004 and later through a purchase in 2008.

Oklahoma City is the capital and largest city of the state of Oklahoma. As the county seat of Oklahoma County, the city ranks 27th among cities in the United States by population. Following the 2010 census, the population increased, reaching an estimated 620,602 residents by July 2014. In 2014, the Oklahoma City metropolitan area had 1,322,429 inhabitants, and the combined statistical area of Oklahoma City-Shawnee had 1,459,758 (Chamber of Commerce), making it the largest metropolitan area in Oklahoma. The city limits of Oklahoma City extend into areas of Canadian, Cleveland, and Pottawatomie counties, although large portions of these are suburban or rural in character outside the core area of Oklahoma County (service area). The city is the eighth-largest in the United States by area (including consolidated city-counties); it is the largest city in the U.S. by area whose government is not consolidated with a county or borough government.

Oklahoma City, located in the Great Plains region, has one of the largest livestock markets in the world. Oil, natural gas, petroleum products, and related industries form the largest economic sector of the region. The city lies in the middle of an active oil field, and drilling rigs line the grounds of the state capitol. The federal government employs numerous workers at Tinker Air Force Base and at the Mike Monroney Aeronautical Center of the U.S. Department of Transportation (several offices of the Federal Aviation Administration and the Department of Transportation's Enterprise Service Center are located at these two sites).

Oklahoma City lies along the I-35 corridor, one of the major transportation routes into neighboring Texas and Mexico. Located in the Frontier Country region of the state, the northeastern part of the city is situated in an ecological region known as the Cross Timbers. The city was founded during the Land Run of 1889 and grew to over 10,000 residents within hours of its establishment. On April 19, 1995, the city was the site of the bombing of the Alfred P. Murrah Federal Building, which killed 168 people. It was the deadliest terrorist attack in United States history until the September 11, 2001 attacks, and remains the most severe case of domestic terrorism in U.S. history.

Oklahoma City was settled on April 22, 1889, when the area of the "Unassigned Lands" was opened for settlement, an event known as "The Land Run." Around 10,000 settlers established themselves in the area that would later become Oklahoma's capital. The city grew rapidly; its population doubled between 1890 and 1900. Early pioneers of urban development included Anton Classen, John Shartel, Henry Overholser, and James W. Maney.

When Oklahoma was admitted to the Union in 1907, Oklahoma City had already surpassed Guthrie, the former territorial capital, as the population and commercial center of the new state. Shortly afterward, the state capital was moved from Guthrie to Oklahoma City. Oklahoma City was an important stop on Route 66 in the early 20th century; it was prominently mentioned in Bobby Troup's 1946 jazz classic "(Get Your Kicks on) Route 66," later made famous by Nat King Cole.

Before World War II, Oklahoma City developed large livestock markets that attracted jobs and revenues previously based in Chicago and Omaha, Nebraska. With the discovery of oil within city limits in 1928 (including beneath the state capitol complex), Oklahoma City became a significant center for oil production. Postwar growth coincided with the construction of the Interstate Highway System, establishing Oklahoma City as a key transportation hub at the intersection of I-35, I-40, and I-44 highways. This was further supported by the federal development of Tinker Air Force Base.

Patience Latting was elected mayor of Oklahoma City in 1971, becoming the city's first female mayor. Latting was also the first woman to serve as mayor of a U.S. city with more than 350,000 residents.

In 1993, the city adopted a comprehensive redevelopment program called Metropolitan Area Projects (MAPS), aimed at revitalizing the downtown area through public-interest projects to attract more activity and life. The city added a new baseball stadium, a central library, renovations to the civic center, convention center, and racetrack, as well as a water canal in the Bricktown commercial district. Water taxis carry passengers through this neighborhood, bringing vibrancy and color along the canal. The MAPS program became one of the most successful public-private partnerships in the United States, generating over $3 billion in private investment by 2010. Thanks to MAPS, the population living in downtown housing has significantly increased, as has the demand for additional residential and commercial amenities such as supermarkets, services, and shops.

Since the completion of the MAPS projects, the downtown area has experienced continuous development. Several downtown buildings are currently undergoing renovation or restoration. Among these is the notable restoration of the Skirvin Hotel in 2007. The famous First National Center is currently being renovated.

Residents of Oklahoma City suffered heavy losses on April 19, 1995, when Timothy McVeigh detonated a bomb in front of the Murrah Building. The building was destroyed (its remains having to be demolished later that year by controlled demolition), more than 100 nearby buildings were severely damaged, and 168 people lost their lives. The site is now commemorated by the Oklahoma City National Memorial and Museum. Since its opening in 2000, more than three million people have visited. Each year on April 19, survivors, families, and friends return to the memorial to read the names of each person who died.

The "Core-to-Shore" project was designed to move I-40 one mile (1.6 km) south and replace it with a boulevard to create a landscaped entrance into the city. This also allows the central part of the city to expand southward and connect to the Oklahoma River shoreline. Several elements of the "Core to Shore" project were included in the MAPS 3 proposal approved by voters at the end of 2009.

According to the U.S. Census Bureau, the city has a total area of 620.34 square miles (1,606.7 km²), of which 601.11 square miles (1,556.9 km²) are land and 19.23 square miles (49.8 km²) are water. The total area is composed of 3.09 percent water.

Oklahoma City is located in the Oklahoma sandstone hills region, known for its hills 75 to 120 meters high and two species of oak: blackjack oak (Quercus marilandica) and post oak (Q. stellata). The northeastern part of the city and its eastern suburbs are part of an ecological region called the Cross Timbers.

The city is roughly divided in two by the North Canadian River (recently renamed Oklahoma River within city limits). The North Canadian once had enough flow to cause annual flooding, resulting in damage to surrounding areas, including downtown and the former Oklahoma City Zoo. In the 1940s, a dam was built on the river to control flooding and reduce its water level. In the 1990s, as part of an urban revitalization project known as MAPS, the city constructed a series of small dams, bringing water back into the portion of the river running through downtown. The city has three major lakes: Lake Hefner and Lake Overholser, located in the city's northwest quadrant; and the largest, Lake Stanley Draper, situated in the sparsely populated southeastern part of the city.

The population density usually cited for Oklahoma City, calculated from the area of its municipal boundaries, can be somewhat misleading. Its urbanized area covers approximately 244 square miles (630 km²), resulting in a density of 2,500 people per square mile (2013 estimate), compared to the vast rural areas included within the city, which account for the remaining 377 square miles (980 km²) of the municipal boundaries.

The city is geographically and culturally divided by the North Canadian River, which essentially separates northern Oklahoma City from southern Oklahoma City. The two halves of the city were actually founded and developed as distinct towns but quickly grew together. The north side is characterized by highly diverse and desirable urban neighborhoods close to downtown, along with extensive suburbs further north. Southern Oklahoma City is generally more working-class and distinctly more industrial, having grown around the stockyards and meatpacking plants at the turn of the century, and now serves as the center of the city's expanding Latino community.

Downtown Oklahoma City, home to 7,600 residents, is currently experiencing an influx of new private investments and major public infrastructure projects, helping to revitalize a central business district that was nearly abandoned after the collapse of the oil industry in the early 1980s. The centerpiece of downtown is the recently renovated Crystal Bridge and the Myriad Botanical Gardens, one of the few elements of the Pei Plan ever realized. In the coming years, a large new central park will connect the gardens near the business district and the new convention center to be built just to the south, extending down to the North Canadian River as part of a major project called Core to Shore; this new park is part of MAPS3, a set of municipal projects funded by a temporary seven-year, one-cent sales tax increase.

The average temperature is 61.4°F (16.3°C), with monthly averages ranging from 39.2°F (4.0°C) in January to 83.0°F (28.3°C) in July. Extremes range from −17°F (−27°C) on February 12, 1899, to 113°F (45°C) on August 11, 1936, and August 3, 2012; the most recent subzero °F temperature was −5°F (−21°C) on February 10, 2011. Temperatures reach 100°F (38°C) for 10.4 days per year, 90°F (32°C) for nearly 70 days, and fail to rise above freezing for 8.3 days. The city receives about 35.9 inches (91.2 cm) of precipitation annually, including 8.6 inches (21.8 cm) of snow.

Oklahoma City experiences a very active severe weather season from March to June, particularly in April and May. Located in the heart of what is commonly known as Tornado Alley, the city is prone to frequent and violent tornadoes, as well as intense hailstorms and occasional derechos. Tornadoes have been recorded every month of the year, with a weaker secondary peak occurring in autumn, especially in October. The Oklahoma City metropolitan area is one of the major cities most exposed to tornadoes in the world, with approximately 150 tornadoes having struck the city since 1890. Since weather records began, Oklahoma City has been hit by thirteen violent tornadoes—eleven rated F/EF4 and two rated F/EF5. On May 3, 1999, parts of southern Oklahoma City and neighboring suburban communities were struck by one of the most powerful tornadoes ever recorded, an F5 on the Fujita scale, with wind speeds estimated by radar at 318 mph (510 km/h). On May 20, 2013, southwestern Oklahoma City, along with Newcastle and Moore, was struck again by an EF5 tornado; it was between 0.5 and 1.3 miles (0.80 to 2.09 km) wide and caused 23 fatalities. Less than two weeks later, on May 31, another tornado outbreak affected the Oklahoma City area, including an EF1 and an EF0 tornado within the city, as well as a tornado located several kilometers west of the city that was 2.6 miles (4.2 km) wide—the widest tornado ever recorded.

With 19.48 inches of precipitation, May 2015 was by far the wettest month ever recorded in Oklahoma City since record-keeping began in 1890. Across Oklahoma and Texas, record flooding occurred at the end of the month.

According to the 2010 census, the city had a population of 579,999 people, 230,233 households, and 144,120 families. The population density was 956.4 inhabitants per square mile (369.3 inhabitants/km²). There were 256,930 housing units distributed at an average density of 375.9 per square mile (145.1/km²).

There were 230,233 households, of which 29.4% had children under 18 living with them, 43.4% were married couples living together, 13.9% were female-headed households with no husband present, and 37.4% were not families. Households consisting of a single person made up 30.5% of all households, and 8.7% of all households included someone aged 65 or older living alone. The average household size was 2.47 people, and the average family size was 3.11 people.

In the 2000 Census, the age composition of Oklahoma City was 25.5% under 18 years old, 10.7% between 18 and 24 years old, 30.8% between 25 and 44 years old, 21.5% between 45 and 64 years old, and 11.5% aged 65 or older. The median age was 34 years. For every 100 women, there were 95.6 men. For every 100 women aged 18 or older, there were 92.7 men.

Oklahoma City has experienced significant population increases since the late 1990s. In May 2014, the U.S. Census announced that Oklahoma City had an estimated population of 620,602 in 2014 and had grown by 5.3 percent between April 2010 and June 2013. Since the official 2000 census, Oklahoma City had grown by 21 percent (a net increase of 114,470 people), according to the bureau's estimates. The 2014 estimate of 620,602 residents is the highest population Oklahoma City has ever recorded. It is the first city in the state to register a population exceeding 600,000 residents and the largest municipal population in the Great Plains region (OK, KS, NE, SD, ND).

Oklahoma City is the principal city of the Oklahoma City Metropolitan Statistical Area, which includes eight counties in central Oklahoma and is the largest urbanized area in the state. By population ranking, the metropolitan area was the 42nd largest in the country in 2012.

Oklahoma City has also had its share of extremely brutal crimes, particularly in the 1970s. The worst of them occurred in 1978, when six employees of a Sirloin Stockade restaurant in the southern part of the city were cold-bloodedly murdered inside the restaurant's freezer. An intense investigation followed, leading to the identification of three individuals involved, who had also killed three others in Purcell, Oklahoma. One of them, Harold Stafford, died in a motorcycle accident in Tulsa shortly after the restaurant murders. Another, Verna Stafford, was sentenced to life imprisonment without the possibility of parole after receiving a new trial following her earlier death sentence. Roger Dale Stafford, considered the mastermind behind the murder spree, was executed by lethal injection at the Oklahoma State Penitentiary in 1995.

The Oklahoma City Police Department has a uniformed force of 1,169 officers and more than 300 civilian employees. The Department has one central police station and five substations covering 2,500 police reporting districts, each with an average size of one-quarter square mile.

On April 19, 1995, the Alfred P. Murrah Federal Building was destroyed by a fertilizer bomb built and detonated by Timothy McVeigh. The explosion and catastrophic collapse killed 168 people and left more than 680 injured. The blast wave destroyed or damaged 324 buildings within a radius of 340 meters, destroyed or burned 86 vehicles, and shattered windows in 258 nearby buildings, causing an estimated $652 million in damages. The main suspect, Timothy McVeigh, was executed by lethal injection on June 11, 2001. It was the deadliest domestic terrorist attack in U.S. history before September 11.

Although not located in Oklahoma City proper, other major employers within the metropolitan area region include: Tinker Air Force Base (27,000); University of Oklahoma (11,900); University of Central Oklahoma (2,900); and Norman Regional Hospital (2,800).
Its gross metropolitan product was $43.1 billion in 2005 and increased to $61.1 billion in 2009.

In 2008, Forbes magazine named Oklahoma City the most "recession-proof city in the United States." The magazine reported that the city had a declining unemployment rate, one of the strongest real estate markets in the country, and solid growth in the energy, agricultural, and manufacturing sectors. However, during the early 1980s, Oklahoma City had one of the worst job and real estate markets due to the collapse of Penn Square Bank in 1982 and subsequently the drop in oil prices after 1985.[citation needed]

Other theaters include the Lyric Theatre, the Jewel Box Theatre, the Kirkpatrick Auditorium, the Poteet Theatre, the Bruce Owen Theatre at Oklahoma City Community College, and the 488-seat Petree Recital Hall on the Oklahoma City University campus. The university also opened the Wanda L. Bass School of Music and its auditorium in April 2006.

The Science Museum of Oklahoma (formerly the Kirkpatrick Science and Air Space Museum at Omniplex) houses exhibits on science, aviation, and an IMAX theater. The museum previously hosted the International Photography Hall of Fame (IPHF), which displayed photographs and artifacts from a wide collection of cameras and other items preserving the history of photography. The IPHF honors those who have made significant contributions to the art and/or science of photography and moved to St. Louis, Missouri in 2013.

The Museum of Osteology houses over 300 real animal skeletons. Focused on the form and function of the skeletal system, this 7,000-square-foot (650 m²) museum displays hundreds of skulls and skeletons from around the world. Exhibits include adaptation, locomotion, classification, and the diversity of the vertebrate kingdom. The Museum of Osteology is the only one of its kind in America.

The National Cowboy and Western Heritage Museum has galleries of Western art and houses the Hall of Great Western Performers.
