In contrast, the city will also host the American Indian Cultural Center and Museum, whose construction began in 2009 (although completion of the building has been delayed due to insufficient funding), on the south side of Interstate 40, southeast of Bricktown.

The Oklahoma City National Memorial, located in the northern part of downtown Oklahoma City, was created to honor, as stated on its eastern gate inscription, "the victims, survivors, rescuers, and all those who were changed forever on April 19, 1995." The memorial was built on the site formerly occupied by the Alfred P. Murrah Federal Building complex before it was bombed in 1995. The outdoor symbolic memorial is open 24 hours a day free of charge, and the adjacent Memorial Museum, located in the former Journal Record building damaged by the explosion, can be visited for a small fee. The site also houses the National Memorial Institute for the Prevention of Terrorism, a nonprofit, impartial research center dedicated to terrorism prevention.

The American Banjo Museum, located in the Bricktown entertainment district, is dedicated to preserving and promoting the music and heritage of the United States' native musical instrument: the banjo. With a collection valued at $3.5 million, it is truly a national treasure. An interpretive exhibit traces the evolution of the banjo from its humble origins in American slavery to bluegrass, folk music, and world music.

The Oklahoma History Center is the state history museum of Oklahoma. Located across from the governor's mansion at 800 Nazih Zuhdi Drive in northeast Oklahoma City, it opened in 2005 and is operated by the Oklahoma Historical Society. It preserves Oklahoma's history from prehistoric times to the present.

Oklahoma City hosts several professional sports teams, including the Oklahoma City Thunder of the National Basketball Association. The Thunder is the city's second "permanent" major professional sports team, after the now-defunct AFL's Oklahoma Wranglers, and is the third major league team to call the city home, considering the temporary relocation of the New Orleans/Oklahoma City Hornets during the NBA's 2005–06 and 2006–07 seasons.

Other professional sports teams in Oklahoma City include the Oklahoma City Dodgers, the Triple-A affiliate of the Los Angeles Dodgers, the Oklahoma City Energy FC of the United Soccer League, and the Crusaders of the Oklahoma Rugby Football Club of USA Rugby.

The Chesapeake Energy Arena in downtown is the city's primary multipurpose venue, hosting concerts, NHL exhibition games, and many of the city's professional teams. In 2008, the Oklahoma City Thunder became the main tenant. Nearby, in the Bricktown district, Chickasaw Bricktown Ballpark hosts the state's minor league baseball team, the Dodgers. "The Brick," as it is known locally, is considered one of the best minor league ballparks in the country.[citation needed]

Oklahoma City hosts the Big 12 College Baseball Championship, the Softball World Cup, and the annual NCAA Women's College Championship every year. The city hosted the first and second rounds of the NCAA Men's Basketball Championship in 2005 and the Big 12 Men's and Women's Basketball Championships in 2007 and 2009. The region's major universities—the University of Oklahoma, Oklahoma City University, and Oklahoma State University—frequently organize major basketball games and other athletic events at the Chesapeake Energy Arena and the Chickasaw Bricktown Ballpark, although most home games are held at their university-owned stadiums.

Other significant sporting events include thoroughbred and quarter horse racing at Remington Park, as well as numerous horse shows and equestrian events held annually at the state fairgrounds. There are many golf courses and club teams scattered throughout the city.

The state of Oklahoma hosts a highly competitive high school soccer culture, with numerous teams in the Oklahoma City metropolitan area. The Oklahoma Secondary School Activities Association (OSSAA) organizes high school soccer into eight distinct classifications based on school enrollment size. Starting from the largest, the classifications are: 6A, 5A, 4A, 3A, 2A, A, B, and C. The 6A classification is divided into two divisions. Schools in the Oklahoma City area within this division include: Edmond North, Mustang, Moore, Yukon, Edmond Memorial, Edmond Santa Fe, Norman North, Westmoore, Southmoore, Putnam City North, Norman, Putnam City, Putnam City West, U.S. Grant, Midwest City.

The Oklahoma City Thunder of the National Basketball Association (NBA) has been based in Oklahoma City since the 2008–09 season, when owner Clay Bennett relocated the team from Seattle, Washington. The team plays its home games at the Chesapeake Energy Arena in downtown Oklahoma City, which is affectionately referred to in national media as "the Peake" and "Loud City." The team is known by various nicknames, such as "OKC Thunder" and simply "OKC," while its mascot is Rumble the Bison.

After a weak start in Oklahoma City for the 2008–09 season, the Oklahoma City Thunder secured a playoff berth (8th seed) in the 2010 NBA Playoffs the following year, after their first 50-win season, winning two games in the first round against the Los Angeles Lakers. In 2012, Oklahoma City reached the NBA Finals but lost to the Miami Heat in five games. In 2013, the team reached the Western Conference semifinals without star player Russell Westbrook, who was injured during the first-round series against the Houston Rockets, and ultimately lost to the Memphis Grizzlies. In 2014, Oklahoma City reached the NBA Western Conference Finals again, but eventually lost to the San Antonio Spurs in six games.

Oklahoma City Thunder has been regarded by sports analysts as one of the top teams in the NBA's Western Conference and as a media favorite for the future of the league. Oklahoma City has won the Northwest Division title every year since 2009 and has consistently improved its win record, reaching 59 wins in 2014. The team is led by new head coach Billy Donovan and relies on several NBA superstars, including perennial All-Star point guard Russell Westbrook, 2014 MVP and four-time NBA scoring champion Kevin Durant, as well as Defensive Player of the Year candidate and shot-blocker Serge Ibaka.

After Katrina, the NBA's New Orleans Hornets (now the New Orleans Pelicans) were temporarily relocated to the Ford Center, where they played most of their home games during the 2005–06 and 2006–07 seasons. The team became the first NBA team to play regular-season games in the state of Oklahoma. [citation needed] During that time, the team was known as the New Orleans/Oklahoma City Hornets. Eventually, the team returned fully to New Orleans for the 2007–08 season. The Hornets played their final home game in Oklahoma City during the preseason on October 9, 2007 against the Houston Rockets.

One of the most prominent features in the city center is the Crystal Bridge at the Myriad Botanical Gardens, a large urban park in downtown. Designed by I. M. Pei, the Crystal Bridge is a tropical conservatory in the area. The park includes an amphitheater known as the Water Stage. In 2007, following the renovation of the stage, the Oklahoma Shakespeare in the Park relocated to the Myriad Gardens. The Myriad Gardens will undergo a massive renovation in conjunction with the recently constructed Devon Tower building, located directly to their north.

The Oklahoma City Zoo and Botanical Garden hosts many natural habitats, WPA-era architecture and landscapes, and holds major summer concert series at its theater. Oklahoma City also has two amusement parks: the Frontier City theme park and White Water Bay water park. Frontier City is an amusement park themed around the "Old West." The park also features a reenactment of a western gunfight at the "OK Corral" and numerous shops located along the main street of the "Western" town. Frontier City also hosts a national concert tour at its theater during the summer. Oklahoma City also has a year-round racetrack and casino complex, Remington Park, which hosts racing seasons for Quarter horses (March–June) and Thoroughbreds (August–December).

Hiking trails run along Hefner Lake and Overholser Lake in the city's northwest, as well as through the city center along the canal and Oklahoma River. Much of the east bank is occupied by parks and trails, including a new off-leash dog park and the post-war Stars and Stripes Park. Stanley Draper Lake is the city's largest and most remote lake.

Oklahoma City has a large park in each quarter of the city, a feature dating back to the first comprehensive park plan. The Will Rogers, Lincoln, Trosper, and Woodward parks were once connected by the circular Grant Boulevard, parts of which no longer exist. The Martin Park Nature Center is a natural habitat located in the far northwest of Oklahoma City. Will Rogers Park hosts the Lakeview Gardens, the Rose Garden, and the Butterfly Garden, all built during the WPA era. Oklahoma City is home to the American Banjo Museum, which houses a large collection of elaborately decorated banjos from the early 20th century, as well as exhibits on the history of the banjo and its place in American history. Concerts and lectures are also held there.

In April 2005, Oklahoma City's Wiley Post Park skate park was renamed the Mat Hoffman Action Sports Park to honor Mat Hoffman, a resident and entrepreneur from the Oklahoma City area who played a key role in designing the skate park and is a ten-time BMX World Vert champion. In March 2009, the Mat Hoffman Action Sports Park was recognized by the National Geographic Society Travel Guide as one of the "Top Ten."

The city of Oklahoma City has operated under a council-manager form of municipal government since 1927. Mick Cornett is mayor, having been first elected in 2004 and re-elected in 2006, 2010, and 2014. Eight council members represent the eight electoral districts of Oklahoma City. City Manager Jim Couch was appointed in November 2000. Couch had previously served as assistant city manager, director of the Metropolitan Area Projects (MAPS), and director of services prior to his tenure as city manager.

The city hosts several colleges and universities. Oklahoma City University, formerly known as Epworth University, was founded by the Methodist Episcopal Church on September 1, 1904, and is renowned for its programs in performing arts, science, communications, business, law, and athletics. OCU has its main campus in the north-central part of the city, near the Bricktown area. The OCU School of Law is located in the Midtown area, close to downtown, in the former Central High School building.

The University of Oklahoma has several higher education institutions within the city and metropolitan area, with the OU Medicine and University of Oklahoma Health Sciences Center campuses located in the Oklahoma Health Center district on the east side of downtown. The main campus is situated in the southern suburb of Norman. OU Medicine hosts the only Level I trauma center in the state. The OU Health Sciences Center is one of the largest independent medical centers in the country and employs more than 12,000 people. OU is one of only four major universities in the nation operating six medical schools. [clarification needed]

The University of Central Oklahoma, the state's third-largest university, is located in the Edmond suburb just north of the city. Oklahoma Christian University, one of the state's private liberal arts institutions, is situated just south of the Edmond border within Oklahoma City limits.

Oklahoma City Community College, located in southern Oklahoma City, is the second-largest community college in the state. Rose State College is situated east of Oklahoma City in the suburban city of Midwest City. The Oklahoma State University–Oklahoma City campus is located in the "Furniture District" on the Westside. In the northeastern part of the city lies Langston University (HBCU), historically serving the state's African American student population. Langston also has an additional urban campus in the eastern part of the city. Southern Nazarene University, founded by the Church of the Nazarene, is a university located in the suburban town of Bethany within Oklahoma City's boundaries.

Although not technically a university, the FAA's Mike Monroney Aeronautical Center possesses many characteristics of higher education institutions. The FAA Academy is accredited by the North Central Association of Colleges and Schools. The Civil Aerospace Medical Institute (CAMI) has a medical education division responsible for aerospace medicine training as well as training aviation medical examiners in the United States and 93 other countries. Additionally, the National Academies offer Research Partnership Programs for grants and other funding for CAMI research.

Oklahoma City is home to Oklahoma City Public Schools, the largest school district in the state. The district's Classen School of Advanced Studies and Harding High School rank among the top public schools nationwide based on a formula that divides the number of Advanced Placement, International Baccalaureate, and/or Cambridge exams taken by students by the number of graduating seniors. Additionally, Belle Isle Enterprise Middle School, part of OKCPS, has been recognized as the top middle school in the state according to the Academic Achievement Index and received the Blue Ribbon School Award in 2004 and again in 2011. KIPP Reach College Preparatory School in Oklahoma City won the 2012 National Blue Ribbon Award, and its principal, Tracy McDaniel Sr., received the Terrel H. Bell Award for Outstanding Leadership.
The Oklahoma School of Science and Mathematics, serving some of the state's most talented math and science students, is also located in Oklahoma City.

Oklahoma City, Oklahoma has several public career and technology education schools affiliated with the Oklahoma City Public Schools Career and Technology Education Department, the largest of which are Metro Technology Center and Francis Tuttle Technology Center.

Oklahoma City's private career and technology education schools include Oklahoma Technology Institute, Platt College, Vatterott College, and Heritage College. The Dale Rogers Training Center in Oklahoma City is a nonprofit vocational training center for individuals with disabilities.

The Oklahoman is Oklahoma City's primary daily newspaper and the most widely circulated in the state. NewsOK.com is The Oklahoman's online presence. The Oklahoma Gazette is Oklahoma City's independent weekly news publication, featuring local commentary, feature stories, restaurant reviews, movie listings, and coverage of music and entertainment. The Journal Record is the city's daily business newspaper, and okcBIZ is a monthly publication covering business news affecting those living and working in Central Oklahoma.

At the local level, numerous community and international newspapers serve the city's ethnic mosaic; examples include The Black Chronicle, based in Eastside, OK VIETIMES and Oklahoma Chinese Times in the Asian District, and various Spanish-language community publications. The student newspaper of Oklahoma City University is The Campus. LGBTQ+ publications include The Gayly Oklahoman.

The metro area has a lifestyle magazine called Slice Magazine, distributed throughout the region. There is also another magazine called The Edmond Outlook, published by Back40 Design Group, which includes local commentary and compelling human interest stories, mailed directly to more than 50,000 Edmond residents.

Oklahoma City has hosted many pioneers in radio and television broadcasting. WKY Radio in Oklahoma City was the first radio station west of the Mississippi River and the third radio station in the United States. WKY received its federal license in 1921 and has broadcast continuously with the same call letters since 1922. In 1928, WKY was acquired by E.K. Gaylord's Oklahoma Publishing Company and affiliated with the NBC Red Network; in 1949, WKY-TV (channel 4) began broadcasting and later became the first independently owned television station in the U.S. to broadcast in color. In mid-2002, WKY Radio was directly purchased by Citadel Broadcasting, which was later acquired by Cumulus Broadcasting in 2011. The Gaylord family had previously sold WKY-TV in 1976, and the station changed ownership several times (now known as KFOR-TV, it was owned by Tribune Broadcasting as of December 2013).

Major U.S. broadcast television networks have affiliates in the Oklahoma City market, which serves a 34-county area covering central, north-central, and west-central regions of Oklahoma (ranked 41st by Nielsen for television and 48th for radio); these include NBC affiliate KFOR-TV (channel 4), ABC affiliate KOCO-TV (channel 5), CBS affiliate KWTV-DT (channel 9, the flagship station of locally based Griffin Communications), PBS station KETA-TV (channel 13, the flagship station of the state-owned OETA network), Fox affiliate KOKH-TV (channel 25), CW affiliate KOCB (channel 34), independent station KAUT-TV (channel 43), MyNetworkTV affiliate KSBI-TV (channel 52), and KOPX-TV (channel 62), owned and operated by Ion Television. The market also hosts several religious channels, including KTBO-TV (channel 14), owned and operated by TBN, and KOCM (channel 46), owned and operated by Norman-based Daystar.

Oklahoma City is protected by the Oklahoma City Fire Department (OKCFD), which employs 1,015 paid and professional firefighters. The current department chief is G. Keith Bryant, and the department is also managed by three Assistant Chiefs. These assistant chiefs, together with the department chief, oversee the offices of Operational Services, Protective Services, and Support Services. Currently, OKCFD operates from 37 fire stations located across six battalions throughout the city. OKCFD also operates a fleet of firefighting apparatus consisting of 36 engine units (including 30 paramedic engines), 13 ladders, 16 squad patrol units, six water tankers, two hazardous materials units, one Technical Rescue Unit, one Air Supply Unit, six Arson Investigation Units, and one Rehabilitation Unit. Each engine unit is staffed with one driver, one officer, and one to two firefighters, while each ladder company is staffed with one driver, one officer, and one firefighter. The minimum staffing level per shift is 213 personnel. The Oklahoma City Fire Department responds to over 70,000 emergency calls annually.

Oklahoma City is a significant point in the United States Interstate Highway System, where three major highways—Interstate 35, Interstate 40, and Interstate 44—intersect and divide the city. Interstate 240 connects Interstate 40 and Interstate 44 in southern Oklahoma City, while Interstate 235 branches off from Interstate 44 in north-central Oklahoma City and extends toward the center.

Major state highways running through the city include Lake Hefner Parkway (SH-74), Kilpatrick Turnpike, Airport Road (SH-152), and the Broadway Extension (US-77), which continues from I-235 connecting central Oklahoma City to Edmond. Lake Hefner Parkway runs through the northwest part of Oklahoma City, while Airport Road runs through the southwest portion, leading to Will Rogers World Airport. The Kilpatrick Turnpike loops around the northern and western sides of Oklahoma City.

Several major national and state highways also run within Oklahoma City limits. Shields Boulevard (US-77) begins at E.K. Gaylord Boulevard in downtown Oklahoma City and extends south, eventually connecting to I-35 near the Moore suburb. The Northwest Expressway (Oklahoma State Highway 3) runs from North Classen Boulevard in north-central Oklahoma City to its northwestern suburbs.

Two major airports serve Oklahoma City: Will Rogers World Airport and the much smaller Wiley Post Airport (coincidentally, both lost their lives in the same plane crash in Alaska). Will Rogers World Airport, with over 3.6 million passengers annually, is the state's busiest commercial airport. Tinker Air Force Base, located southeast of Oklahoma City, is the largest military air depot nationwide; it serves as a major maintenance and logistics facility for the Navy and Air Force and is the second-largest military installation in the state (after Fort Sill in Lawton).
